                       0b0 Timer condition is not met.
                       0b1 Timer condition is met.
                   When the value of the ENABLE bit is 1, ISTATUS indicates
                   whether the timer condition is met. ISTATUS takes no account
                   of the value of the IMASK bit. If the value of ISTATUS is 1
                   and the value of IMASK is 0 then the timer interrupt is
                   asserted. When the value of the ENABLE bit is 0, the ISTATUS
                   field is unknown. For more information see 'Operation of the
                   CompareValue views of the timers' and 'Operation of the
                   TimerValue views of the timers' in the Arm® Architecture
                   Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile,
                   chapter D6. This bit is read-only.
IMASK, bit [1]   - Timer interrupt mask bit. Permitted values are:
                       0b0 Timer interrupt is not masked by the IMASK bit.
                       0b1 Timer interrupt is masked by the IMASK bit.
                   For more information, see the description of the ISTATUS bit.
ENABLE, bit [0]  - Enables the timer. Permitted values are:
                       0b0 Timer disabled.
                       0b1 Timer enabled.
                   Setting this bit to 0 disables the timer output signal, but
                   the timer value accessible from CNTV_TVAL_EL0 continues to
                   count down. Disabling the output signal might be a power-
                   saving option.

CNTV_CVAL_EL0.purpose:
Holds the compare value for the virtual timer.

CompareValue, bits [0:63] - Holds the EL1 virtual timer CompareValue. When
                            CNTV_CTL_EL0.ENABLE is 1, the timer condition is met
                            when (CNTVCT_EL0 - CompareValue) is greater than or
                            equal to zero. This means that CompareValue acts
                            like a 64-bit upcounter timer. When the timer
                            condition is met:
                              - CNTV_CTL_EL0.ISTATUS is set to 1.
                              - If CNTV_CTL_EL0.IMASK is 0, an interrupt is
                            generated. When CNTV_CTL_EL0.ENABLE is 0, the timer
                            condition is not met, but CNTVCT_EL0 continues to
                            count. If the Generic counter is implemented at a
                            size less than 64 bits, then this field is permitted
                            to be implemented at the same width as the counter,
                            and the upper bits are res0. The value of this field
                            is treated as zero-extended in all counter
                            calculations.

CNTV_TVAL_EL0.purpose:
Holds the timer value for the EL1 virtual timer.

TimerValue, bits [0:31] - The TimerValue view of the EL1 virtual timer. On a
                          read of this register:
                            - If CNTV_CTL_EL0.ENABLE is 0, the value returned is
                          unknown.
                            - If CNTV_CTL_EL0.ENABLE is 1, the value returned is
                          (CNTV_CVAL_EL0 - CNTVCT_EL0). On a write of this
                          register, CNTV_CVAL_EL0 is set to (CNTVCT_EL0 +
                          TimerValue), where TimerValue is treated as a signed
                          32-bit integer. When CNTV_CTL_EL0.ENABLE is 1, the
                          timer condition is met when (CNTVCT_EL0 -
                          CNTV_CVAL_EL0) is greater than or equal to zero. This
                          means that TimerValue acts like a 32-bit downcounter
                          timer. When the timer condition is met:
                            - CNTV_CTL_EL0.ISTATUS is set to 1.
                            - If CNTV_CTL_EL0.IMASK is 0, an interrupt is
                          generated. When CNTV_CTL_EL0.ENABLE is 0, the timer
                          condition is not met, but CNTVCT_EL0 continues to
                          count, so the TimerValue view appears to continue to
                          count down.

CONTEXTIDR_EL1.purpose:
Identifies the current Process Identifier.

The value of the whole of this register is called the Context ID and is used by:

  - The debug logic, for Linked and Unlinked Context ID matching.
  - The trace logic, to identify the current process.

The significance of this register is for debug and trace use only.

This register is used when ARMv8.1-VHE is not implemented, or whenARMv8.1-VHE is
implemented and HCR_EL2.E2H is set to 0.

When ARMv8.1-VHE is implemented and HCR_EL2.E2H is set to 1, CONTEXTIDR_EL2 is
used.

PROCID, bits [0:31] - Process Identifier. This field must be programmed with a
                      unique value that identifies the current process. In
                      AArch32 state, when TTBCR.EAE is set to 0, CONTEXTIDR.ASID
                      holds the ASID. In AArch64 state, CONTEXTIDR_EL1 is
                      independent of the ASID, and for the EL1&0 translation
                      regime either TTBR0_EL1 or TTBR1_EL1 holds the ASID.

CONTEXTIDR_EL2.purpose:
When HCR_EL2.E2H is set to 1, identifies the current Process Identifier.

The value of the whole of this register is called the Context ID and is used by:

  - The debug logic, for Linked and Unlinked Context ID matching.
  - The trace logic, to identify the current process.

The significance of this register is for debug and trace use only.

When HCR_EL2.E2H is 0, CONTEXTIDR_EL2 replaces CONTEXTIDR_EL1 where
CONTEXTIDR_EL1 would usually be used.

PROCID, bits [0:31] - Process Identifier. This field must be programmed with a
                      unique value that identifies the current process. In
                      AArch32 state, when TTBCR.EAE is set to 0, CONTEXTIDR.ASID
                      holds the ASID. In AArch64 state, CONTEXTIDR_EL2 is
                      independent of the ASID, and for the EL2&0 translation
                      regime either TTBR0_EL2 or TTBR1_EL2 holds the ASID.

CPACR_EL1.purpose:
Controls access to trace, SVE, Advanced SIMD and floating-point functionality.

TTA, bit [28]      - Traps EL0 and EL1 System register accesses to all
                     implemented trace registers to EL1, or to EL2 when it is
                     implemented and enabled for the current Security state and
                     HCR_EL2.TGE is 1, from both Execution states as follows.
FPEN, bits [20:21] - Traps EL0 and EL1 accesses to the SVE, Advanced SIMD, and
                     floating-point registers to EL1, reported using EC syndrome
                     value 0x07, or to EL2 reported using EC syndrome value
                     0x00, when EL2 is implemented and enabled for the current
                     Security state and HCR_EL2.TGE is 1, from both Execution
                     states as follows.
ZEN, bits [16:17]  - Traps SVE instructions and instructions that access SVE
                     System registers at EL0 and EL1 to EL1, or to EL2 when it
                     is implemented and enabled for the current Security state
                     and HCR_EL2.TGE is 1.

CPTR_EL2.purpose:
Controls:

  - Trapping to EL2 of access to CPACR, CPACR_EL1, trace functionality, and to
SVE, Advanced SIMD and floating-point functionality.
  - EL2 access to trace functionality, and to SVE, Advanced SIMD and floating-
point functionality.

TCPAC, bit [31]    - When HCR_EL2.TGE is 0, traps EL1 accesses to CPACR_EL1
                     reported using EC syndrome value 0x18, and accesses to
                     CPACR reported using EC syndrome value 0x03, to EL2 when
                     EL2 is enabled in the current Security state.
TAM, bit [30]      - Trap Activity Monitor access.
TTA, bit [28]      - Traps System register accesses to all implemented trace
                     registers to EL2 when EL2 is enabled in the current
                     Security state, from both Execution states, as follows.
FPEN, bits [20:21] - Traps EL0, EL2 and, when HCR_EL2.TGE is 0, EL1 accesses to
                     the SVE, Advanced SIMD and floating-point registers to EL2
                     when EL2 is enabled in the current Security state, from
                     both Execution states.
ZEN, bits [16:17]  - Traps execution at EL2, EL1, and EL0 of SVE instructions or
                     instructions that access SVE System registers to EL2 when
                     EL2 is enabled in the current Security state.

CPTR_EL3.purpose:
Controls trapping to EL3 of access to CPACR_EL1, CPTR_EL2, trace functionality
and registers associated with SVE, Advanced SIMD and floating-point execution.
Also controls EL3 access to trace functionality and registers associated with
SVE, Advanced SIMD and floating-point execution.

TCPAC, bit [31] - Traps all of the following to EL3, from both Security states
                  and both Execution states.
TAM, bit [30]   - Trap Activity Monitor access.
TTA, bit [20]   - Traps System register accesses.
TFP, bit [10]   - Traps all accesses to SVE, Advanced SIMD and floating-point
                  functionality, from all Exception levels, both Security
                  states, and both Execution states, to EL3.
EZ, bit [8]     - Traps all accesses to SVE functionality and registers from all
                  Exception levels, and both Security states, to EL3.

CSSELR_EL1.purpose:
Selects the current Cache Size ID Register, CCSIDR_EL1, by specifying the
required cache level and the cache type (either instruction or data cache).

TnD, bit [4]      - Allocation Tag not Data bit.
                        0b0 Data, Instruction or Unified cache.
                        0b1 Separate Allocation Tag cache.
                    When CSSELR_EL1.InD == 1, this bit is res0. If
                    CSSELR_EL1.Level is programmed to a cache level that is not
                    implemented, then the value for this field on a read of
                    CSSELR_EL1 is unknown.
Level, bits [1:3] - Cache level of required cache.
                        0b000 Level 1 cache.
                        0b001 Level 2 cache.
                        0b010 Level 3 cache.
                        0b011 Level 4 cache.
                        0b100 Level 5 cache.
                        0b101 Level 6 cache.
                        0b110 Level 7 cache.
                    All other values are reserved. If CSSELR_EL1.Level is
                    programmed to a cache level that is not implemented, then
                    the value for this field on a read of CSSELR_EL1 is unknown.
InD, bit [0]      - Instruction not Data bit.
                        0b0 Data or unified cache.
                        0b1 Instruction cache.
                    If CSSELR_EL1.Level is programmed to a cache level that is
                    not implemented, then a read of CSSELR_EL1 is constrained
                    unpredictable, and returns unknown values for
                    CSSELR_EL1.{Level, InD}.

CTR_EL0.purpose:
Provides information about the architecture of the caches.

TminLine, bits [32:37] - Tag minimum Line.
DIC, bit [29]          - Instruction cache invalidation requirements for
                         instruction to data coherence.
IDC, bit [28]          - Data cache clean requirements for instruction to data
                         coherence.
CWG, bits [24:27]      - Cache writeback granule.
ERG, bits [20:23]      - Exclusives reservation granule.
DminLine, bits [16:19] - Log_2 of the number of words in the smallest cache line
                         of all the data caches and unified caches that are
                         controlled by the PE.
L1Ip, bits [14:15]     - Level 1 instruction cache policy.
IminLine, bits [0:3]   - Log_2 of the number of words in the smallest cache line
                         of all the instruction caches that are controlled by
                         the PE.

CurrentEL.purpose:
Holds the current Exception level.

EL, bits [2:3] - Current Exception level. Possible values of this field are:
                     0b00 EL0
                     0b01 EL1
                     0b10 EL2
                     0b11 EL3
                 When the HCR_EL2.NV bit is 1, EL1 read accesses to the
                 CurrentEL register return the value of 0b10 in this field.

DACR32_EL2.purpose:
Allows access to the AArch32 DACR register from AArch64 state only. Its value
has no effect on execution in AArch64 state.

D<n>, bits [0:31] - Domain n access permission, where n = 0 to 15. Permitted
                    values are:
                        0b00 No access. Any access to the domain generates a
                    Domain fault.
                        0b01 Client. Accesses are checked against the permission
                    bits in the translation tables.
                        0b11 Manager. Accesses are not checked against the
                    permission bits in the translation tables.
                    The value 0b10 is reserved.

DAIF.purpose:
Allows access to the interrupt mask bits.

D, bit [9] - Process state D mask. The possible values of this bit are:
                 0b0 Watchpoint, Breakpoint, and Software Step exceptions
             targeted at the current Exception level are not masked.
                 0b1 Watchpoint, Breakpoint, and Software Step exceptions
             targeted at the current Exception level are masked.
             When the target Exception level of the debug exception is higher
             than the current Exception level, the exception is not masked by
             this bit.
A, bit [8] - SError interrupt mask bit. The possible values of this bit are:
                 0b0 Exception not masked.
                 0b1 Exception masked.
I, bit [7] - IRQ mask bit. The possible values of this bit are:
                 0b0 Exception not masked.
                 0b1 Exception masked.
F, bit [6] - FIQ mask bit. The possible values of this bit are:
                 0b0 Exception not masked.
                 0b1 Exception masked.

DBGAUTHSTATUS_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the state of the implementation defined
authentication interface for debug.

SNID, bits [6:7]  - Secure non-invasive debug.
SNID, bits [6:7]  - Secure non-invasive debug.
SID, bits [4:5]   - Secure invasive debug.
NSNID, bits [2:3] - Non-secure non-invasive debug.
NSNID, bits [2:3] - Non-secure non-invasive debug.
NSID, bits [0:1]  - Non-secure invasive debug.

DBGBCR<n>_EL1.purpose:
Holds control information for a breakpoint. Forms breakpoint n together with
value register DBGBVR<n>_EL1.

BT, bits [20:23]  - Breakpoint Type.
LBN, bits [16:19] - Linked breakpoint number.
SSC, bits [14:15] - Security state control.
HMC, bit [13]     - Higher mode control.
BAS, bits [5:8]   - Byte address select.
PMC, bits [1:2]   - Privilege mode control.
E, bit [0]        - Enable breakpoint DBGBVR<n>_EL1.

DBGBVR<n>_EL1.purpose:
Holds a virtual address, or a VMID and/or a context ID, for use in breakpoint
matching. Forms breakpoint n together with control register DBGBCR<n>_EL1.

VA[52:49], bits [49:52] - Extension to VA[48:2]. See VA[48:2] for more details.
RESS[3:0], bits [49:52] - Extension to RESS[14:4]. See RESS[14:4] for more
                          details.
VA[48:2], bits [2:48]   - Bits[48:2] of the address value for comparison. When
                          ARMv8.2-LVA is implemented, VA[52:49] forms the upper
                          part of the address value. Otherwise, VA[52:49] are
                          RESS.

DBGCLAIMCLR_EL1.purpose:
Used by software to read the values of the CLAIM tag bits, and to clear CLAIM
tag bits to 0.

The architecture does not define any functionality for the CLAIM tag bits.

CLAIM tags are typically used for communication between the debugger and target
software.

Used in conjunction with the DBGCLAIMSET_EL1 register.

CLAIM, bits [0:7] - Read or clear CLAIM tag bits. Reading this field returns the
                    current value of the CLAIM tag bits. Writing a 1 to one of
                    these bits clears the corresponding CLAIM tag bit to 0. This
                    is an indirect write to the CLAIM tag bits. A single write
                    operation can clear multiple CLAIM tag bits to 0. Writing 0
                    to one of these bits has no effect.

DBGCLAIMSET_EL1.purpose:
Used by software to set the CLAIM tag bits to 1.

The architecture does not define any functionality for the CLAIM tag bits.

CLAIM tags are typically used for communication between the debugger and target
software.

Used in conjunction with the DBGCLAIMCLR_EL1 register.

CLAIM, bits [0:7] - Set CLAIM tag bits. This field is RAO. Writing a 1 to one of
                    these bits sets the corresponding CLAIM tag bit to 1. This
                    is an indirect write to the CLAIM tag bits. A single write
                    operation can set multiple CLAIM tag bits to 1. Writing 0 to
                    one of these bits has no effect.

DBGDTRRX_EL0.purpose:
Transfers data from an external debugger to the PE. For example, it is used by a
debugger transferring commands and data to a debug target. See DBGDTR_EL0 for
additional architectural mappings. It is a component of the Debug Communications
Channel.

bits [0:31] - Update DTRRX. Reads of this register:
                -  If RXfull is set to 1, return the last value written to
              DTRRX.
                -  If RXfull is set to 0, return an unknown value. After the
              read, RXfull is cleared to 0. For the full behavior of the Debug
              Communications Channel, see The Debug Communication Channel and
              Instruction Transfer Register.

DBGDTRTX_EL0.purpose:
Transfers data from the PE to an external debugger. For example, it is used by a
debug target to transfer data to the debugger. See DBGDTR_EL0 for additional
architectural mappings. It is a component of the Debug Communication Channel.

bits [0:31] - Return DTRTX. Writes to this register:
                -  If TXfull is set to 1, set DTRRX and DTRTX to unknown.
                -  If TXfull is set to 0, update the value in DTRTX. After the
              write, TXfull is set to 1. For the full behavior of the Debug
              Communications Channel, see The Debug Communication Channel and
              Instruction Transfer Register.

DBGDTR_EL0.purpose:
Transfers 64 bits of data between the PE and an external debugger. Can transfer
both ways using only a single register.

HighWord, bits [32:63] - Writes to this register set DTRRX to the value in this
                         field and do not change RXfull. Reads of this register:
                           -  If RXfull is set to 1, return the last value
                         written to DTRTX.
                           -  If RXfull is set to 0, return an unknown value.
                         After the read, RXfull is cleared to 0.
LowWord, bits [0:31]   - Writes to this register set DTRTX to the value in this
                         field and set TXfull to 1. Reads of this register:
                           -  If RXfull is set to 1, return the last value
                         written to DTRRX.
                           -  If RXfull is set to 0, return an unknown value.
                         After the read, RXfull is cleared to 0.

DBGPRCR_EL1.purpose:
Controls behavior of the PE on powerdown request.

CORENPDRQ, bit [0] - Core no powerdown request. Requests emulation of powerdown.
                     This request is typically passed to an external power
                     controller. This means that whether a request causes power
                     up is dependent on the implementation defined nature of the
                     system. The power controller must not allow the Core power
                     domain to switch off while this bit is 1.
                         0b0 If the system responds to a powerdown request, it
                     powers down Core power domain.
                         0b1 If the system responds to a powerdown request, it
                     does not powerdown the Core power domain, but instead
                     emulates a powerdown of that domain.
CORENPDRQ, bit [0] - Core no powerdown request. Requests emulation of powerdown.
                     This request is typically passed to an external power
                     controller. This means that whether a request causes power
                     up is dependent on the implementation defined nature of the
                     system. The power controller must not allow the Core power
                     domain to switch off while this bit is 1.
                         0b0 If the system responds to a powerdown request, it
                     powers down Core power domain.
                         0b1 If the system responds to a powerdown request, it
                     does not powerdown the Core power domain, but instead
                     emulates a powerdown of that domain.

DBGVCR32_EL2.purpose:
Allows access to the AArch32 register DBGVCR from AArch64 state only. Its value
has no effect on execution in AArch64 state.

NSF, bit [31] - FIQ vector catch enable in Non-secure state. The exception
                vector offset is 0x1C.
NSI, bit [30] - IRQ vector catch enable in Non-secure state. The exception
                vector offset is 0x18.
NSD, bit [28] - Data Abort vector catch enable in Non-secure state. The
                exception vector offset is 0x10.
NSP, bit [27] - Prefetch Abort vector catch enable in Non-secure state. The
                exception vector offset is 0x0C.
NSS, bit [26] - Supervisor Call (SVC) vector catch enable in Non-secure state.
                The exception vector offset is 0x08.
NSU, bit [25] - Undefined Instruction vector catch enable in Non-secure state.
                The exception vector offset is 0x04.
SF, bit [7]   - FIQ vector catch enable in Secure state. The exception vector
                offset is 0x1C.
SI, bit [6]   - IRQ vector catch enable in Secure state. The exception vector
                offset is 0x18.
SD, bit [4]   - Data Abort vector catch enable in Secure state. The exception
                vector offset is 0x10.
SP, bit [3]   - Prefetch Abort vector catch enable in Secure state. The
                exception vector offset is 0x0C.
SS, bit [2]   - Supervisor Call (SVC) vector catch enable in Secure state. The
                exception vector offset is 0x08.
SU, bit [1]   - Undefined Instruction vector catch enable in Secure state. The
                exception vector offset is 0x04.

DBGWCR<n>_EL1.purpose:
Holds control information for a watchpoint. Forms watchpoint n together with
value register DBGWVR<n>_EL1.

MASK, bits [24:28] - Address mask.
WT, bit [20]       - Watchpoint type.
LBN, bits [16:19]  - Linked breakpoint number.
SSC, bits [14:15]  - Security state control.
HMC, bit [13]      - Higher mode control.
BAS, bits [5:12]   - Byte address select.
LSC, bits [3:4]    - Load/store control.
PAC, bits [1:2]    - Privilege of access control.
E, bit [0]         - Enable watchpoint n.

DBGWVR<n>_EL1.purpose:
Holds a data address value for use in watchpoint matching. Forms watchpoint n
together with control register DBGWCR<n>_EL1.

VA[52:49], bits [49:52] - Extension to VA[48:2]. See VA[48:2] for more details.
RESS[3:0], bits [49:52] - Extension to RESS[14:4]. See RESS[14:4] for more
                          details.
VA[48:2], bits [2:48]   - Bits[48:2] of the address value for comparison. When
                          ARMv8.2-LVA is implemented, VA[52:49] forms the upper
                          part of the address value. Otherwise, VA[52:49] are
                          RESS. Arm deprecates setting DBGWVR<n>_EL1[2] == 1.

DCZID_EL0.purpose:
Indicates the block size that is written with byte values of 0 by the DC ZVA
(Data Cache Zero by Address) System instruction.

If ARMv8.5-MemTag is implemented, this register also indicates the granularity
at which the DC GVA and DC GZVA instructions write.

DZP, bit [4]   - Data Zero Prohibited. This field indicates whether use of DC
                 ZVA instructions is permitted or prohibited. If ARMv8.5-MemTag
                 is implemented, this field also indicates whether use of the DC
                 GVA and DC GZVA instructions are permitted or prohibited.
                     0b0 Instructions are permitted.
                     0b1 Instructions are prohibited.
                 The value read from this field is governed by the access state
                 and the values of the HCR_EL2.TDZ and SCTLR_EL1.DZE bits.
BS, bits [0:3] - Log_2 of the block size in words. The maximum size supported is
                 2KB (value == 9).

DISR_EL1.purpose:
Records that an SError interrupt has been consumed by an ESB instruction.

A, bit [31]       - Set to 1 when an ESB instruction defers an asynchronous
                    SError interrupt. If the implementation does not include any
                    sources of SError interrupt that can be synchronized by an
                    Error Synchronization Barrier, then this bit is res0.
IDS, bit [24]     - Indicates the deferred SError interrupt type.
                        0b0 Deferred error uses architecturally-defined format.
AET, bits [10:12] - Asynchronous Error Type. See the description of ESR_ELx.AET
                    for an SError interrupt.
EA, bit [9]       - External abort Type. See the description of ESR_ELx.EA for
                    an SError interrupt.
DFSC, bits [0:5]  - Fault Status Code. See the description of ESR_ELx.DFSC for
                    an SError interrupt.

DIT.purpose:
Allows access to the Data Independent Timing bit.

DIT, bit [24] - Data Independent Timing.
                    0b0 The architecture makes no statement about the timing
                properties of any instructions.
                    0b1 The architecture requires that:
                  -  The timing of every load and store instruction is
                insensitive to the value of the data being loaded or stored.
                  -  For certain data processing instructions, the instruction
                takes a time which is independent of:
                    -  The values of the data supplied in any of its registers.
                    -  The values of the NZCV flags.
                  -  For certain data processing instructions, the response of
                the instruction to asynchronous exceptions does not vary based
                on:
                    -  The values of the data supplied in any of its registers.
                    -  The values of the NZCV flags.

DLR_EL0.purpose:
In Debug state, holds the address to restart from.

bits [0:63] - Restart address.

DSPSR_EL0.purpose:
Holds the saved process state for Debug state. On entering Debug state, PSTATE
information is written to this register. On exiting Debug state, values are
copied from this register to PSTATE.

N, bit [31]           - Negative Condition flag.
Z, bit [30]           - Zero Condition flag.
C, bit [29]           - Carry Condition flag.
V, bit [28]           - Overflow Condition flag.
Q, bit [27]           - Overflow or saturation flag.
IT[1:0], bits [25:26] - If-Then.
DIT, bit [24]         - Data Independent Timing.
SSBS, bit [23]        - Speculative Store Bypass.
PAN, bit [22]         - Privileged Access Never.
SS, bit [21]          - Software Step.
IL, bit [20]          - Illegal Execution state.
GE, bits [16:19]      - Greater than or Equal flags.
IT[7:2], bits [10:15] - If-Then.
E, bit [9]            - Endianness.
A, bit [8]            - SError interrupt mask.
I, bit [7]            - IRQ interrupt mask.
F, bit [6]            - FIQ interrupt mask.
T, bit [5]            - T32 Instruction set state.
M[4], bit [4]         - Execution state.
M[3:0], bits [0:3]    - AArch32 Mode.

ELR_EL1.purpose:
When taking an exception to EL1, holds the address to return to.

bits [0:63] - Return address. An exception return from EL1 using AArch64 makes
              ELR_EL1 become unknown.

ELR_EL2.purpose:
When taking an exception to EL2, holds the address to return to.

bits [0:63] - Return address. An exception return from EL2 using AArch64 makes
              ELR_EL2 become unknown. When EL2 is in AArch32 Execution state and
              an exception is taken from EL0, EL1, or EL2 to EL3 and AArch64
              execution, the upper 32-bits of ELR_EL2 are either set to 0 or
              hold the same value that they did before AArch32 execution. Which
              option is adopted is determined by an implementation, and might
              vary dynamically within an implementation. Correspondingly
              software must regard the value as being an unknown choice between
              the two values.

ELR_EL3.purpose:
When taking an exception to EL3, holds the address to return to.

bits [0:63] - Return address. An exception return from EL3 using AArch64 makes
              ELR_EL3 become unknown.

ERRIDR_EL1.purpose:
Defines the highest numbered index of the error records that can be accessed
through the Error Record System registers.

NUM, bits [0:15] - Highest numbered index of the records that can be accessed
                   through the Error Record System registers plus one. Zero
                   indicates that no records can be accessed through the Error
                   Record System registers. Each implemented record is owned by
                   a node. A node might own multiple records.

ERRSELR_EL1.purpose:
Selects an error record to be accessed through the Error Record System
registers.

SEL, bits [0:15] - Selects the record accessed through the ERX registers. For
                   example, if ERRSELR_EL1.SEL is set to 0x4, then direct reads
                   and writes of ERXSTATUS_EL1 access ERR4STATUS.
                   If ERRSELR_EL1.SEL is set to a value greater than or equal to
                   ERRIDR_EL1.NUM, then all of the following apply:
                     -  The value read back from ERRSELR_EL1.SEL is unknown.
                     -  One of the following occurs:
                       -  An unknown error record is selected.
                       -  The ERX* registers are RAZ/WI.
                       -  ERX* register reads and writes are NOPs.
                       -  ERX* register reads and writes are undefined.

ERXADDR_EL1.purpose:
Accesses ERR<n>ADDR for the error record selected by ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

bits [0:63] - ERXADDR_EL1 accesses ERR<n>ADDR, where n is the value in
              ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

ERXCTLR_EL1.purpose:
Accesses ERR<n>CTLR for the error record selected by ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

bits [0:63] - ERXCTLR_EL1 accesses ERR<n>CTLR, where n is the value in
              ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

ERXFR_EL1.purpose:
Accesses ERR<n>FR for the error record selected by ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

bits [0:63] - ERXFR_EL1 accesses ERR<n>FR, where n is the value in
              ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

ERXMISC0_EL1.purpose:
Accesses ERR<n>MISC0 for the error record selected by ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

bits [0:63] - ERXMISC0_EL1 accesses ERR<n>MISC0, where n is the value in
              ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

ERXMISC1_EL1.purpose:
Accesses ERR<n>MISC1 for the error record selected by ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

bits [0:63] - ERXMISC1_EL1 accesses ERR<n>MISC1, where n is the value in
              ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

ERXMISC2_EL1.purpose:
Accesses ERR<n>MISC2 for the error record selected by ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

bits [0:63] - ERXMISC2_EL1 accesses ERR<n>MISC2, where n is the value in
              ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

ERXMISC3_EL1.purpose:
Accesses ERR<n>MISC3 for the error record selected by ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

bits [0:63] - ERXMISC3_EL1 accesses ERR<n>MISC3, where n is the value in
              ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

ERXPFGCDN_EL1.purpose:
Accesses the ERR<n>PFGCDN register for the error record selected by
ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

bits [0:63] - ERXPFGCDN_EL1 accesses ERR<n>PFGCDN, where n is the value in
              ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

ERXPFGCTL_EL1.purpose:
Accesses the ERR<n>PFGCTL register for the error record selected by
ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

bits [0:63] - ERXPFGCTL_EL1 accesses ERR<n>PFGCTL, where n is the value in
              ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

ERXPFGF_EL1.purpose:
Accesses the ERR<n>PFGF register for the error record selected by
ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

bits [0:63] - ERXPFGF_EL1 accesses ERR<n>PFGF, where n is the value in

ERXSTATUS_EL1.long_name: Selected Error Record Primary Status Register
ERXSTATUS_EL1.purpose:
Accesses ERR<n>STATUS for the error record selected by ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

bits [0:63] - ERXSTATUS_EL1 accesses ERR<n>STATUS, where n is the value in
              ERRSELR_EL1.SEL.

ESR_EL1.purpose:
Holds syndrome information for an exception taken to EL1.

EC, bits [26:31] - Exception Class.
IL, bit [25]     - Instruction Length for synchronous exceptions.
ISS, bits [0:24] - Instruction Specific Syndrome.

ESR_EL2.purpose:
Holds syndrome information for an exception taken to EL2.

EC, bits [26:31] - Exception Class.
IL, bit [25]     - Instruction Length for synchronous exceptions.
ISS, bits [0:24] - Instruction Specific Syndrome.

ESR_EL3.purpose:
Holds syndrome information for an exception taken to EL3.

EC, bits [26:31] - Exception Class.
IL, bit [25]     - Instruction Length for synchronous exceptions.
ISS, bits [0:24] - Instruction Specific Syndrome.

FAR_EL1.purpose:
Holds the faulting Virtual Address for all synchronous Instruction or Data
Abort, PC alignment fault and Watchpoint exceptions that are taken to EL1.

bits [0:63] - Faulting Virtual Address for synchronous exceptions taken to EL1.

FAR_EL2.purpose:
Holds the faulting Virtual Address for all synchronous Instruction or Data
Abort, PC alignment fault and Watchpoint exceptions that are taken to EL2.

bits [0:63] - Faulting Virtual Address for synchronous exceptions taken to EL2.

FAR_EL3.purpose:
Holds the faulting Virtual Address for all synchronous Instruction or Data Abort
and PC alignment fault exceptions that are taken to EL3.

bits [0:63] - Faulting Virtual Address for synchronous exceptions taken to EL3.

FPCR.purpose:
Controls floating-point behavior.

AHP, bit [26]        - Alternative half-precision control bit:
DN, bit [25]         - Default NaN mode control bit:
FZ, bit [24]         - Flush-to-zero mode control bit:
RMode, bits [22:23]  - Rounding Mode control field.
Stride, bits [20:21] - This field has no function in AArch64 state, and non-zero
                       values are ignored during execution in AArch64  state. It
                       is included only for context saving and restoration of
                       the AArch32 FPSCR.Stride field.
FZ16, bit [19]       - Flush-to-zero mode control bit on half-precision data-
                       processing instructions:
Len, bits [16:18]    - This field has no function in AArch64 state, and non-zero
                       values are ignored during execution in AArch64  state. It
                       is included only for context saving and restoration of
                       the AArch32 FPSCR.Len field.
IDE, bit [15]        - Input Denormal floating-point exception trap enable.
IXE, bit [12]        - Inexact floating-point exception trap enable.
UFE, bit [11]        - Underflow floating-point exception trap enable.
OFE, bit [10]        - Overflow floating-point exception trap enable.
DZE, bit [9]         - Divide by Zero floating-point exception trap enable.
IOE, bit [8]         - Invalid Operation floating-point exception trap enable.

FPEXC32_EL2.purpose:
Allows access to the AArch32 register FPEXC from AArch64 state only. Its value
has no effect on execution in AArch64 state.

EX, bit [31]        - Exception bit.
EN, bit [30]        - Enables access to the Advanced SIMD and floating-point
                      functionality from all Exception levels, except that
                      setting this field to 0 does not disable the following.
DEX, bit [29]       - Defined synchronous exception on floating-point execution.
FP2V, bit [28]      - FPINST2 instruction valid bit.
VV, bit [27]        - VECITR valid bit.
TFV, bit [26]       - Trapped Fault Valid bit.
VECITR, bits [8:10] - Vector iteration count.
IDF, bit [7]        - Input Denormal trapped exception bit.
IXF, bit [4]        - Inexact trapped exception bit.
UFF, bit [3]        - Underflow trapped exception bit.
OFF, bit [2]        - Overflow trapped exception bit.
DZF, bit [1]        - Divide by Zero trapped exception bit.
IOF, bit [0]        - Invalid Operation trapped exception bit.

FPSR.purpose:
Provides floating-point system status information.

N, bit [31]  - Negative condition flag for AArch32 floating-point comparison
               operations.
Z, bit [30]  - Zero condition flag for AArch32 floating-point comparison
               operations.
C, bit [29]  - Carry condition flag for AArch32 floating-point comparison
               operations.
V, bit [28]  - Overflow condition flag for AArch32 floating-point comparison
               operations.
QC, bit [27] - Cumulative saturation bit, Advanced SIMD only.
IDC, bit [7] - Input Denormal cumulative floating-point exception bit.
IXC, bit [4] - Inexact cumulative floating-point exception bit.
UFC, bit [3] - Underflow cumulative floating-point exception bit.
OFC, bit [2] - Overflow cumulative floating-point exception bit.
DZC, bit [1] - Divide by Zero cumulative floating-point exception bit.
IOC, bit [0] - Invalid Operation cumulative floating-point exception bit.

GCR_EL1.purpose:
Tag Control Register.

RRND, bit [16]       - Controls whether RandomTag() generates a deterministic
                       value solely based on the contents of RGSR_EL1, or a non-
                       deterministic value.
                           0b0 Generate a deterministic value based on RGSR_EL1.
                           0b1 Generate an implementation defined non-
                       deterministic value.
                       When the value of GCR_EL1.RRND is 1, the value generated
                       does not need to be cryptographically random. A similar
                       algorithm to that used when RRND=0 but with free running
                       clock is sufficient.
Exclude, bits [0:15] - Allocation Tag values excluded from selection by
                       ChooseNonExcludedTag().

GMID_EL1.purpose:
Indicates the block size that is accessed by the LDGM and STGM System
instructions.

BS, bits [0:3] - Log_2 of the block size in words. The minimum supported size is
                 16B (value == 2) and the maximum is 256B (value == 6).

HACR_EL2.purpose:
Controls trapping to EL2 of implementation defined aspects of EL1 or EL0
operation.

Arm recommends that the values in this register do not cause unnecessary traps
to EL2 when HCR_EL2.{E2H, TGE} == {1, 1}.

HAFGRTR_EL2.long_name: Hypervisor Activity Monitors Fine-Grained Read Trap Register

                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVTYPER1<15> at
                             EL0 using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVCNTR115_EL0, bit [48]  - Trap MRS reads of AMEVCNTR1<15>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVCNTR1<15> at EL0
                             using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.

                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVTYPER1<14> at
                             EL0 using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVCNTR114_EL0, bit [46]  - Trap MRS reads of AMEVCNTR1<14>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVCNTR1<14> at EL0
                             using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVTYPER113_EL0, bit [45] - Trap MRS reads of AMEVTYPER1<13>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVTYPER1<13> at

AMEVCNTR113_EL0, bit [44]  - Trap MRS reads of AMEVCNTR1<13>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVCNTR1<13> at EL0
                             using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVTYPER112_EL0, bit [43] - Trap MRS reads of AMEVTYPER1<12>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVTYPER1<12> at
                             EL0 using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVCNTR112_EL0, bit [42]  - Trap MRS reads of AMEVCNTR1<12>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVCNTR1<12> at EL0
                             using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVTYPER111_EL0, bit [41] - Trap MRS reads of AMEVTYPER1<11>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVTYPER1<11> at
                             EL0 using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVCNTR111_EL0, bit [40]  - Trap MRS reads of AMEVCNTR1<11>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0

AMEVTYPER110_EL0, bit [39] - Trap MRS reads of AMEVTYPER1<10>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVTYPER1<10> at
                             EL0 using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVCNTR110_EL0, bit [38]  - Trap MRS reads of AMEVCNTR1<10>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVCNTR1<10> at EL0
                             using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVTYPER19_EL0, bit [37]  - Trap MRS reads of AMEVTYPER1<9>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVTYPER1<9> at EL0
                             using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVCNTR19_EL0, bit [36]   - Trap MRS reads of AMEVCNTR1<9>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVCNTR1<9> at EL0
                             using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVTYPER18_EL0, bit [35]  - Trap MRS reads of AMEVTYPER1<8>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVTYPER1<8> at EL0
                             using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVCNTR18_EL0, bit [34]   - Trap MRS reads of AMEVCNTR1<8>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVCNTR1<8> at EL0
                             using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVTYPER17_EL0, bit [33]  - Trap MRS reads of AMEVTYPER1<7>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVTYPER1<7> at EL0
                             using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVCNTR17_EL0, bit [32]   - Trap MRS reads of AMEVCNTR1<7>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVCNTR1<7> at EL0

AMEVTYPER16_EL0, bit [31]  - Trap MRS reads of AMEVTYPER1<6>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0

AMEVCNTR16_EL0, bit [30]   - Trap MRS reads of AMEVCNTR1<6>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0

AMEVTYPER15_EL0, bit [29]  - Trap MRS reads of AMEVTYPER1<5>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVTYPER1<5> at EL0
                             using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVCNTR15_EL0, bit [28]   - Trap MRS reads of AMEVCNTR1<5>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0
                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of AMEVCNTR1<5> at EL0
                             using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
AMEVTYPER14_EL0, bit [27]  - Trap MRS reads of AMEVTYPER1<4>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0

AMEVCNTR14_EL0, bit [26]   - Trap MRS reads of AMEVCNTR1<4>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0

AMEVTYPER13_EL0, bit [25]  - Trap MRS reads of AMEVTYPER1<3>_EL0 at EL1 and EL0

HCR_EL2.purpose:
Provides configuration controls for virtualization, including defining whether
various operations are trapped to EL2.

TWEDEL, bits [60:63] - TWE Delay.
TWEDEn, bit [59]     - TWE Delay Enable.
TID5, bit [58]       - Trap ID group 5.
DCT, bit [57]        - Default Cacheability Tagging.
ATA, bit [56]        - Allocation Tag Access.
TTLBOS, bit [55]     - Trap TLB maintenance instructions that operate on the
                       Outer Shareable domain.
TTLBIS, bit [54]     - Trap TLB maintenance instructions that operate on the
                       Inner Shareable domain.
EnSCXT, bit [53]     - Enable Access to the SCXTNUM_EL1 and SCXTNUM_EL0
                       registers.
TOCU, bit [52]       - Trap cache maintenance instructions that operate to the
                       Point of Unification.
AMVOFFEN, bit [51]   - Activity Monitors Virtual Offsets Enable.
TICAB, bit [50]      - Trap ICIALLUIS/IC IALLUIS cache maintenance instructions.
TID4, bit [49]       - Trap ID group 4.
FIEN, bit [47]       - Fault Injection Enable.
FWB, bit [46]        - Defines the combined cacheability attributes in a 2 stage
                       translation regime.
NV2, bit [45]        - Nested Virtualization.
AT, bit [44]         - Address Translation.
NV1, bit [43]        - Nested Virtualization.
NV1, bit [43]        - Nested Virtualization.
NV, bit [42]         - Nested Virtualization.
NV, bit [42]         - Nested Virtualization.
API, bit [41]        - Controls the use of instructions related to Pointer
                       Authentication.
APK, bit [40]        - Trap registers holding "key" values for Pointer
                       Authentication.
MIOCNCE, bit [38]    - Mismatched Inner/Outer Cacheable Non-Coherency Enable,
                       for the EL1&0 translation regimes.
TEA, bit [37]        - Route synchronous External abort exceptions to EL2.
TERR, bit [36]       - Trap Error record accesses.
TLOR, bit [35]       - Trap LOR registers.
E2H, bit [34]        - EL2 Host.
ID, bit [33]         - Stage 2 Instruction access cacheability disable.
CD, bit [32]         - Stage 2 Data access cacheability disable.
RW, bit [31]         - Execution state control for lower Exception levels:
TRVM, bit [30]       - Trap Reads of Virtual Memory controls.
HCD, bit [29]        - HVC instruction disable.
TDZ, bit [28]        - Trap DC ZVA instructions.
TGE, bit [27]        - Trap General Exceptions, from EL0.
TVM, bit [26]        - Trap Virtual Memory controls.
TTLB, bit [25]       - Trap TLB maintenance instructions.
TTLB, bit [25]       - Trap TLB maintenance instructions.
TPU, bit [24]        - Trap cache maintenance instructions that operate to the
                       Point of Unification.
TPCP, bit [23]       - Trap data or unified cache maintenance instructions that
                       operate to the Point of Coherency or Persistence.
TPC, bit [23]        - Trap data or unified cache maintenance instructions that
                       operate to the Point of Coherency.
TSW, bit [22]        - Trap data or unified cache maintenance instructions that
                       operate by Set/Way.
TACR, bit [21]       - Trap Auxiliary Control Registers.
TIDCP, bit [20]      - Trap implementation defined functionality.
TSC, bit [19]        - Trap SMC instructions.
TID3, bit [18]       - Trap ID group 3.
TID2, bit [17]       - Trap ID group 2.
TID1, bit [16]       - Trap ID group 1.
TID0, bit [15]       - Trap ID group 0.
TWE, bit [14]        - Traps EL0 and EL1 execution of WFE instructions to EL2,
                       when EL2 is enabled in the current Security state, from
                       both Execution states, reported using EC syndrome value
                       0x01.
TWI, bit [13]        - Traps EL0 and EL1 execution of WFI instructions to EL2,
                       when EL2 is enabled in the current Security state, from
                       both Execution states, reported using EC syndrome value
                       0x01.
DC, bit [12]         - Default Cacheability.
BSU, bits [10:11]    - Barrier Shareability upgrade.
FB, bit [9]          - Force broadcast.
VSE, bit [8]         - Virtual SError interrupt.
VI, bit [7]          - Virtual IRQ Interrupt.
VF, bit [6]          - Virtual FIQ Interrupt.
AMO, bit [5]         - Physical SError interrupt routing.
IMO, bit [4]         - Physical IRQ Routing.
FMO, bit [3]         - Physical FIQ Routing.
PTW, bit [2]         - Protected Table Walk.
SWIO, bit [1]        - Set/Way Invalidation Override.
VM, bit [0]          - Virtualization enable.

HDFGRTR_EL2.long_name: Hypervisor Debug Fine-Grained Read Trap Register
HDFGRTR_EL2.purpose:
Provides controls for traps of MRS and MRC reads of debug, trace, PMU, and
Statistical Profiling System registers.

                             using AArch64 and MRC reads of PMUSERENR at EL0
                             using AArch32 when EL1 is using AArch64 to EL2.
TRCVICTLR, bit [48]        - Trap MRS reads of TRCVICTLR at EL1 using AArch64 to
                             EL2.
TRCSTATR, bit [47]         - Trap MRS reads of TRCSTATR at EL1 using AArch64 to
                             EL2.
TRCSSCSRn, bit [46]        - Trap MRS reads of TRCSSCSR<n> at EL1 using AArch64
                             to EL2.
TRCSEQSTR, bit [45]        - Trap MRS reads of TRCSEQSTR at EL1 using AArch64 to
                             EL2.
TRCPRGCTLR, bit [44]       - Trap MRS reads of TRCPRGCTLR at EL1 using AArch64
                             to EL2.
TRCOSLSR, bit [43]         - Trap MRS reads of TRCOSLSR at EL1 using AArch64 to
                             EL2.
TRCIMSPECn, bit [41]       - Trap MRS reads of TRCIMSPEC<n> at EL1 using AArch64
                             to EL2.
TRCID, bit [40]            - Trap MRS reads of multiple System registers.
TRCCNTVRn, bit [37]        - Trap MRS reads of TRCCNTVR<n> at EL1 using AArch64
                             to EL2.
TRCCLAIM, bit [36]         - Trap MRS reads of multiple System registers.
TRCAUXCTLR, bit [35]       - Trap MRS reads of TRCAUXCTLR at EL1 using AArch64
                             to EL2.
TRCAUTHSTATUS, bit [34]    - Trap MRS reads of TRCAUTHSTATUS at EL1 using

TRC, bit [33]              - Trap MRS reads of multiple System registers.
PMSLATFR_EL1, bit [32]     - Trap MRS reads of PMSLATFR_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64
                             to EL2.
PMSIRR_EL1, bit [31]       - Trap MRS reads of PMSIRR_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64
                             to EL2.
PMSIDR_EL1, bit [30]       - Trap MRS reads of PMSIDR_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64
                             to EL2.
PMSICR_EL1, bit [29]       - Trap MRS reads of PMSICR_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64
                             to EL2.
PMSFCR_EL1, bit [28]       - Trap MRS reads of PMSFCR_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64
                             to EL2.
PMSEVFR_EL1, bit [27]      - Trap MRS reads of PMSEVFR_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64
                             to EL2.
PMSCR_EL1, bit [26]        - Trap MRS reads of PMSCR_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64 to
                             EL2.
PMBSR_EL1, bit [25]        - Trap MRS reads of PMBSR_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64 to
                             EL2.
PMBPTR_EL1, bit [24]       - Trap MRS reads of PMBPTR_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64
                             to EL2.

FAR_EL1, bit [17]         - Trap MSR writes of FAR_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64 to
                            EL2.
ESR_EL1, bit [16]         - Trap MSR writes of ESR_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64 to
                            EL2.
CSSELR_EL1, bit [13]      - Trap MSR writes of CSSELR_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64
                            to EL2.
CPACR_EL1, bit [12]       - Trap MSR writes of CPACR_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64 to
                            EL2.
CONTEXTIDR_EL1, bit [11]  - Trap MSR writes of CONTEXTIDR_EL1 at EL1 using
                            AArch64 to EL2.
APIBKey, bit [8]          - Trap MSR writes of multiple System registers.
APIAKey, bit [7]          - Trap MSR writes of multiple System registers.
APGAKey, bit [6]          - Trap MSR writes of multiple System registers.
APDBKey, bit [5]          - Trap MSR writes of multiple System registers.
APDAKey, bit [4]          - Trap MSR writes of multiple System registers.
AMAIR_EL1, bit [3]        - Trap MSR writes of AMAIR_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64 to
                            EL2.
AFSR1_EL1, bit [1]        - Trap MSR writes of AFSR1_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64 to
                            EL2.
AFSR0_EL1, bit [0]        - Trap MSR writes of AFSR0_EL1 at EL1 using AArch64 to
                            EL2.

HPFAR_EL2.purpose:
Holds the faulting IPA for some aborts on a stage 2 translation taken to EL2.

NS, bit [63]              - Faulting IPA address space.
FIPA[51:48], bits [40:43] - Extension to FIPA[47:12].
FIPA[47:12], bits [4:39]  - Bits [47:12] of the faulting intermediate physical
                            address.

HSTR_EL2.purpose:
Controls trapping to EL2 of EL1 or lower AArch32 accesses to the System register
in the coproc == 0b1111 encoding space, by the CRn value used to access the
register using MCR or MRC instruction. When the register is accessible using an
MCRR or MRRC instruction, this is the CRm value used to access the register.

T<n>, bits [0:15] - Fields T14 and T4 are res0. The remaining fields control
                    whether EL0 and EL1 accesses, using MCR, MRC, MCRR, and MRRC
                    instructions, to the System registers in the coproc ==
                    0b1111 encoding space are trapped to EL2 as follows:
                      - MCR or MRC accesses to these registers that are trapped
                    to EL2 are reported using EC syndrome value 0x03, unless the
                    access is undefined.
                      - MCRR or MRRC accesses to these registers that are
                    trapped to EL2 are reported using EC syndrome value 0x04,
                    unless the access is undefined.

ICC_AP0R<n>_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Active Priorities Group 0 Registers
ICC_AP0R<n>_EL1.purpose: Provides information about Group 0 active priorities.

ICC_AP1R<n>_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Active Priorities Group 1 Registers
ICC_AP1R<n>_EL1.purpose: Provides information about Group 1 active priorities.

ICC_ASGI1R_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Alias Software Generated Interrupt Group 1 Register
ICC_ASGI1R_EL1.purpose:
Generates Group 1 SGIs for the Security state that is not the current Security
state.

Aff3, bits [48:55]      - The affinity 3 value of the affinity path of the
                          luster for which SGI interrupts will be generated.
RS, bits [44:47]        - RangeSelector Controls which group of 16 values is
                          represented by the TargetList field.
IRM, bit [40]           - Interrupt Routing Mode.
Aff2, bits [32:39]      - The affinity 2 value of the affinity path of the
                          cluster for which SGI interrupts will be generated.
INTID, bits [24:27]     - The INTID of the SGI.
Aff1, bits [16:23]      - The affinity 1 value of the affinity path of the
                          cluster for which SGI interrupts will be generated.
TargetList, bits [0:15] - Target List.

ICC_BPR0_EL1.purpose:
Defines the point at which the priority value fields split into two parts, the
group priority field and the subpriority field. The group priority field
determines Group 0 interrupt preemption.

BinaryPoint, bits [0:2] - The value of this field controls how the 8-bit
                          interrupt priority field is split into a group
                          priority field, that determines interrupt preemption,
                          and a subpriority field. This is done as follows:

ICC_BPR1_EL1.purpose:
Defines the point at which the priority value fields split into two parts, the
group priority field and the subpriority field. The group priority field
determines Group 1 interrupt preemption.

BinaryPoint, bits [0:2] - If the GIC is configured to use separate binary point
                          fields for Group 0 and Group 1 interrupts, the value
                          of this field controls how the 8-bit interrupt
                          priority field is split into a group priority field,
                          that determines interrupt preemption, and a
                          subpriority field. For more information about
                          priorities, see Priority grouping. The minimum value
                          of the Non-secure copy of this register is the minimum
                          value of ICC_BPR0_EL1 + 1. The minimum value of the
                          Secure copy of this register is the minimum value of
                          ICC_BPR0_EL1. If EL3 is implemented and
                          ICC_CTLR_EL3.CBPR_EL1S is 1:
                            -  When SCR_EL3.EEL2 is 1 and HCR_EL2.IMO is 1,
                          Secure accesses to this register at EL1 access the
                          state of ICV_BPR1_EL1.
                            -  Otherwise, Secure accesses to this register at
                          EL1 access the state of ICC_BPR0_EL1. If EL3 is
                          implemented and ICC_CTLR_EL3.CBPR_EL1NS is 1, Non-
                          secure accesses to this register at EL1 or EL2 behave
                          as follows, depending on the values of HCR_EL2.IMO and
                          SCR_EL3.IRQ: If EL3 is not implemented and
                          ICC_CTLR_EL1.CBPR is 1, Non-secure accesses to this
                          register at EL1 or EL2 behave as follows, depending on
                          the values of HCR_EL2.IMO:

ICC_CTLR_EL1.purpose:
Controls aspects of the behavior of the GIC CPU interface and provides
information about the features implemented.

ExtRange, bit [19]   - Extended INTID range (read-only).
RSS, bit [18]        - Range Selector Support.
A3V, bit [15]        - Affinity 3 Valid. Read-only and writes are ignored.
SEIS, bit [14]       - SEI Support. Read-only and writes are ignored.
IDbits, bits [11:13] - Identifier bits. Read-only and writes are ignored.
PRIbits, bits [8:10] - Priority bits. Read-only and writes are ignored. The
                       number of priority bits implemented, minus one. An
                       implementation that supports two Security states must
                       implement at least 32 levels of physical priority (5
                       priority bits). An implementation that supports only a
                       single Security state must implement at least 16 levels
                       of physical priority (4 priority bits). This field always
                       returns the number of priority bits implemented,
                       regardless of the Security state of the access or the
                       value of GICD_CTLR.DS. For physical accesses, this field
                       determines the minimum value of ICC_BPR0_EL1. If EL3 is
                       implemented, physical accesses return the value from
                       ICC_CTLR_EL3.PRIbits. If EL3 is not implemented, physical
                       accesses return the value from this field.
PMHE, bit [6]        - Priority Mask Hint Enable.
EOImode, bit [1]     - EOI mode for the current Security state.
CBPR, bit [0]        - Common Binary Point Register.

ICC_CTLR_EL3.purpose:
Controls aspects of the behavior of the GIC CPU interface and provides
information about the features implemented.

ExtRange, bit [19]     - Extended INTID range (read-only).
RSS, bit [18]          - Range Selector Support.
nDS, bit [17]          - Disable Security not supported.
A3V, bit [15]          - Affinity 3 Valid.
SEIS, bit [14]         - SEI Support.
IDbits, bits [11:13]   - Identifier bits.
PRIbits, bits [8:10]   - Priority bits.
PMHE, bit [6]          - Priority Mask Hint Enable.
RM, bit [5]            - Routing Modifier.
EOImode_EL1NS, bit [4] - EOI mode for interrupts handled at Non-secure EL1 and
                         EL2.
EOImode_EL1S, bit [3]  - EOI mode for interrupts handled at Secure EL1.
EOImode_EL3, bit [2]   - EOI mode for interrupts handled at EL3.
CBPR_EL1NS, bit [1]    - Common Binary Point Register, EL1 Non-secure.
CBPR_EL1S, bit [0]     - Common Binary Point Register, EL1 Secure.

ICC_DIR_EL1.purpose:
When interrupt priority drop is separated from interrupt deactivation, a write
to this register deactivates the specified interrupt.

INTID, bits [0:23] - The INTID of the interrupt to be deactivated. This field
                     has either 16 or 24 bits implemented. The number of
                     implemented bits can be found in ICC_CTLR_EL1.IDbits and
                     ICC_CTLR_EL3.IDbits. If only 16 bits are implemented, bits
                     [23:16] of this register are res0.

ICC_EOIR0_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller End Of Interrupt Register 0
ICC_EOIR0_EL1.purpose:
A PE writes to this register to inform the CPU interface that it has completed
the processing of the specified Group 0 interrupt.

INTID, bits [0:23] - The INTID from the corresponding ICC_IAR0_EL1 access. This
                     field has either 16 or 24 bits implemented. The number of
                     implemented bits can be found in ICC_CTLR_EL1.IDbits and
                     ICC_CTLR_EL3.IDbits. If only 16 bits are implemented, bits
                     [23:16] of this register are res0. If the EOImode bit for
                     the current Exception level and Security state is 0, a
                     write to this register drops the priority for the
                     interrupt, and also deactivates the interrupt. If the
                     EOImode bit for the current Exception level and Security
                     state is 1, a write to this register only drops the
                     priority for the interrupt. Software must write to
                     ICC_DIR_EL1 to deactivate the interrupt. The EOImode bit
                     for the current Exception level and Security state is
                     determined as follows:
                       - If EL3 is not implemented, the appropriate bit is
                     ICC_CTLR_EL1.EOImode.
                       - If EL3 is implemented and the software is executing at
                     EL3, the appropriate bit is ICC_CTLR_EL3.EOImode_EL3.
                       - If EL3 is implemented and the software is not executing
                     at EL3, the bit depends on the current Security state:
                         - If the software is executing in Secure state, the bit
                     is ICC_CTLR_EL3.EOImode_EL1S.
                         - If the software is executing in Non-secure state, the
                     bit is ICC_CTLR_EL3.EOImode_EL1NS.

ICC_EOIR1_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller End Of Interrupt Register 1
ICC_EOIR1_EL1.purpose:
A PE writes to this register to inform the CPU interface that it has completed
the processing of the specified Group 1 interrupt.

INTID, bits [0:23] - The INTID from the corresponding ICC_IAR1_EL1 access. This
                     field has either 16 or 24 bits implemented. The number of
                     implemented bits can be found in ICC_CTLR_EL1.IDbits and
                     ICC_CTLR_EL3.IDbits. If only 16 bits are implemented, bits
                     [23:16] of this register are res0. If the EOImode bit for
                     the current Exception level and Security state is 0, a
                     write to this register drops the priority for the
                     interrupt, and also deactivates the interrupt. If the
                     EOImode bit for the current Exception level and Security
                     state is 1, a write to this register only drops the
                     priority for the interrupt. Software must write to
                     ICC_DIR_EL1 to deactivate the interrupt. The EOImode bit
                     for the current Exception level and Security state is
                     determined as follows:
                       - If EL3 is not implemented, the appropriate bit is
                     ICC_CTLR_EL1.EOImode.
                       - If EL3 is implemented and the software is executing at
                     EL3, the appropriate bit is ICC_CTLR_EL3.EOImode_EL3.
                       - If EL3 is implemented and the software is not executing
                     at EL3, the bit depends on the current Security state:
                         - If the software is executing in Secure state, the bit
                     is ICC_CTLR_EL3.EOImode_EL1S.
                         - If the software is executing in Non-secure state, the
                     bit is ICC_CTLR_EL3.EOImode_EL1NS.

ICC_HPPIR0_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Highest Priority Pending Interrupt Register 0
ICC_HPPIR0_EL1.purpose:
Indicates the highest priority pending Group 0 interrupt on the CPU interface.

INTID, bits [0:23] - The INTID of the highest priority pending interrupt, if
                     that interrupt is observable at the current Security state
                     and Exception level. If the highest priority pending
                     interrupt is not observable, this field contains a special
                     INTID to indicate the reason. These special INTIDs can be
                     one of: 1020, 1021, or 1023. See Special INTIDs, for more
                     information. This field has either 16 or 24 bits
                     implemented. The number of implemented bits can be found in
                     ICC_CTLR_EL1.IDbits and ICC_CTLR_EL3.IDbits. If only 16
                     bits are implemented, bits [23:16] of this register are
                     res0.

ICC_HPPIR1_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Highest Priority Pending Interrupt Register 1
ICC_HPPIR1_EL1.purpose:
Indicates the highest priority pending Group 1 interrupt on the CPU interface.

INTID, bits [0:23] - The INTID of the highest priority pending interrupt, if
                     that interrupt is observable at the current Security state
                     and Exception level. If the highest priority pending
                     interrupt is not observable, this field contains a special
                     INTID to indicate the reason. These special INTIDs can be
                     one of: 1020, 1021, or 1023. See Special INTIDs, for more
                     information. This field has either 16 or 24 bits
                     implemented. The number of implemented bits can be found in
                     ICC_CTLR_EL1.IDbits and ICC_CTLR_EL3.IDbits. If only 16
                     bits are implemented, bits [23:16] of this register are
                     res0.

ICC_IAR0_EL1.purpose:
The PE reads this register to obtain the INTID of the signaled Group 0
interrupt. This read acts as an acknowledge for the interrupt.

INTID, bits [0:23] - The INTID of the signaled interrupt. This is the INTID of
                     the highest priority pending interrupt, if that interrupt
                     is of sufficient priority for it to be signaled to the PE,
                     and if it can be acknowledged at the current Security state
                     and Exception level. If the highest priority pending
                     interrupt is not observable, this field contains a special
                     INTID to indicate the reason. These special INTIDs can be
                     one of: 1020, 1021, or 1023. See Special INTIDs, for more
                     information. This field has either 16 or 24 bits
                     implemented. The number of implemented bits can be found in
                     ICC_CTLR_EL1.IDbits and ICC_CTLR_EL3.IDbits. If only 16
                     bits are implemented, bits [23:16] of this register are
                     res0.

ICC_IAR1_EL1.purpose:
The PE reads this register to obtain the INTID of the signaled Group 1
interrupt. This read acts as an acknowledge for the interrupt.

INTID, bits [0:23] - The INTID of the signaled interrupt. This is the INTID of
                     the highest priority pending interrupt, if that interrupt
                     is of sufficient priority for it to be signaled to the PE,
                     and if it can be acknowledged at the current Security state
                     and Exception level. If the highest priority pending
                     interrupt is not observable, this field contains a special
                     INTID to indicate the reason. These special INTIDs can be
                     one of: 1020, 1021, or 1023. See Special INTIDs, for more
                     information. This field has either 16 or 24 bits
                     implemented. The number of implemented bits can be found in
                     ICC_CTLR_EL1.IDbits and ICC_CTLR_EL3.IDbits. If only 16
                     bits are implemented, bits [23:16] of this register are
                     res0.

ICC_IGRPEN0_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Interrupt Group 0 Enable register
ICC_IGRPEN0_EL1.purpose:
Controls whether Group 0 interrupts are enabled or not.

Enable, bit [0] - Enables Group 0 interrupts.
                      0b0 Group 0 interrupts are disabled.
                      0b1 Group 0 interrupts are enabled.
                  Virtual accesses to this register update ICH_VMCR_EL2.VENG0.
                  If the highest priority pending interrupt for that PE is a
                  Group 0 interrupt using 1 of N model, then the interrupt will
                  be targeted to another PE as a result of the Enable bit
                  changing from 1 to 0.

ICC_IGRPEN1_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Interrupt Group 1 Enable register
ICC_IGRPEN1_EL1.purpose:
Controls whether Group 1 interrupts are enabled for the current Security state.

Enable, bit [0] - Enables Group 1 interrupts for the current Security state.
                      0b0 Group 1 interrupts are disabled for the current
                  Security state.
                      0b1 Group 1 interrupts are enabled for the current
                  Security state.
                  Virtual accesses to this register update ICH_VMCR_EL2.VENG1.
                  If EL3 is present:
                    - The Secure ICC_IGRPEN1_EL1.Enable bit is a read/write
                  alias of the ICC_IGRPEN1_EL3.EnableGrp1S bit.
                    - The Non-secure ICC_IGRPEN1_EL1.Enable bit is a read/write
                  alias of the ICC_IGRPEN1_EL3.EnableGrp1NS bit. If the highest
                  priority pending interrupt for that PE is a Group 1 interrupt
                  using 1 of N model, then the interrupt will target another PE
                  as a result of the Enable bit changing from 1 to 0.

ICC_IGRPEN1_EL3.long_name: Interrupt Controller Interrupt Group 1 Enable register (EL3)
ICC_IGRPEN1_EL3.purpose:
Controls whether Group 1 interrupts are enabled or not.

EnableGrp1S, bit [1]  - Enables Group 1 interrupts for the Secure state.
                            0b0 Secure Group 1 interrupts are disabled.
                            0b1 Secure Group 1 interrupts are enabled.
                        The Secure ICC_IGRPEN1_EL1.Enable bit is a read/write
                        alias of the ICC_IGRPEN1_EL3.EnableGrp1S bit. If the
                        highest priority pending interrupt for that PE is a
                        Group 1 interrupt using 1 of N model, then the interrupt
                        will target another PE as a result of the Enable bit
                        changing from 1 to 0.
EnableGrp1NS, bit [0] - Enables Group 1 interrupts for the Non-secure state.
                            0b0 Non-secure Group 1 interrupts are disabled.
                            0b1 Non-secure Group 1 interrupts are enabled.
                        The Non-secure ICC_IGRPEN1_EL1.Enable bit is a
                        read/write alias of the ICC_IGRPEN1_EL3.EnableGrp1NS
                        bit. If the highest priority pending interrupt for that
                        PE is a Group 1 interrupt using 1 of N model, then the
                        interrupt will target another PE as a result of the
                        Enable bit changing from 1 to 0.

ICC_PMR_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Interrupt Priority Mask Register
ICC_PMR_EL1.purpose:
Provides an interrupt priority filter. Only interrupts with a higher priority
than the value in this register are signaled to the PE.

Writes to this register must be high performance and must ensure that no
interrupt of lower priority than the written value occurs after the write,
without requiring an ISB or an exception boundary.

Priority, bits [0:7] - The priority mask level for the CPU interface. If the
                       priority of an interrupt is higher than the value
                       indicated by this field, the interface signals the
                       interrupt to the PE. The possible priority field values
                       are as follows: Unimplemented priority bits are RAZ/WI.

ICC_RPR_EL1.purpose:
Indicates the Running priority of the CPU interface.

Priority, bits [0:7] - The current running priority on the CPU interface. This
                       is the group priority of the current active interrupt. If
                       there are no active interrupts on the CPU interface, or
                       all active interrupts have undergone a priority drop, the
                       value returned is the Idle priority. The priority
                       returned is the group priority as if the BPR for the
                       current Exception level and Security state was set to the
                       minimum value of BPR for the number of implemented
                       priority bits. If 8 bits of priority are implemented the
                       group priority is bits[7:1] of the priority.

ICC_SGI0R_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Software Generated Interrupt Group 0 Register
ICC_SGI0R_EL1.purpose:
Generates Secure Group 0 SGIs.

Aff3, bits [48:55]      - The affinity 3 value of the affinity path of the
                          cluster for which SGI interrupts will be generated.
RS, bits [44:47]        - RangeSelector Controls which group of 16 values is
                          represented by the TargetList field.
IRM, bit [40]           - Interrupt Routing Mode.
Aff2, bits [32:39]      - The affinity 2 value of the affinity path of the
                          cluster for which SGI interrupts will be generated.
INTID, bits [24:27]     - The INTID of the SGI.
Aff1, bits [16:23]      - The affinity 1 value of the affinity path of the
                          cluster for which SGI interrupts will be generated.
TargetList, bits [0:15] - Target List.

ICC_SGI1R_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Software Generated Interrupt Group 1 Register
ICC_SGI1R_EL1.purpose:
Generates Group 1 SGIs for the current Security state.

Aff3, bits [48:55]      - The affinity 3 value of the affinity path of the
                          cluster for which SGI interrupts will be generated.
RS, bits [44:47]        - RangeSelector Controls which group of 16 values is
                          represented by the TargetList field.
IRM, bit [40]           - Interrupt Routing Mode.
Aff2, bits [32:39]      - The affinity 2 value of the affinity path of the
                          cluster for which SGI interrupts will be generated.
INTID, bits [24:27]     - The INTID of the SGI.
Aff1, bits [16:23]      - The affinity 1 value of the affinity path of the
                          cluster for which SGI interrupts will be generated.
TargetList, bits [0:15] - Target List.

ICC_SRE_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller System Register Enable register (EL1)
ICC_SRE_EL1.purpose:
Controls whether the System register interface or the memory-mapped interface to
the GIC CPU interface is used for EL1.

DIB, bit [2] - Disable IRQ bypass.
                   0b0 IRQ bypass enabled.
                   0b1 IRQ bypass disabled.
DFB, bit [1] - Disable FIQ bypass.
                   0b0 FIQ bypass enabled.
                   0b1 FIQ bypass disabled.
SRE, bit [0] - System Register Enable.
                   0b0 The memory-mapped interface must be used. Access at EL1
               to any ICC_* System register other than ICC_SRE_EL1 is trapped to
               EL1.
                   0b1 The System register interface for the current Security
               state is enabled.

ICC_SRE_EL2.long_name: Interrupt Controller System Register Enable register (EL2)
ICC_SRE_EL2.purpose:
Controls whether the System register interface or the memory-mapped interface to
the GIC CPU interface is used for EL2.

Enable, bit [3] - Enable. Enables lower Exception level access to ICC_SRE_EL1.
                      0b0 When EL2 is implemented and enabled in the current
                  Security state, EL1 accesses to ICC_SRE_EL1 trap to EL2.
                      0b1 EL1 accesses to ICC_SRE_EL1 do not trap to EL2.
DIB, bit [2]    - Disable IRQ bypass.
                      0b0 IRQ bypass enabled.
                      0b1 IRQ bypass disabled.
DFB, bit [1]    - Disable FIQ bypass.
                      0b0 FIQ bypass enabled.
                      0b1 FIQ bypass disabled.
SRE, bit [0]    - System Register Enable.
                      0b0 The memory-mapped interface must be used. Access at
                  EL2 to any ICH_* or ICC_* register other than ICC_SRE_EL1 or
                  ICC_SRE_EL2, is trapped to EL2.
                      0b1 The System register interface to the ICH_* registers
                  and the EL1 and EL2 ICC_* registers is enabled for EL2.

ICC_SRE_EL3.long_name: Interrupt Controller System Register Enable register (EL3)
ICC_SRE_EL3.purpose:
Controls whether the System register interface or the memory-mapped interface to
the GIC CPU interface is used for EL3.

Enable, bit [3] - Enable. Enables lower Exception level access to ICC_SRE_EL1
                  and ICC_SRE_EL2.
                      0b0 EL1 accesses to ICC_SRE_EL1 trap to EL3, unless these
                  accesses are trapped to EL2 as a result of ICC_SRE_EL2.Enable
                  == 0. EL2 accesses to ICC_SRE_EL1 and ICC_SRE_EL2 trap to EL3.
                      0b1 EL1 accesses to ICC_SRE_EL1 do not trap to EL3. EL2
                  accesses to ICC_SRE_EL1 and ICC_SRE_EL2 do not trap to EL3.
DIB, bit [2]    - Disable IRQ bypass.
                      0b0 IRQ bypass enabled.
                      0b1 IRQ bypass disabled.
DFB, bit [1]    - Disable FIQ bypass.
                      0b0 FIQ bypass enabled.
                      0b1 FIQ bypass disabled.
SRE, bit [0]    - System Register Enable.
                      0b0 The memory-mapped interface must be used. Access at
                  EL3 to any ICH_* or ICC_* register other than ICC_SRE_EL1,
                  ICC_SRE_EL2, or ICC_SRE_EL3 is trapped to EL3
                      0b1 The System register interface to the ICH_* registers
                  and the EL1, EL2, and EL3 ICC_* registers is enabled for EL3.

ICH_AP0R<n>_EL2.long_name: Interrupt Controller Hyp Active Priorities Group 0 Registers
ICH_AP0R<n>_EL2.purpose:
Provides information about Group 0 virtual active priorities for EL2.

P<x>, bits [0:31] - Provides the access to the virtual active priorities for
                    Group 0 interrupts. Possible values of each bit are:
                        0b0 There is no Group 0 interrupt active with this
                    priority level, or all active Group 0 interrupts with this
                    priority level have undergone priority-drop.
                        0b1 There is a Group 0 interrupt active with this
                    priority level which has not undergone priority drop.

ICH_AP1R<n>_EL2.long_name: Interrupt Controller Hyp Active Priorities Group 1 Registers
ICH_AP1R<n>_EL2.purpose:
Provides information about Group 1 virtual active priorities for EL2.

P<x>, bits [0:31] - Group 1 interrupt active priorities. Possible values of each
