                    bit are:
                        0b0 There is no Group 1 interrupt active with this
                    priority level, or all active Group 1 interrupts with this
                    priority level have undergone priority-drop.
                        0b1 There is a Group 1 interrupt active with this
                    priority level which has not undergone priority drop.

ICH_EISR_EL2.long_name: Interrupt Controller End of Interrupt Status Register
ICH_EISR_EL2.purpose:
Indicates which List registers have outstanding EOI maintenance interrupts.

Status<n>, bits [0:15] - EOI maintenance interrupt status bit for List register
                         <n>:
                             0b0 List register <n>, ICH_LR<n>_EL2, does not have
                         an EOI maintenance interrupt.
                             0b1 List register <n>, ICH_LR<n>_EL2, has an EOI
                         maintenance interrupt that has not been handled.
                         For any ICH_LR<n>_EL2, the corresponding status bit is
                         set to 1 if all of the following are true:
                           - ICH_LR<n>_EL2.State is 0b00.
                           - ICH_LR<n>_EL2.HW is 0.
                           - ICH_LR<n>_EL2.EOI (bit [41]) is 1, indicating that
                         when the interrupt corresponding to that List register
                         is deactivated, a maintenance interrupt is asserted.
                         Otherwise the status bit takes the value 0.

ICH_ELRSR_EL2.long_name: Interrupt Controller Empty List Register Status Register
ICH_ELRSR_EL2.purpose:
These registers can be used to locate a usable List register when the hypervisor
is delivering an interrupt to a VM.

Status<n>, bits [0:15] - Status bit for List register <n>, ICH_LR<n>_EL2:
                             0b0 List register ICH_LR<n>_EL2, if implemented,
                         contains a valid interrupt. Using this List register
                         can result in overwriting a valid interrupt.
                             0b1 List register ICH_LR<n>_EL2 does not contain a
                         valid interrupt. The List register is empty and can be
                         used without overwriting a valid interrupt or losing an
                         EOI maintenance interrupt.
                         For any List register <n>, the corresponding status bit
                         is set to 1 if ICH_LR<n>_EL2.State is 0b00 and either
                         ICH_LR<n>_EL2.HW is 1 or ICH_LR<n>_EL2.EOI (bit [41])
                         is 0. Otherwise the status bit takes the value 0.

ICH_HCR_EL2.purpose:
Controls the environment for VMs.

EOIcount, bits [27:31] - This field is incremented whenever a successful write
                         to a virtual EOIR or DIR register would have resulted
                         in a virtual interrupt deactivation.
TDIR, bit [14]         - Trap EL1 writes to ICC_DIR_EL1 and ICV_DIR_EL1.
TSEI, bit [13]         - Trap all locally generated SEIs.
TALL1, bit [12]        - Trap all EL1 accesses to ICC_* and ICV_* System
                         registers for Group 1 interrupts to EL2.
TALL0, bit [11]        - Trap all EL1 accesses to ICC_* and ICV_* System
                         registers for Group 0 interrupts to EL2.
TC, bit [10]           - Trap all EL1 accesses to System registers that are
                         common to Group 0 and Group 1 to EL2.
VGrp1DIE, bit [7]      - VM Group 1 Disabled Interrupt Enable.
VGrp1EIE, bit [6]      - VM Group 1 Enabled Interrupt Enable.
VGrp0DIE, bit [5]      - VM Group 0 Disabled Interrupt Enable.
VGrp0EIE, bit [4]      - VM Group 0 Enabled Interrupt Enable.
NPIE, bit [3]          - No Pending Interrupt Enable.
LRENPIE, bit [2]       - List Register Entry Not Present Interrupt Enable.
UIE, bit [1]           - Underflow Interrupt Enable.
En, bit [0]            - Enable.

ICH_LR<n>_EL2.purpose:
Provides interrupt context information for the virtual CPU interface.

State, bits [62:63]    - The state of the interrupt:
HW, bit [61]           - Indicates whether this virtual interrupt maps directly
                         to a hardware interrupt, meaning that it corresponds to
                         a physical interrupt.
Group, bit [60]        - Indicates the group for this virtual interrupt.
Priority, bits [48:55] - The priority of this interrupt.
pINTID, bits [32:44]   - Physical INTID, for hardware interrupts.
vINTID, bits [0:31]    - Virtual INTID of the interrupt.

ICH_MISR_EL2.long_name: Interrupt Controller Maintenance Interrupt State Register
ICH_MISR_EL2.purpose:
Indicates which maintenance interrupts are asserted.

VGrp1D, bit [7] - vPE Group 1 Disabled.
VGrp1E, bit [6] - vPE Group 1 Enabled.
VGrp0D, bit [5] - vPE Group 0 Disabled.
VGrp0E, bit [4] - vPE Group 0 Enabled.
NP, bit [3]     - No Pending.
LRENP, bit [2]  - List Register Entry Not Present.
U, bit [1]      - Underflow.
EOI, bit [0]    - End Of Interrupt.

ICH_VMCR_EL2.long_name: Interrupt Controller Virtual Machine Control Register
ICH_VMCR_EL2.purpose:
Enables the hypervisor to save and restore the virtual machine view of the GIC
state.

VPMR, bits [24:31]  - Virtual Priority Mask.
VBPR0, bits [21:23] - Virtual Binary Point Register, Group 0.
VBPR1, bits [18:20] - Virtual Binary Point Register, Group 1.
VEOIM, bit [9]      - Virtual EOI mode.
VCBPR, bit [4]      - Virtual Common Binary Point Register.
VFIQEn, bit [3]     - Virtual FIQ enable.
VAckCtl, bit [2]    - Virtual AckCtl.
VENG1, bit [1]      - Virtual Group 1 interrupt enable.
VENG0, bit [0]      - Virtual Group 0 interrupt enable.

ICH_VTR_EL2.purpose:
Reports supported GIC virtualisartion features.

PRIbits, bits [29:31] - Priority bits. The number of virtual priority bits
                        implemented, minus one. An implementation must implement
                        at least 32 levels of virtual priority (5 priority
                        bits). This field is an alias of ICV_CTLR_EL1.PRIbits.
PREbits, bits [26:28] - The number of virtual preemption bits implemented, minus
                        one. An implementation must implement at least 32 levels
                        of virtual preemption priority (5 preemption bits). The
                        value of this field must be less than or equal to the
                        value of ICH_VTR_EL2.PRIbits. The maximum value of this
                        field is 6, indicating 7 bits of preemption. This field
                        determines the minimum value of ICH_VMCR_EL2.VBPR0.
IDbits, bits [23:25]  - The number of virtual interrupt identifier bits
                        supported:
SEIS, bit [22]        - SEI Support.
A3V, bit [21]         - Affinity 3 Valid.
nV4, bit [20]         - Direct injection of virtual interrupts not supported.
TDS, bit [19]         - Separate trapping of EL1 writes to ICV_DIR_EL1
                        supported.
ListRegs, bits [0:4]  - The number of implemented List registers, minus one. For
                        example, a value of 0b01111 indicates that the maximum
                        of 16 List registers are implemented.

ICV_AP0R<n>_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Virtual Active Priorities Group 0 Registers
ICV_AP0R<n>_EL1.purpose: Provides information about virtual Group 0 active priorities.

ICV_AP1R<n>_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Virtual Active Priorities Group 1 Registers
ICV_AP1R<n>_EL1.purpose: Provides information about virtual Group 1 active priorities.

ICV_BPR0_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Virtual Binary Point Register 0
ICV_BPR0_EL1.purpose:
Defines the point at which the priority value fields split into two parts, the
group priority field and the subpriority field. The group priority field
determines virtual Group 0 interrupt preemption.

BinaryPoint, bits [0:2] - The value of this field controls how the 8-bit
                          interrupt priority field is split into a group
                          priority field, that determines interrupt preemption,
                          and a subpriority field. This is done as follows:

ICV_BPR1_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Virtual Binary Point Register 1
ICV_BPR1_EL1.purpose:
Defines the point at which the priority value fields split into two parts, the
group priority field and the subpriority field. The group priority field
determines virtual Group 1 interrupt preemption.

BinaryPoint, bits [0:2] - If the GIC is configured to use separate binary point
                          fields for virtual Group 0 and virtual Group 1
                          interrupts, the value of this field controls how the
                          8-bit interrupt priority field is split into a group
                          priority field, that determines interrupt preemption,
                          and a subpriority field. This is done as follows:
                          Writing 0 to this field will set this field to its
                          reset value. If ICV_CTLR_EL1.CBPR is set to 1, Non-
                          secure EL1 reads return ICV_BPR0_EL1 + 1 saturated to
                          0b111. Non-secure EL1 writes are ignored. If
                          ICV_CTLR_EL1.CBPR is set to 1, Secure EL1 reads return
                          ICV_BPR0_EL1. Secure EL1 writes modify ICV_BPR0_EL1.

ICV_CTLR_EL1.purpose:
Controls aspects of the behavior of the GIC virtual CPU interface and provides
information about the features implemented.

ExtRange, bit [19]   - Extended INTID range (read-only).
RSS, bit [18]        - Range Selector Support.
A3V, bit [15]        - Affinity 3 Valid. Read-only and writes are ignored.
SEIS, bit [14]       - SEI Support. Read-only and writes are ignored.
IDbits, bits [11:13] - Identifier bits. Read-only and writes are ignored.
PRIbits, bits [8:10] - Priority bits. Read-only and writes are ignored. The
                       number of priority bits implemented, minus one. An
                       implementation must implement at least 32 levels of
                       physical priority (5 priority bits). This field always
                       returns the number of priority bits implemented. The
                       division between group priority and subpriority is
                       defined in the binary point registers ICV_BPR0_EL1 and
                       ICV_BPR1_EL1.
EOImode, bit [1]     - Virtual EOI mode.
CBPR, bit [0]        - Common Binary Point Register.

ICV_DIR_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Deactivate Virtual Interrupt Register
ICV_DIR_EL1.purpose:
When interrupt priority drop is separated from interrupt deactivation, a write
to this register deactivates the specified virtual interrupt.

INTID, bits [0:23] - The INTID of the virtual interrupt to be deactivated. This
                     field has either 16 or 24 bits implemented. The number of
                     implemented bits can be found in ICV_CTLR_EL1.IDbits. If
                     only 16 bits are implemented, bits [23:16] of this register
                     are res0.

ICV_EOIR0_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Virtual End Of Interrupt Register 0
ICV_EOIR0_EL1.purpose:
A PE writes to this register to inform the CPU interface that it has completed
the processing of the specified virtual Group 0 interrupt.

INTID, bits [0:23] - The INTID from the corresponding ICV_IAR0_EL1 access. This
                     field has either 16 or 24 bits implemented. The number of
                     implemented bits can be found in ICV_CTLR_EL1.IDbits. If
                     only 16 bits are implemented, bits [23:16] of this register
                     are res0. If the ICV_CTLR.EOImode bit is 0, a write to this
                     register drops the priority for the virtual interrupt, and
                     also deactivates the virtual interrupt. If the
                     ICV_CTLR.EOImode bit is 1, a write to this register only
                     drops the priority for the virtual interrupt. Software must
                     write to ICV_DIR_EL1 to deactivate the virtual interrupt.

ICV_EOIR1_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Virtual End Of Interrupt Register 1
ICV_EOIR1_EL1.purpose:
A PE writes to this register to inform the CPU interface that it has completed
the processing of the specified virtual Group 1 interrupt.

INTID, bits [0:23] - The INTID from the corresponding ICV_IAR1_EL1 access. This
                     field has either 16 or 24 bits implemented. The number of
                     implemented bits can be found in ICV_CTLR_EL1.IDbits. If
                     only 16 bits are implemented, bits [23:16] of this register
                     are res0. If the ICV_CTLR.EOImode bit is 0, a write to this
                     register drops the priority for the virtual interrupt, and
                     also deactivates the virtual interrupt. If the
                     ICV_CTLR.EOImode bit is 1, a write to this register only
                     drops the priority for the virtual interrupt. Software must
                     write to ICV_DIR_EL1 to deactivate the virtual interrupt.

ICV_HPPIR0_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Virtual Highest Priority Pending Interrupt Register 0
ICV_HPPIR0_EL1.purpose:
Indicates the highest priority pending virtual Group 0 interrupt on the virtual
CPU interface.

INTID, bits [0:23] - The INTID of the highest priority pending virtual
                     interrupt. If the highest priority pending interrupt is not
                     observable, this field contains a special INTID to indicate
                     the reason. This special INTID can take the value 1023
                     only. See Special INTIDs, for more information. This field
                     has either 16 or 24 bits implemented. The number of
                     implemented bits can be found in ICV_CTLR_EL1.IDbits. If
                     only 16 bits are implemented, bits [23:16] of this register
                     are res0.

ICV_HPPIR1_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Virtual Highest Priority Pending Interrupt Register 1
ICV_HPPIR1_EL1.purpose:
Indicates the highest priority pending virtual Group 1 interrupt on the virtual
CPU interface.

INTID, bits [0:23] - The INTID of the highest priority pending virtual
                     interrupt. If the highest priority pending interrupt is not
                     observable, this field contains a special INTID to indicate
                     the reason. This special INTID can take the value 1023
                     only. See Special INTIDs, for more information. This field
                     has either 16 or 24 bits implemented. The number of
                     implemented bits can be found in ICV_CTLR_EL1.IDbits. If
                     only 16 bits are implemented, bits [23:16] of this register
                     are res0.

ICV_IAR0_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Virtual Interrupt Acknowledge Register 0
ICV_IAR0_EL1.purpose:
The PE reads this register to obtain the INTID of the signaled virtual Group 0
interrupt. This read acts as an acknowledge for the interrupt.

INTID, bits [0:23] - The INTID of the signaled virtual interrupt. This is the
                     INTID of the highest priority pending virtual interrupt, if
                     that interrupt is of sufficient priority for it to be
                     signaled to the PE, and if it can be acknowledged. If the
                     highest priority pending interrupt is not observable, this
                     field contains a special INTID to indicate the reason. This
                     special INTID can take the value 1023 only. See Special
                     INTIDs, for more information. This field has either 16 or
                     24 bits implemented. The number of implemented bits can be
                     found in ICV_CTLR_EL1.IDbits. If only 16 bits are
                     implemented, bits [23:16] of this register are res0.

ICV_IAR1_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Virtual Interrupt Acknowledge Register 1
ICV_IAR1_EL1.purpose:
The PE reads this register to obtain the INTID of the signaled virtual Group 1
interrupt. This read acts as an acknowledge for the interrupt.

INTID, bits [0:23] - The INTID of the signaled virtual interrupt. This is the
                     INTID of the highest priority pending virtual interrupt, if
                     that interrupt is of sufficient priority for it to be
                     signaled to the PE, and if it can be acknowledged. If the
                     highest priority pending interrupt is not observable, this
                     field contains a special INTID to indicate the reason. This
                     special INTID can take the value 1023 only. See Special
                     INTIDs, for more information. This field has either 16 or
                     24 bits implemented. The number of implemented bits can be
                     found in ICV_CTLR_EL1.IDbits. If only 16 bits are
                     implemented, bits [23:16] of this register are res0.

ICV_IGRPEN0_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Virtual Interrupt Group 0 Enable register
ICV_IGRPEN0_EL1.purpose:
Controls whether virtual Group 0 interrupts are enabled or not.

Enable, bit [0] - Enables virtual Group 0 interrupts.
                      0b0 Virtual Group 0 interrupts are disabled.
                      0b1 Virtual Group 0 interrupts are enabled.

ICV_IGRPEN1_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Virtual Interrupt Group 1 Enable register
ICV_IGRPEN1_EL1.purpose:
Controls whether virtual Group 1 interrupts are enabled for the current Security
state.

Enable, bit [0] - Enables virtual Group 1 interrupts.
                      0b0 Virtual Group 1 interrupts are disabled.
                      0b1 Virtual Group 1 interrupts are enabled.

ICV_PMR_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Virtual Interrupt Priority Mask Register
ICV_PMR_EL1.purpose:
Provides a virtual interrupt priority filter. Only virtual interrupts with a
higher priority than the value in this register are signaled to the PE.

Priority, bits [0:7] - The priority mask level for the virtual CPU interface. If
                       the priority of a virtual interrupt is higher than the
                       value indicated by this field, the interface signals the
                       virtual interrupt to the PE. The possible priority field
                       values are as follows: Unimplemented priority bits are
                       RAZ/WI.

ICV_RPR_EL1.long_name: Interrupt Controller Virtual Running Priority Register
ICV_RPR_EL1.purpose:
Indicates the Running priority of the virtual CPU interface.

Priority, bits [0:7] - The current running priority on the virtual CPU
                       interface. This is the group priority of the current
                       active virtual interrupt. If there are no active
                       interrupts on the virtual CPU interface, or all active
                       interrupts have undergone a priority drop, the value
                       returned is the Idle priority. The priority returned is
                       the group priority as if the BPR for the current
                       Exception level and Security state was set to the minimum
                       value of BPR for the number of implemented priority bits.
                       If 8 bits of priority are implemented the group priority
                       is bits[7:1] of the priority.

ID_AA64AFR0_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the implementation defined features of the PE in
AArch64 state.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

ID_AA64AFR1_EL1.purpose:
Reserved for future expansion of information about the implementation defined
features of the PE in AArch64 state.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

ID_AA64DFR0_EL1.purpose:
Provides top level information about the debug system in AArch64 state.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

MTPMU, bits [48:51]      - Multi-threaded PMU extension.
TraceFilt, bits [40:43]  - Armv8.4 Self-hosted Trace Extension version.
DoubleLock, bits [36:39] - OS Double Lock implemented.
PMSVer, bits [32:35]     - Statistical Profiling Extension version.
CTX_CMPs, bits [28:31]   - Number of breakpoints that are context-aware, minus
                           1. These are the highest numbered breakpoints.
WRPs, bits [20:23]       - Number of watchpoints, minus 1. The value of 0b0000
                           is reserved.
BRPs, bits [12:15]       - Number of breakpoints, minus 1. The value of 0b0000
                           is reserved.
PMUVer, bits [8:11]      - Performance Monitors Extension version. This field
                           does not follow the standard ID scheme, but uses the
                           Alternative ID scheme described in 'Alternative ID
                           scheme used for the Performance Monitors Extension
                           version' in the Arm® Architecture Reference Manual,
                           Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile.
TraceVer, bits [4:7]     - Trace support. Indicates whether System register
                           interface to a PE trace unit is implemented.
DebugVer, bits [0:3]     - Debug architecture version. Indicates presence of
                           Armv8 debug architecture.

ID_AA64DFR1_EL1.purpose:
Reserved for future expansion of top level information about the debug system in
AArch64 state.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

ID_AA64ISAR0_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the instructions implemented in AArch64 state.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

RNDR, bits [60:63]   - Indicates support for Random Number instructions in
                       AArch64 state.
TLB, bits [56:59]    - Indicates support for Outer shareable and TLB range
                       maintenance instructions.
TS, bits [52:55]     - Indicates support for flag manipulation instructions.
FHM, bits [48:51]    - Indicates whether FMLAL and FMLSL instructions are
                       implemented.
DP, bits [44:47]     - Dot Product instructions implemented in AArch64 state.
SM4, bits [40:43]    - SM4 instructions implemented in AArch64 state.
SM3, bits [36:39]    - SM3 instructions implemented in AArch64 state.
SHA3, bits [32:35]   - SHA3 instructions implemented in AArch64 state.
RDM, bits [28:31]    - SQRDMLAH and SQRDMLSH instructions implemented in AArch64
                       state.
Atomic, bits [20:23] - Atomic instructions implemented in AArch64 state.
CRC32, bits [16:19]  - CRC32 instructions implemented in AArch64 state.
SHA2, bits [12:15]   - SHA2 instructions implemented in AArch64 state.
SHA1, bits [8:11]    - SHA1 instructions implemented in AArch64 state.
AES, bits [4:7]      - AES instructions implemented in AArch64 state.

ID_AA64ISAR1_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the features and instructions implemented in AArch64
state.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

I8MM, bits [52:55]    - Indicates support for Advanced SIMD and floating-point
                        Int8 matrix multiplication instructions in AArch64
                        state.
DGH, bits [48:51]     - Indicates presence of the Data Gathering Hint
                        instruction.
BF16, bits [44:47]    - Indicates support for Advanced SIMD and floating-point
                        BFloat16 instructions in AArch64 state.
SPECRES, bits [40:43] - Speculation invalidation instruction support in AArch64
                        state.
SB, bits [36:39]      - SB instruction support in AArch64 state.
FRINTTS, bits [32:35] - Indicates whether FRINT32Z, FRINT32X, FRINT64Z, and
                        FRINT64X instructions are implemented.
GPI, bits [28:31]     - Indicates whether an implementation defined algorithm is
                        implemented in the PE for generic code authentication,
                        in AArch64 state.
GPA, bits [24:27]     - Indicates whether QARMA or Architected algorithm is
                        implemented in the PE for generic code authentication,
                        in AArch64 state.
LRCPC, bits [20:23]   - Indicates support for weaker release consistency, RCpc
                        based model.
LRCPC, bits [20:23]   - Indicates support for weaker release consistency, RCpc
                        based model.
FCMA, bits [16:19]    - Indicates support for complex number addition and
                        multiplication, where numbers are stored in vectors.
JSCVT, bits [12:15]   - Indicates support for javascript conversion from double
                        precision floating point values to integers in AArch64
                        state.
API, bits [8:11]      - Indicates whether an implementation defined algorithm is
                        implemented in the PE for address authentication, in
                        AArch64 state.
APA, bits [4:7]       - Indicates whether QARMA or Architected algorithm is
                        implemented in the PE for address authentication, in
                        AArch64 state.
DPB, bits [0:3]       - Data Persistence writeback.

ID_AA64MMFR0_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the implemented memory model and memory management
support in AArch64 state.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

ECV, bits [60:63]       - Presence of Enhanced Counter Virtualization.
FGT, bits [56:59]       - Presence of the Fine-Grained Trap controls:
                            - HAFGRTR_EL2, HDFGRTR_EL2, HDFGWTR_EL2, HFGRTR_EL2,
                          HFGITR_EL2 and HFGWTR_EL2 registers, and their
                          associated traps.
                            - MDCR_EL2.TDCC and MDCR_EL3.TDCC.
                            - SCR_EL3.FGTEn.
ExS, bits [44:47]       - Support for disabling context synchronizing exception
                          entry and exit.
TGran4_2, bits [40:43]  - Support for 4KB memory granule size for stage 2.
TGran64_2, bits [36:39] - Support for 64KB memory granule size for stage 2.
TGran16_2, bits [32:35] - Support for 16KB memory granule size for stage 2.
TGran4, bits [28:31]    - Support for 4KB memory translation granule size.
TGran64, bits [24:27]   - Support for 64KB memory translation granule size.
TGran16, bits [20:23]   - Support for 16KB memory translation granule size.
BigEndEL0, bits [16:19] - Mixed-endian support at EL0 only.
SNSMem, bits [12:15]    - Secure versus Non-secure Memory distinction.
BigEnd, bits [8:11]     - Mixed-endian configuration support.
ASIDBits, bits [4:7]    - Number of ASID bits.
PARange, bits [0:3]     - Physical Address range supported.

ID_AA64MMFR1_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the implemented memory model and memory management
support in AArch64 state.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

ETS, bits [36:39]     - Support for Enhanced Translation Synchronization.
TWED, bits [32:35]    - Support for the configurable delayed trapping of WFE.
XNX, bits [28:31]     - Support for execute-never control distinction by
                        Exception level at stage 2.
SpecSEI, bits [24:27] - Describes whether the PE can generate SError interrupt
                        exceptions from speculative reads of memory, including
                        speculative instruction fetches.
PAN, bits [20:23]     - Privileged Access Never. Indicates support for the PAN
                        bit in PSTATE, SPSR_EL1, SPSR_EL2, SPSR_EL3, and
                        DSPSR_EL0.
LO, bits [16:19]      - LORegions. Indicates support for LORegions.
HPDS, bits [12:15]    - Hierarchical permission disables bits in translation
                        tables.
VH, bits [8:11]       - Virtualization Host Extensions.
VMIDBits, bits [4:7]  - Number of VMID bits.
HAFDBS, bits [0:3]    - Hardware updates to Access flag and Dirty state in
                        translation tables.

ID_AA64MMFR2_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the implemented memory model and memory management
support in AArch64 state.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers.

E0PD, bits [60:63]    - Indicates support for the E0PD mechanism.
EVT, bits [56:59]     - Enhanced Virtualization Traps.
BBM, bits [52:55]     - Allows identification of the requirements of the
                        hardware to have break-before-make sequences when
                        changing block size for a translation.
TTL, bits [48:51]     - Indicates support for TTL field in address operations.
FWB, bits [40:43]     - Indicates support for HCR_EL2.FWB
IDS, bits [36:39]     - Indicates the value of ESR_ELx.EC that reports an
                        exception generated by a read access to the feature ID
                        space.
AT, bits [32:35]      - Identifies support for unaligned single-copy atomicity
                        and atomic functions.
ST, bits [28:31]      - Identifies support for small translation tables.
NV, bits [24:27]      - Nested Virtualization.
CCIDX, bits [20:23]   - Support for the use of revised CCSIDR_EL1 register
                        format.
VARange, bits [16:19] - Indicates support for a larger virtual address.
IESB, bits [12:15]    - Indicates support for the IESB bit in the SCTLR_ELx
                        registers.
LSM, bits [8:11]      - Indicates support for LSMAOE and nTLSMD bits in
                        SCTLR_EL1 and SCTLR_EL2.
UAO, bits [4:7]       - User Access Override.
CnP, bits [0:3]       - Common not Private translations.

ID_AA64PFR0_EL1.purpose:
Provides additional information about implemented PE features in AArch64 state.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

CSV3, bits [60:63]    - Speculative use of faulting data.
CSV2, bits [56:59]    - Speculative use of out of context branch targets.
DIT, bits [48:51]     - Data Independent Timing.
AMU, bits [44:47]     - Activity Monitors Extension.
MPAM, bits [40:43]    - MPAM Extension.
SEL2, bits [36:39]    - Secure EL2.
SVE, bits [32:35]     - Scalable Vector Extension.
RAS, bits [28:31]     - RAS Extension version.
GIC, bits [24:27]     - System register GIC interface support.
AdvSIMD, bits [20:23] - Advanced SIMD.
FP, bits [16:19]      - Floating-point.
EL3, bits [12:15]     - EL3 Exception level handling.
EL2, bits [8:11]      - EL2 Exception level handling.
EL1, bits [4:7]       - EL1 Exception level handling.
EL0, bits [0:3]       - EL0 Exception level handling.

ID_AA64PFR1_EL1.purpose:
Reserved for future expansion of information about implemented PE features in
AArch64 state.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

MPAM_frac, bits [16:19] - MPAM Extension fractional field.
RAS_frac, bits [12:15]  - RAS Extension fractional field.
MTE, bits [8:11]        - Support for the Memory Tagging Extension.
SSBS, bits [4:7]        - Speculative Store Bypassing controls in AArch64 state.
BT, bits [0:3]          - Branch Target Identification mechanism support in
                          AArch64 state.

ID_AA64ZFR0_EL1.purpose:
Provides additional information about the implemented features of the AArch64
Scalable Vector Extension, when the ID_AA64PFR0_EL1.SVE field is not zero.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers.

F64MM, bits [56:59] - Indicates support for SVE FP64 double-precision floating-
                      point matrix multiplication instructions.
F32MM, bits [52:55] - Indicates support for the SVE FP32 single-precision
                      floating-point matrix multiplication instruction.
I8MM, bits [44:47]  - Indicates support for SVE Int8 matrix multiplication
                      instructions.
BF16, bits [20:23]  - Indicates support for SVE BFloat16 instructions.
SVEver, bits [0:3]  - Scalable Vector Extension instruction set version.

ID_AFR0_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the implementation defined features of the PE in
AArch32 state.

Must be interpreted with the Main ID Register, MIDR_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

ID_DFR0_EL1.purpose:
Provides top level information about the debug system in AArch32 state.

Must be interpreted with the Main ID Register, MIDR_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

TraceFilt, bits [28:31] - Armv8.4 Self-hosted Trace Extension version.
PerfMon, bits [24:27]   - Performance Monitors Extension version.
MProfDbg, bits [20:23]  - M Profile Debug.
MMapTrc, bits [16:19]   - Memory Mapped Trace.
CopTrc, bits [12:15]    - Support for System registers-based trace model, using
                          registers in the coproc == 0b1110 encoding space.
MMapDbg, bits [8:11]    - Memory Mapped Debug.
CopSDbg, bits [4:7]     - Support for  a System registers-based Secure debug
                          model, using registers in the coproc = 0b1110 encoding
                          space, for an A profile processor that includes EL3.
CopDbg, bits [0:3]      - Support for System registers-based debug model, using
                          registers in the coproc == 0b1110 encoding space, for
                          A and R profile processors.

ID_DFR1_EL1.purpose:
Provides top level information about the debug system in AArch32.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

MTPMU, bits [0:3] - Multi-threaded PMU extension. Defined values are:
                        0b0000 ARMv8.6-MTPMU not implemented. If PMUv3 is
                    implemented, it is implementation defined whether
                    PMEVTYPER<n>_EL0.MT are read/write or res0.
                        0b0001 ARMv8.6-MTPMU implemented and PMEVTYPER<n>_EL0.MT
                    are read/write. When ARMv8.6-MTPMU is disabled, the
                    Effective values of PMEVTYPER<n>.MT are 0.
                        0b1111 ARMv8.6-MTPMU not implemented. If PMUv3 is
                    implemented, PMEVTYPER<n>_EL0.MT are res0.
                    All other values are reserved. ARMv8.6-MTPMU implements the
                    functionality identified by the value 0b0001. In an
                    Armv8.6-compliant implementation that includes PMUv3, the
                    value 0b0000 is not permitted. In an implementation that
                    does not include PMUv3, the value 0b0001 is not permitted.

ID_ISAR0_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the instruction sets implemented by the PE in AArch32
state.

Must be interpreted with ID_ISAR1_EL1, ID_ISAR2_EL1, ID_ISAR3_EL1, ID_ISAR4_EL1,
and ID_ISAR5_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers, see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D7.1.3.

Divide, bits [24:27]    - Indicates the implemented Divide instructions.
Debug, bits [20:23]     - Indicates the implemented Debug instructions.
Coproc, bits [16:19]    - Indicates the implemented System register access
                          instructions.
CmpBranch, bits [12:15] - Indicates the implemented combined Compare and Branch
                          instructions in the T32 instruction set.
BitField, bits [8:11]   - Indicates the implemented BitField instructions.
BitCount, bits [4:7]    - Indicates the implemented Bit Counting instructions.
Swap, bits [0:3]        - Indicates the implemented Swap instructions in the A32
                          instruction set.

ID_ISAR1_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the instruction sets implemented by the PE in AArch32
state.

Must be interpreted with ID_ISAR0_EL1, ID_ISAR2_EL1, ID_ISAR3_EL1, ID_ISAR4_EL1,
and ID_ISAR5_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers, see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D7.1.3.

Jazelle, bits [28:31]   - Indicates the implemented Jazelle extension
                          instructions.
Interwork, bits [24:27] - Indicates the implemented Interworking instructions.
Immediate, bits [20:23] - Indicates the implemented data-processing instructions
                          with long immediates.
IfThen, bits [16:19]    - Indicates the implemented If-Then instructions in the
                          T32 instruction set.
Extend, bits [12:15]    - Indicates the implemented Extend instructions.
Except_AR, bits [8:11]  - Indicates the implemented A and R profile exception-
                          handling instructions.
Except, bits [4:7]      - Indicates the implemented exception-handling
                          instructions in the A32 instruction set.
Endian, bits [0:3]      - Indicates the implemented Endian instructions.

ID_ISAR2_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the instruction sets implemented by the PE in AArch32
state.

Must be interpreted with ID_ISAR0_EL1, ID_ISAR1_EL1, ID_ISAR3_EL1, ID_ISAR4_EL1,
and ID_ISAR5_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

Reversal, bits [28:31]      - Indicates the implemented Reversal instructions.
PSR_AR, bits [24:27]        - Indicates the implemented A and R profile
                              instructions to manipulate the PSR.
MultU, bits [20:23]         - Indicates the implemented advanced unsigned
                              Multiply instructions.
MultS, bits [16:19]         - Indicates the implemented advanced signed Multiply
                              instructions.
Mult, bits [12:15]          - Indicates the implemented additional Multiply
                              instructions.
MultiAccessInt, bits [8:11] - Indicates the support for interruptible multi-
                              access instructions.
MemHint, bits [4:7]         - Indicates the implemented Memory Hint
                              instructions.
LoadStore, bits [0:3]       - Indicates the implemented additional load/store
                              instructions.

ID_ISAR3_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the instruction sets implemented by the PE in AArch32
state.

Must be interpreted with ID_ISAR0_EL1, ID_ISAR1_EL1, ID_ISAR2_EL1, ID_ISAR4_EL1,
and ID_ISAR5_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers, see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D7.1.3.

T32EE, bits [28:31]     - Indicates the implemented T32EE instructions.
TrueNOP, bits [24:27]   - Indicates the implemented true NOP instructions.
T32Copy, bits [20:23]   - Indicates the support for T32 non flag-setting MOV
                          instructions.
TabBranch, bits [16:19] - Indicates the implemented Table Branch instructions in
                          the T32 instruction set.
SynchPrim, bits [12:15] - Used in conjunction with ID_ISAR4.SynchPrim_frac to
                          indicate the implemented Synchronization Primitive
                          instructions.
SVC, bits [8:11]        - Indicates the implemented SVC instructions.
SIMD, bits [4:7]        - Indicates the implemented SIMD instructions.
Saturate, bits [0:3]    - Indicates the implemented Saturate instructions.

ID_ISAR4_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the instruction sets implemented by the PE in AArch32
state.

Must be interpreted with ID_ISAR0_EL1, ID_ISAR1_EL1, ID_ISAR2_EL1, ID_ISAR3_EL1,
and ID_ISAR5_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers, see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D7.1.3.

SWP_frac, bits [28:31]       - Indicates support for the memory system locking
                               the bus for SWP or SWPB instructions.
PSR_M, bits [24:27]          - Indicates the implemented M profile instructions
                               to modify the PSRs.
SynchPrim_frac, bits [20:23] - Used in conjunction with ID_ISAR3.SynchPrim to
                               indicate the implemented Synchronization
                               Primitive instructions.
Barrier, bits [16:19]        - Indicates the implemented Barrier instructions in
                               the A32 and T32 instruction sets.
SMC, bits [12:15]            - Indicates the implemented SMC instructions.
Writeback, bits [8:11]       - Indicates the support for Writeback addressing
                               modes.
WithShifts, bits [4:7]       - Indicates the support for instructions with
                               shifts.
Unpriv, bits [0:3]           - Indicates the implemented unprivileged
                               instructions.

ID_ISAR5_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the instruction sets implemented by the PE in AArch32
state.

Must be interpreted with ID_ISAR0_EL1, ID_ISAR1_EL1, ID_ISAR2_EL1, ID_ISAR3_EL1,
and ID_ISAR4_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers, see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D7.1.3.

VCMA, bits [28:31]  - Indicates AArch32 support for complex number addition and
                      multiplication where numbers are stored in vectors.
RDM, bits [24:27]   - Indicates whether the VQRDMLAH and VQRDMLSH instructions
                      are implemented in AArch32 state.
CRC32, bits [16:19] - Indicates whether the CRC32 instructions are implemented
                      in AArch32 state.
SHA2, bits [12:15]  - Indicates whether the SHA2 instructions are implemented in
                      AArch32 state.
SHA1, bits [8:11]   - Indicates whether the SHA1 instructions are implemented in
                      AArch32 state.
AES, bits [4:7]     - Indicates whether the AES instructions are implemented in
                      AArch32 state.
SEVL, bits [0:3]    - Indicates whether the SEVL instruction is implemented in
                      AArch32 state.

ID_ISAR6_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the instruction sets implemented by the PE in AArch32
state.

Must be interpreted with ID_ISAR0_EL1, ID_ISAR1_EL1, ID_ISAR2_EL1, ID_ISAR3_EL1,
ID_ISAR4_EL1 and ID_ISAR5_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

I8MM, bits [24:27]    - Indicates support for Advanced SIMD and floating-point
                        Int8 matrix multiplication instructions in AArch32
                        state.
BF16, bits [20:23]    - Indicates support for Advanced SIMD and floating-point
                        BFloat16 instructions in AArch32 state.
SPECRES, bits [16:19] - Indicates supporte for Speculation invalidation
                        instruction in AArch32 state.
SB, bits [12:15]      - Indicates support for SB instruction in AArch32 state.
FHM, bits [8:11]      - Indicates support for Advanced SIMD and floating-point
                        VFMAL and VFMSL instructions in AArch32 state.
DP, bits [4:7]        - Indicates the support for dot product instructions in
                        AArch32 state.
JSCVT, bits [0:3]     - Indicates support for the Javascript conversion
                        instruction in AArch32 state.

ID_MMFR0_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the implemented memory model and memory management
support in AArch32 state.

Must be interpreted with ID_MMFR1_EL1, ID_MMFR2_EL1, ID_MMFR3_EL1, and
ID_MMFR4_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

InnerShr, bits [28:31] - Innermost Shareability. Indicates the innermost
                         shareability domain implemented.
FCSE, bits [24:27]     - Indicates whether the implementation includes the FCSE.
AuxReg, bits [20:23]   - Auxiliary Registers. Indicates support for Auxiliary
                         registers.
TCM, bits [16:19]      - Indicates support for TCMs and associated DMAs.
ShareLvl, bits [12:15] - Shareability Levels. Indicates the number of
                         shareability levels implemented.
OuterShr, bits [8:11]  - Outermost Shareability. Indicates the outermost
                         shareability domain implemented.
PMSA, bits [4:7]       - Indicates support for a PMSA.
VMSA, bits [0:3]       - Indicates support for a VMSA.

ID_MMFR1_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the implemented memory model and memory management
support in AArch32 state.

Must be interpreted with ID_MMFR0_EL1, ID_MMFR2_EL1, ID_MMFR3_EL1, and
ID_MMFR4_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

BPred, bits [28:31]    - Branch Predictor.
L1TstCln, bits [24:27] - Level 1 cache Test and Clean.
L1Uni, bits [20:23]    - Level 1 Unified cache.
L1Hvd, bits [16:19]    - Level 1 Harvard cache.
L1UniSW, bits [12:15]  - Level 1 Unified cache by Set/Way.
L1HvdSW, bits [8:11]   - Level 1 Harvard cache by Set/Way.
L1UniVA, bits [4:7]    - Level 1 Unified cache by Virtual Address.
L1HvdVA, bits [0:3]    - Level 1 Harvard cache by Virtual Address.

ID_MMFR2_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the implemented memory model and memory management
support in AArch32 state.

Must be interpreted with ID_MMFR0_EL1, ID_MMFR1_EL1, ID_MMFR3_EL1, and
ID_MMFR4_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

HWAccFlg, bits [28:31] - Hardware Access Flag.
WFIStall, bits [24:27] - Wait For Interrupt Stall.
MemBarr, bits [20:23]  - Memory Barrier.
UniTLB, bits [16:19]   - Unified TLB.
HvdTLB, bits [12:15]   - If the Unified TLB field (UniTLB, bits [19:16]) is not
                         0000, then the meaning of this field is implementation
                         defined.
L1HvdRng, bits [8:11]  - Level 1 Harvard cache Range.
L1HvdBG, bits [4:7]    - Level 1 Harvard cache Background fetch.
L1HvdFG, bits [0:3]    - Level 1 Harvard cache Foreground fetch.

ID_MMFR3_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the implemented memory model and memory management
support in AArch32 state.

Must be interpreted with ID_MMFR0_EL1, ID_MMFR1_EL1, ID_MMFR2_EL1, and
ID_MMFR4_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

Supersec, bits [28:31]  - Supersections.
CMemSz, bits [24:27]    - Cached Memory Size.
CohWalk, bits [20:23]   - Coherent Walk.
PAN, bits [16:19]       - Privileged Access Never.
MaintBcst, bits [12:15] - Maintenance Broadcast.
BPMaint, bits [8:11]    - Branch Predictor Maintenance.
CMaintSW, bits [4:7]    - Cache Maintenance by Set/Way.
CMaintVA, bits [0:3]    - Cache Maintenance by  Virtual Address.

ID_MMFR4_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the implemented memory model and memory management
support in AArch32 state.

Must be interpreted with ID_MMFR0_EL1, ID_MMFR1_EL1, ID_MMFR2_EL1, and
ID_MMFR3_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

EVT, bits [28:31]   - Enhanced Virtualization Traps. If EL2 is implemented,
                      indicates support for the HCR2.{TTLBIS, TOCU, TICAB, TID4}
                      traps.
CCIDX, bits [24:27] - Support for use of the revised CCSIDR format and the
                      presence of the CCSIDR2 is indicated.
LSM, bits [20:23]   - Indicates support for LSMAOE and nTLSMD bits in HSCTLR and
                      SCTLR.
HPDS, bits [16:19]  - Hierarchical permission disables bits in translation
                      tables.
CnP, bits [12:15]   - Common not Private translations.
XNX, bits [8:11]    - Support for execute-never control distinction by Exception
                      level at stage 2.
AC2, bits [4:7]     - Indicates the extension of the ACTLR and HACTLR registers
                      using ACTLR2 and HACTLR2.
SpecSEI, bits [0:3] - Describes whether the PE can generate SError interrupt
                      exceptions from speculative reads of memory, including
                      speculative instruction fetches.

ID_MMFR5_EL1.purpose:
Provides information about the implemented memory model and memory management
support in AArch32 state.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

ETS, bits [0:3] - Support for Enhanced Translation Synchronization. Defined
                  values are:
                      0b0000 Enhanced Translation Synchronization is not
                  supported.
                      0b0001 Enhanced Translation Synchronization is supported.
                  All other values are reserved. ARMv8.0-ETS implements the
                  functionality identified by the value 0b0001. From Armv8.0,
                  the permitted values are 0b0000 and 0b0001.

ID_PFR0_EL1.purpose:
Gives top-level information about the instruction sets supported by the PE in
AArch32 state.

Must be interpreted with ID_PFR1_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

RAS, bits [28:31]    - RAS Extension version.
DIT, bits [24:27]    - Data Independent Timing.
AMU, bits [20:23]    - Activity Monitors Extension.
CSV2, bits [16:19]   - Speculative use of out of context branch targets.
State3, bits [12:15] - T32EE instruction set support.
State2, bits [8:11]  - Jazelle extension support.
State1, bits [4:7]   - T32 instruction set support.
State0, bits [0:3]   - A32 instruction set support.

ID_PFR1_EL1.purpose:
Gives information about the AArch32 programmers' model.

Must be interpreted with ID_PFR0_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

GIC, bits [28:31]            - System register GIC CPU interface.
Virt_frac, bits [24:27]      - Virtualization fractional field. When the
                               Virtualization field is 0b0000, determines the
                               support for features from the ARMv7
                               Virtualization Extensions.
Sec_frac, bits [20:23]       - Security fractional field. When the Security
                               field is 0b0000, determines the support for
                               features from the ARMv7 Security Extensions.
GenTimer, bits [16:19]       - Generic Timer support.
Virtualization, bits [12:15] - Virtualization support.
MProgMod, bits [8:11]        - M profile programmers' model support.
Security, bits [4:7]         - Security support.
ProgMod, bits [0:3]          - Support for the standard programmers' model for
                               Armv4 and later. Model must support User, FIQ,
                               IRQ, Supervisor, Abort, Undefined, and System
                               modes.

ID_PFR2_EL1.purpose:
Gives information about the AArch32 programmers' model.

Must be interpreted with ID_PFR0_EL1 and ID_PFR1_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

RAS_frac, bits [8:11] - RAS Extension fractional field.
SSBS, bits [4:7]      - Speculative Store Bypassing controls in AArch64 state.
CSV3, bits [0:3]      - Speculative use of faulting data.

IFSR32_EL2.purpose:
Allows access to the AArch32 IFSR register from AArch64 state only. Its value
has no effect on execution in AArch64 state.

FnV, bit [16]       - FAR not Valid, for a synchronous External abort other than
                      a synchronous External abort on a translation table walk.
ExT, bit [12]       - External abort type. This bit can be used to provide an
                      implementation defined classification of External aborts.
                      In an implementation that does not provide any
                      classification of External aborts, this bit is res0. For
                      aborts other than External aborts this bit always returns
                      0.
FS[4], bit [10]     - This field is bit[4] of FS[4:0]. Fault Status bits. Bits
                      [10] and [3:0] are interpreted together.
LPAE, bit [9]       - On taking a Data Abort exception, this bit is set as
                      follows:
FS[3:0], bits [0:3] - This field is bits[3:0] of FS[4:0]. See FS[4] for the
                      field description.

ISR_EL1.purpose:
Shows the pending status of the IRQ, FIQ, or SError interrupt.

When executing at EL2, EL3 or Secure EL1 when SCR_EL3.EEL2 == 0b0, this shows
the pending status of the physical IRQ, FIQ, or SError interrupts.

When executing at either Non-secure EL1 or at Secure EL1 when SCR_EL3.EEL2 ==
0b1:

  - If the HCR_EL2.{IMO,FMO,AMO} bit has a value of 1, the corresponding
ISR_EL1.{I,F,A} bit shows the pending status of the virtual IRQ, FIQ, or SError.
  - If the HCR_EL2.{IMO,FMO,AMO} bit has a value of 0, the corresponding
ISR_EL1.{I,F,A} bit shows the pending status of the physical IRQ, FIQ, or
SError.

A, bit [8] - SError interrupt pending bit.
                 0b0 No pending SError.
                 0b1 An SError interrupt is pending.
             If the SError interrupt is edge-triggered, this field is cleared to
             zero when the physical SError interrupt is taken.
I, bit [7] - IRQ pending bit. Indicates whether an IRQ interrupt is pending:
                 0b0 No pending IRQ.
                 0b1 An IRQ interrupt is pending.
F, bit [6] - FIQ pending bit. Indicates whether an FIQ interrupt is pending.
                 0b0 No pending FIQ.
                 0b1 An FIQ interrupt is pending.

LORC_EL1.purpose:
Enables and disables LORegions, and selects the current LORegion descriptor.

DS, bits [2:9] - Descriptor Select. Selects the current LORegion descriptor
                 accessed by LORSA_EL1, LOREA_EL1, and LORN_EL1. The number of
                 LORegion descriptors in implementation defined. The maximum
                 number of LORegion descriptors supported is 256. If the number
                 is less than 256, then bits[63:M+2] are res0, where M is
                 Log_2(Number of LORegion descriptors supported by the
                 implementation). If this field points to an LORegion descriptor
                 that is not supported by an implementation, then the registers
                 LORN_EL1, LOREA_EL1, and LORSA_EL1 are res0.
EN, bit [0]    - Enable. Indicates whether LORegions are enabled.
                     0b0 Disabled. Memory accesses do not match any LORegions.
                     0b1 Enabled. Memory accesses may match a LORegion.
                 This bit is permitted to be cached in a TLB.

LOREA_EL1.purpose:
Holds the physical address of the end of the LORegion described in the current
LORegion descriptor selected by LORC_EL1.DS.

EA[51:48], bits [48:51] - Extension to EA[47:16]. See EA[47:16] for more
                          details.
EA[47:16], bits [16:47] - Bits [47:16] of the end physical address of an
                          LORegion described in the current LORegion descriptor
                          selected by LORC_EL1.DS. Bits[15:0] of this address
                          are defined to be 0xFFFF. For implementations with
                          fewer than 48 bits, the upper bits of this field are
                          res0. When ARMv8.2-LPA is implemented, and 52-bit
                          addresses and a 64KB translation granule are in use,
                          EA[51:48] form the upper part of the address value.
                          Otherwise, for implementations with fewer than 52
                          physical address bits, EA[51:48] are res0.

LORID_EL1.purpose:
Indicates the number of LORegions and LORegion descriptors supported by the PE.

LD, bits [16:23] - Number of LORegion descriptors supported by the PE. This is
                   an 8-bit binary number.
LR, bits [0:7]   - Number of LORegions supported by the PE. This is an 8-bit
                   binary number. If LORID_EL1 indicates that no LORegions are
                   implemented, then LoadLOAcquire and StoreLORelease will
                   behave as LoadAcquire and StoreRelease.

LORN_EL1.purpose:
Holds the number of the LORegion described in the current LORegion descriptor
selected by LORC_EL1.DS.

Num, bits [0:7] - Number of the LORegion described in the current LORegion
                  descriptor selected by LORC_EL1.DS. The maximum number of
                  LORegions supported by the PE is 256. If the maximum number is
                  less than 256, then bits[8:N] are res0, where N is
                  (Log_2(Number of LORegions supported by the PE)). If this
                  field points to a LORegion that is not supported by the PE,
                  then the current LORegion descriptor does not match any
                  LORegion.

LORSA_EL1.purpose:
Indicates whether the current LORegion descriptor selected by LORC_EL1.DS is
enabled, and holds the physical address of the start of the LORegion.

SA[51:48], bits [48:51] - Extension to SA[47:16]. See SA[47:16] for more
                          details.
SA[47:16], bits [16:47] - Bits [47:16] of the start physical address of the
                          LORegion described in the current LORegion descriptor
                          selected by LORC_EL1.DS. Bits[15:0] of this address
                          are defined to be 0x0000. For implementations with
                          fewer than 48 bits, the upper bits of this field are
                          res0. When ARMv8.2-LPA is implemented, and 52-bit
                          addresses and a 64KB translation granule are in use,
                          SA[51:48] form the upper part of the address value.
                          Otherwise, for implementations with fewer than 52
                          physical address bits, SA[51:48] are res0.
Valid, bit [0]          - Indicates whether the current LORegion Descriptor is
                          enabled.
                              0b0 Disabled
                              0b1 Enabled

MAIR_EL1.purpose:
Provides the memory attribute encodings corresponding to the possible AttrIndx
values in a Long-descriptor format translation table entry for stage 1
translations at EL1.

Attr<n>, bits [0:63] - The memory attribute encoding for an AttrIndx[2:0] entry
                       in a Long descriptor format translation table entry,
                       where AttrIndx[2:0] gives the value of <n> in Attr<n>.
                       Attr is encoded as follows: 'dd' is encoded as follows:
                       'oooo' is encoded as follows: R = Outer Read-Allocate
                       policy, W = Outer Write-Allocate policy. 'iiii' is
                       encoded as follows: R = Inner Read-Allocate policy, W =
                       Inner Write-Allocate policy. The R and W bits in 'oooo'
                       and 'iiii' fields have the following meanings:

MAIR_EL2.purpose:
Provides the memory attribute encodings corresponding to the possible AttrIndx
values in a Long-descriptor format translation table entry for stage 1
translations at EL2.

Attr<n>, bits [0:63] - The memory attribute encoding for an AttrIndx[2:0] entry
                       in a Long descriptor format translation table entry,
                       where AttrIndx[2:0] gives the value of <n> in Attr<n>.
                       Attr is encoded as follows: 'dd' is encoded as follows:
                       'oooo' is encoded as follows: R = Outer Read-Allocate
                       policy, W = Outer Write-Allocate policy. 'iiii' is
                       encoded as follows: R = Inner Read-Allocate policy, W =
                       Inner Write-Allocate policy. The R and W bits in 'oooo'
                       and 'iiii' fields have the following meanings:

MAIR_EL3.purpose:
Provides the memory attribute encodings corresponding to the possible AttrIndx
values in a Long-descriptor format translation table entry for stage 1
translations at EL3.

Attr<n>, bits [0:63] - The memory attribute encoding for an AttrIndx[2:0] entry
                       in a Long descriptor format translation table entry,
                       where AttrIndx[2:0] gives the value of <n> in Attr<n>.
                       Attr is encoded as follows: 'dd' is encoded as follows:
                       'oooo' is encoded as follows: R = Outer Read-Allocate
                       policy, W = Outer Write-Allocate policy. 'iiii' is
                       encoded as follows: R = Inner Read-Allocate policy, W =
                       Inner Write-Allocate policy. The R and W bits in 'oooo'
                       and 'iiii' fields have the following meanings:

MDCCINT_EL1.purpose:
Enables interrupt requests to be signaled based on the DCC status flags.

RX, bit [30] - DCC interrupt request enable control for DTRRX. Enables a common
               COMMIRQ interrupt request to be signaled based on the DCC status
               flags.
                   0b0 No interrupt request generated by DTRRX.
                   0b1 Interrupt request will be generated on RXfull == 1.
               If legacy COMMRX and COMMTX signals are implemented, then these
               are not affected by the value of this bit.
TX, bit [29] - DCC interrupt request enable control for DTRTX. Enables a common
               COMMIRQ interrupt request to be signaled based on the DCC status
               flags.
                   0b0 No interrupt request generated by DTRTX.
                   0b1 Interrupt request will be generated on TXfull == 0.
               If legacy COMMRX and COMMTX signals are implemented, then these
               are not affected by the value of this bit.

MDCCSR_EL0.purpose:
Read-only register containing control status flags for the DCC.

RXfull, bit [30] - DTRRX full. Read-only view of the equivalent bit in the
                   EDSCR.
TXfull, bit [29] - DTRTX full. Read-only view of the equivalent bit in the
                   EDSCR.

MDCR_EL2.purpose:
Provides EL2 configuration options for self-hosted debug and the Performance
Monitors Extension.

MTPME, bit [28]    - Multi-threaded PMU Enable.
TDCC, bit [27]     - Trap DCC.
HLP, bit [26]      - Hypervisor Long event counter enable.
HCCD, bit [23]     - Hypervisor Cycle Counter Disable.
TTRF, bit [19]     - Traps use of the Trace Filter Control registers at EL1 to
                     EL2, as follows.
HPMD, bit [17]     - Guest Performance Monitors Disable.
TPMS, bit [14]     - Trap Performance Monitor Sampling.
E2PB, bits [12:13] - EL2 Profiling Buffer.
TDRA, bit [11]     - Trap Debug ROM Address register access.
TDOSA, bit [10]    - Trap debug OS-related register access.
TDOSA, bit [10]    - Trap debug OS-related register access.
TDA, bit [9]       - Trap Debug Access.
TDE, bit [8]       - Trap Debug exceptions.
HPME, bit [7]      - [MDCR_EL2.HPMN..(N-1)] event counters enable.
TPM, bit [6]       - Trap Performance Monitors accesses.
TPMCR, bit [5]     - Trap PMCR_EL0 or PMCR accesses.
HPMN, bits [0:4]   - Defines the number of event counters that are accessible
                     from EL3, EL2, EL1, and from EL0 if permitted.

MDCR_EL3.purpose:
Provides EL3 configuration options for self-hosted debug and the Performance
Monitors Extension.

MTPME, bit [28]     - Multi-threaded PMU Enable.
TDCC, bit [27]      - Trap DCC.
SCCD, bit [23]      - Secure Cycle Counter Disable.
EPMAD, bit [21]     - External Performance Monitors Non-secure Access Disable.
EPMAD, bit [21]     - External Performance Monitors Access Disable.
EDAD, bit [20]      - External Debug Non-secure Access Disable.
EDAD, bit [20]      - External Debug Access Disable.
EDAD, bit [20]      - External Debug Access disable.
TTRF, bit [19]      - Trap Trace Filter controls.
STE, bit [18]       - Secure Trace enable.
SPME, bit [17]      - Secure Performance Monitors enable.
SPME, bit [17]      - Secure Performance Monitors enable.
SDD, bit [16]       - AArch64 Secure Self-hosted invasive debug disable.
SPD32, bits [14:15] - AArch32 Secure self-hosted privileged debug.
NSPB, bits [12:13]  - Non-secure Profiling Buffer.
TDOSA, bit [10]     - Trap debug OS-related register access.
TDOSA, bit [10]     - Trap debug OS-related register access.
TDA, bit [9]        - Trap Debug Access.
TPM, bit [6]        - Trap Performance Monitor register accesses.

MDRAR_EL1.purpose:
Defines the base physical address of a 4KB-aligned memory-mapped debug
component, usually a ROM table that locates and describes the memory-mapped
debug components in the system. Armv8 deprecates any use of this register.

ROMADDR[51:48], bits [48:51] - Extension to ROMADDR[47:12]. See ROMADDR[47:12]
                               for more details.
ROMADDR[47:12], bits [12:47] - Bits[47:12] of the ROM table physical address.
                               When ARMv8.2-LPA is implemented, ROMADDR[51:48]
                               forms the upper part of the address value.
                               Otherwise, ROMADDR[51:48] is res0. If the
                               physical address size in bits (PAsize) is less
                               than 52, then the register bits corresponding to
                               ROMADDR [51:PAsize] are res0. Bits [11:0] of the
                               ROM table physical address are zero. Arm strongly
                               recommends that bits ROMADDR[(PAsize-1):32] are
                               zero in any system that supports AArch32 at the
                               highest implemented Exception level. In an
                               implementation that includes EL3, ROMADDR is an
                               address in Non-secure memory. It is
                               implementation defined whether the ROM table is
                               also accessible in Secure memory.
Valid, bits [0:1]            - This field indicates whether the ROM Table
                               address is valid. The permitted values of this
                               field are:
                                   0b00 ROM Table address is not valid. Software
                               must ignore ROMADDR.
                                   0b11 ROM Table address is valid.
                               Other values are reserved.

MDSCR_EL1.purpose:
Main control register for the debug implementation.

TFO, bit [31]        - Trace Filter override.
RXfull, bit [30]     - Used for save/restore of EDSCR.RXfull.
TXfull, bit [29]     - Used for save/restore of EDSCR.TXfull.
RXO, bit [27]        - Used for save/restore of EDSCR.RXO.
TXU, bit [26]        - Used for save/restore of EDSCR.TXU.
INTdis, bits [22:23] - Used for save/restore of EDSCR.INTdis.
TDA, bit [21]        - Used for save/restore of EDSCR.TDA.
SC2, bit [19]        - Used for save/restore of EDSCR.SC2.
MDE, bit [15]        - Monitor debug events.
HDE, bit [14]        - Used for save/restore of EDSCR.HDE.
KDE, bit [13]        - Local (kernel) debug enable.
TDCC, bit [12]       - Traps EL0 accesses to the Debug Communication Channel
                       (DCC) registers to EL1, or to EL2 when it is implemented
                       and enabled for the current Security state and
                       HCR_EL2.TGE is 1, from both Execution states, as follows.
ERR, bit [6]         - Used for save/restore of EDSCR.ERR.
SS, bit [0]          - Software step control bit.

MIDR_EL1.purpose:
Provides identification information for the PE, including an implementer code
for the device and a device ID number.

Implementer, bits [24:31]  - The Implementer code. This field must hold an
                             implementer code that has been assigned by Arm.
                             Assigned codes include the following: Arm can
                             assign codes that are not published in this manual.
                             All values not assigned by Arm are reserved and
                             must not be used.
Variant, bits [20:23]      - An implementation defined variant number.
                             Typically, this field is used to distinguish
                             between different product variants, or major
                             revisions of a product.
Architecture, bits [16:19] - The permitted values of this field are:
PartNum, bits [4:15]       - An implementation defined primary part number for
                             the device. On processors implemented by Arm, if
                             the top four bits of the primary part number are
                             0x0 or 0x7, the variant and architecture are
                             encoded differently.
Revision, bits [0:3]       - An implementation defined revision number for the
                             device.

MPAM0_EL1.purpose:
Holds information to generate MPAM labels for memory requests when executing at
EL0. When EL2 is present and enabled, the MPAM virtualization option is present,
MPAMHCR_EL2.GSTAPP_PLK == 1 and HCR_EL2.TGE == 0, MPAM1_EL1 is used instead of
MPAM0_EL1 to generate MPAM information to label memory requests.

If EL2 is present and enabled, and HCR_EL2.E2H == 0 or HCR_EL2.TGE == 0, the
MPAM virtualization option is present and MPAMHCR_EL2.EL0_VPMEN == 1, then MPAM
PARTIDs in MPAM0_EL1 are virtual and mapped into physical PARTIDs for the
current Security state.

PMG_D, bits [40:47]    - Performance monitoring group property for PARTID_D.
PMG_I, bits [32:39]    - Performance monitoring group property for PARTID_I.
PARTID_D, bits [16:31] - Partition ID for data accesses, including load and
                         store accesses, made from EL0.
PARTID_I, bits [0:15]  - Partition ID for instruction accesses made from EL0.

MPAM1_EL1.purpose:
Holds information to generate MPAM labels for memory requests when executing at
EL1.

When EL2 is present and enabled, the MPAM virtualization option is present,
MPAMHCR_EL2.GSTAPP_PLK == 1 and HCR_EL2.TGE == 0, MPAM1_EL1 is used instead of
MPAM0_EL1 to generate MPAM labels for memory requests when executing at EL0.

MPAM1_EL1 is an alias for MPAM2_EL2 when executing at EL2 with HCR_EL2.E2H == 1.

MPAM1_EL12 is an alias for MPAM1_EL1 when executing at EL2 or EL3 with
HCR_EL2.E2H == 1.

If EL2 is is present and enabled, the MPAM virtualization option is present and
MPAMHCR_EL2.EL1_VPMEN == 1, MPAM PARTIDs in MPAM1_EL1 are virtual and mapped
into physical PARTIDs for the current Security state. This mapping of MPAM1_EL1
virtual PARTIDs to physical PARTIDs when EL1_VPMEN is 1 also applies when
MPAM1_EL1 is used at EL0 due to MPAMHCR_EL2.GSTAPP_PLK.

MPAMEN, bit [63]       - MPAM Enable. MPAM is enabled when MPAMEN == 1. When
                         disabled, all PARTIDs and PMGs are output as their
                         default value in the corresponding ID space.
FORCED_NS, bit [60]    - In the Secure state, FORCED_NS Secure state indicates
                         the state of MPAM3_EL3.FORCE_NS.
PMG_D, bits [40:47]    - Performance monitoring group property for PARTID_D.
PMG_I, bits [32:39]    - Performance monitoring group property for PARTID_I.
PARTID_D, bits [16:31] - Partition ID for data accesses, including load and
                         store accesses, made from EL1.
PARTID_I, bits [0:15]  - Partition ID for instruction accesses made from EL1.

MPAM2_EL2.purpose:
Holds information to generate MPAM labels for memory requests when executing at
EL2.

MPAMEN, bit [63]       - MPAM Enable. MPAM is enabled when MPAMEN == 1. When
                         disabled, all PARTIDs and PMGs are output as their
                         default value in the corresponding ID space.
TIDR, bit [58]         - TIDR traps accesses to MPAMIDR_EL1 from EL1 to EL2.
TRAPMPAM0EL1, bit [49] - TRAPMPAM0EL1: Trap accesses from EL1 to the MPAM0_EL1
                         register trap to EL2.
TRAPMPAM1EL1, bit [48] - TRAPMPAM1EL1: Trap accesses from EL1 to the MPAM1_EL1
                         register trap to EL2.
PMG_D, bits [40:47]    - Performance monitoring group for data accesses.
PMG_I, bits [32:39]    - Performance monitoring group for instruction accesses.
PARTID_D, bits [16:31] - Partition ID for data accesses, including load and
                         store accesses, made from EL2.
PARTID_I, bits [0:15]  - Partition ID for instruction accesses made from EL2.

MPAM3_EL3.purpose:
Holds information to generate MPAM labels for memory requests when executing at
EL3.

MPAMEN, bit [63]       - MPAM Enable. MPAM is enabled when MPAMEN == 1. When
                         disabled, all PARTIDs and PMGs are output as their
                         default value in the corresponding ID space.
TRAPLOWER, bit [62]    - Trap direct accesses to any MPAM system registers that
                         are not undefined from all ELn lower than EL3.
SDEFLT, bit [61]       - SDEFLT overrides the PARTID with the default PARTID
                         when executing in the Secure state.
FORCE_NS, bit [60]     - FORCE_NS forces MPAM_NS to always be 1 in the Secure
                         state.
PMG_D, bits [40:47]    - Performance monitoring group for data accesses.
PMG_I, bits [32:39]    - Performance monitoring group for instruction accesses.
PARTID_D, bits [16:31] - Partition ID for data accesses, including load and
                         store accesses, made from EL3.
PARTID_I, bits [0:15]  - Partition ID for instruction accesses made from EL3.

MPAMHCR_EL2.purpose:
Controls the PARTID virtualization features of MPAM. It controls the mapping of
virtual PARTIDs into physical PARTIDs in MPAM0_EL1 when EL0_VPMEN == 1 and in
MPAM1_EL1 when EL1_VPMEN == 1.

TRAP_MPAMIDR_EL1, bit [31] - Trap accesses from EL1 to MPAMIDR_EL1 to EL2.
GSTAPP_PLK, bit [8]        - Make the PARTIDs at EL0 the same as the PARTIDs at
                             EL1. When executing at EL0, EL2 is enabled,
                             HCR_EL2.TGE == 0 and GSTAPP_PLK = 1, MPAM1_EL1 is
                             used instead of MPAM0_EL1 to generate MPAM labels
                             for memory requests.
EL1_VPMEN, bit [1]         - Enable the virtual PARTID mapping of the PARTID
                             fields in MPAM1_EL1 when executing at EL1. This bit
                             also enables virtual PARTID mapping when MPAM1_EL1
                             is used to generate MPAM labels for memory requests
                             at EL0 due to GSTAPP_PLK == 1.
EL0_VPMEN, bit [0]         - Enable the virtual PARTID mapping of the PARTID
                             fields of MPAM0_EL1 unless HCR_EL2.E2H == 1 and
                             HCR_EL2.TGE == 1. When HCR_EL2.E2H == 1 and
                             HCR_EL2.TGE == 1, EL0_VPMEN is ignored and
                             MPAM0_EL1 PARTID fields are not mapped. When
                             MPAMHCR_EL2.GSTAPP_PLK == 1 and HCR_EL2.TGE == 0,
                             MPAM1_EL1 is used as the source of PARTIDs and the
                             virtual PARTID mapping of MPAM1_EL1 PARTIDs is
                             controlled by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL1_VPMEN.

MPAMIDR_EL1.purpose:
Indicates the presence and maximum PARTID and PMG values supported in the
implementation. It also indicates whether the implementation supports MPAM
virtualization.

HAS_SDEFLT, bit [61]    - HAS_SDEFLT indicates support for MPAM3_EL3.SDEFLT bit.
HAS_FORCE_NS, bit [60]  - HAS_FORCE_NS indicates support for MPAM3_EL3.FORCE_NS
                          bit.
HAS_TIDR, bit [58]      - HAS_TIDR indicates support for MPAM2_EL2.TIDR bit.
PMG_MAX, bits [32:39]   - The largest value of PMG that the implementation can
                          generate. The PMG_I and PMG_D fields of every
                          MPAMn_ELx must implement at least enough bits to
                          represent PMG_MAX.
