VPMR_MAX, bits [18:20]  - If HAS_HCR == 0, VPMR_MAX must be 0b000. Otherwise, it
                          indicates the maximum register index n for the
                          MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 registers.
HAS_HCR, bit [17]       - HAS_HCR indicates that the PE implementation supports
                          MPAM virtualization, including MPAMHCR_EL2,
                          MPAMVPMV_EL2 and MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 with n in the range 0
                          to VPMR_MAX. Must be 0 if EL2 is not implemented in
                          either security state.
PARTID_MAX, bits [0:15] - The largest value of PARTID that the implementation
                          can generate. The PARTID_I and PARTID_D fields of
                          every MPAMn_ELx must implement at least enough bits to
                          represent PARTID_MAX.

MPAMVPM0_EL2.purpose:
MPAMVPM0_EL2 provides mappings from virtual PARTIDs 0 - 3 to physical PARTIDs.

MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX field gives the index of the highest implemented
MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 register. VPMR_MAX can be as large as 7 (8 registers) or 32
virtual PARTIDs. If MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX == 0, there is only a single
MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 register, MPAMVPM0_EL2.

Virtual PARTID mapping is enabled by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL1_VPMEN for PARTIDs in
MPAM1_EL1 and by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL0_VPMEN for PARTIDs in MPAM0_EL1.

A virtual-to-physical PARTID mapping entry, PhyPARTID<n>, is only valid when the
MPAMVPMV_EL2.VPM_V bit in bit position n is set to 1.

PhyPARTID3, bits [48:63] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 3.
                           PhyPARTID3 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 3 to a
                           physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID2, bits [32:47] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 2.
                           PhyPARTID2 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 2 to a
                           physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID1, bits [16:31] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 1.
                           PhyPARTID1 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 1 to a
                           physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID0, bits [0:15]  - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 0.
                           PhyPARTID0 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 0 to a
                           physical PARTID.

MPAMVPM1_EL2.purpose:
MPAMVPM1_EL2 provides mappings from virtual PARTIDs 4 - 7 to physical PARTIDs.

MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX field gives the index of the highest implemented
MPAMVPM0_EL2 to MPAMVPM7_EL2 registers. VPMR_MAX can be as large as 7 (8
registers) or 32 virtual PARTIDs. If MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX == 0, there is only a
single MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 register, MPAMVPM0_EL2.

Virtual PARTID mapping is enabled by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL1_VPMEN for PARTIDs in
MPAM1_EL1 and by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL0_VPMEN for PARTIDs in MPAM0_EL1.

A virtual-to-physical PARTID mapping entry, PhyPARTID<n>, is only valid when the
MPAMVPMV_EL2.VPM_V bit in bit position n is set to 1.

PhyPARTID7, bits [48:63] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 7.
                           PhyPARTID7 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 7 to a
                           physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID6, bits [32:47] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 6.
                           PhyPARTID6 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 6 to a
                           physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID5, bits [16:31] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 5.
                           PhyPARTID5 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 5 to a
                           physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID4, bits [0:15]  - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 4.
                           PhyPARTID4 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 4 to a
                           physical PARTID.

MPAMVPM2_EL2.purpose:
MPAMVPM2_EL2 provides mappings from virtual PARTIDs 8 - 11 to physical PARTIDs.

MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX field gives the index of the highest implemented
MPAMVPM0_EL2 to MPAMVPM7_EL2 registers. VPMR_MAX can be as large as 7 (8
registers) or 32 virtual PARTIDs. If MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX == 0, there is only a
single MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 register, MPAMVPM0_EL2.

Virtual PARTID mapping is enabled by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL1_VPMEN for PARTIDs in
MPAM1_EL1 and by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL0_VPMEN for PARTIDs in MPAM0_EL1.

A virtual-to-physical PARTID mapping entry, PhyPARTID<n>, is only valid when the
MPAMVPMV_EL2.VPM_V bit in bit position n is set to 1.

PhyPARTID11, bits [48:63] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 11.
                            PhyPARTID11 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 11
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID10, bits [32:47] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 10.
                            PhyPARTID10 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 10
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID9, bits [16:31]  - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 9.
                            PhyPARTID9 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 9 to
                            a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID8, bits [0:15]   - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 8.
                            PhyPARTID8 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 8 to
                            a physical PARTID.

MPAMVPM3_EL2.purpose:
MPAMVPM3_EL2 provides mappings from virtual PARTIDs 12 - 15 to physical PARTIDs.

MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX field gives the index of the highest implemented
MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 registers. VPMR_MAX can be as large as 7 (8 registers) or 32
virtual PARTIDs. If MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX == 0, there is only a single
MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 register, MPAMVPM0_EL2.

Virtual PARTID mapping is enabled by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL1_VPMEN for PARTIDs in
MPAM1_EL1 and by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL0_VPMEN for PARTIDs in MPAM0_EL1.

A virtual-to-physical PARTID mapping entry, PhyPARTID<n>, is only valid when the
MPAMVPMV_EL2.VPM_V bit in bit position n is set to 1.

PhyPARTID15, bits [48:63] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 15.
                            PhyPARTID15 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 15
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID14, bits [32:47] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 14.
                            PhyPARTID14 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 14
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID13, bits [16:31] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 13.
                            PhyPARTID13 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 13
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID12, bits [0:15]  - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 12.
                            PhyPARTID12 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 12
                            to a physical PARTID.

MPAMVPM4_EL2.purpose:
MPAMVPM4_EL2 provides mappings from virtual PARTIDs 16 - 19 to physical PARTIDs.

MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX field gives the index of the highest implemented
MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 registers. VPMR_MAX can be as large as 7 (8 registers) or 32
virtual PARTIDs. If MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX == 0, there is only a single
MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 register, MPAMVPM0_EL2.

Virtual PARTID mapping is enabled by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL1_VPMEN for PARTIDs in
MPAM1_EL1 and by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL0_VPMEN for PARTIDs in MPAM0_EL1.

A virtual-to-physical PARTID mapping entry, PhyPARTID<n>, is only valid when the
MPAMVPMV_EL2.VPM_V bit in bit position n is set to 1.

PhyPARTID19, bits [48:63] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 19.
                            PhyPARTID19 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 19
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID18, bits [32:47] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 18.
                            PhyPARTID18 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 18
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID17, bits [16:31] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 17.
                            PhyPARTID17 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 17
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID16, bits [0:15]  - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 16.
                            PhyPARTID16 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 16
                            to a physical PARTID.

MPAMVPM5_EL2.purpose:
MPAMVPM5_EL2 provides mappings from virtual PARTIDs 20 - 23 to physical PARTIDs.

MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX field gives the index of the highest implemented
MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 registers. VPMR_MAX can be as large as 7 (8 registers) or 32
virtual PARTIDs. If MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX == 0, there is only a single
MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 register, MPAMVPM0_EL2.

Virtual PARTID mapping is enabled by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL1_VPMEN for PARTIDs in
MPAM1_EL1 and by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL0_VPMEN for PARTIDs in MPAM0_EL1.

A virtual-to-physical PARTID mapping entry, PhyPARTID<n>, is only valid when the
MPAMVPMV_EL2.VPM_V bit in bit position n is set to 1.

PhyPARTID23, bits [48:63] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 23.
                            PhyPARTID23 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 23
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID22, bits [32:47] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 22.
                            PhyPARTID22 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 22
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID21, bits [16:31] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 21.
                            PhyPARTID21 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 21
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID20, bits [0:15]  - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 20.
                            PhyPARTID20 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 20
                            to a physical PARTID.

MPAMVPM6_EL2.purpose:
MPAMVPM6_EL2 provides mappings from virtual PARTIDs 24 - 27 to physical PARTIDs.

MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX field gives the index of the highest implemented
MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 registers. VPMR_MAX can be as large as 7 (8 registers) or 32
virtual PARTIDs. If MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX == 0, there is only a single
MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 register, MPAMVPM0_EL2.

Virtual PARTID mapping is enabled by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL1_VPMEN for PARTIDs in
MPAM1_EL1 and by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL0_VPMEN for PARTIDs in MPAM0_EL1.

A virtual-to-physical PARTID mapping entry, PhyPARTID<n>, is only valid when the
MPAMVPMV_EL2.VPM_V bit in bit position n is set to 1.

PhyPARTID27, bits [48:63] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 27.
                            PhyPARTID27 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 27
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID26, bits [32:47] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 26.
                            PhyPARTID26 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 26
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID25, bits [16:31] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 25.
                            PhyPARTID25 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 25
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID24, bits [0:15]  - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 24.
                            PhyPARTID24 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 24
                            to a physical PARTID.

MPAMVPM7_EL2.purpose:
MPAMVPM7_EL2 provides mappings from virtual PARTIDs 28 - 31 to physical PARTIDs.

MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX field gives the index of the highest implemented
MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 registers. VPMR_MAX can be as large as 7 (8 registers) or 32
virtual PARTIDs. If MPAMIDR_EL1.VPMR_MAX == 0, there is only a single
MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 register, MPAMVPM0_EL2.

Virtual PARTID mapping is enabled by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL1_VPMEN for PARTIDs in
MPAM1_EL1 and by MPAMHCR_EL2.EL0_VPMEN for MPAM0_EL1.

A virtual-to-physical PARTID mapping entry, PhyPARTID<n>, is only valid when the
MPAMVPMV_EL2.VPM_V bit in bit position n is set to 1.

PhyPARTID31, bits [48:63] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 31.
                            PhyPARTID31 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 31
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID30, bits [32:47] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 30.
                            PhyPARTID30 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 30
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID29, bits [16:31] - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 29.
                            PhyPARTID29 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 29
                            to a physical PARTID.
PhyPARTID28, bits [0:15]  - Virtual PARTID Mapping Entry for virtual PARTID 28.
                            PhyPARTID28 gives the mapping of virtual PARTID 28
                            to a physical PARTID.

MPAMVPMV_EL2.long_name: MPAM Virtual Partition Mapping Valid Register
MPAMVPMV_EL2.purpose:
Valid bits for virtual PARTID mapping entries. Each bit m corresponds to virtual
PARTID mapping entry m in the MPAMVPM<n>_EL2 registers where n = m >> 2.

VPM_V<m>, bits [0:31] - Contains valid bit for virtual PARTID mapping entry
                        corresponding to virtual PARTID<m>.

MPIDR_EL1.purpose:
In a multiprocessor system, provides an additional PE identification mechanism
for scheduling purposes.

Aff3, bits [32:39] - Affinity level 3. See the description of Aff0 for more
                     information. Aff3 is not supported in AArch32 state.
U, bit [30]        - Indicates a Uniprocessor system, as distinct from PE 0 in a
                     multiprocessor system.
MT, bit [24]       - Indicates whether the lowest level of affinity consists of
                     logical PEs that are implemented using a multithreading
                     type approach. See the description of Aff0 for more
                     information about affinity levels.
Aff2, bits [16:23] - Affinity level 2. See the description of Aff0 for more
                     information.
Aff1, bits [8:15]  - Affinity level 1. See the description of Aff0 for more
                     information.
Aff0, bits [0:7]   - Affinity level 0. This is the affinity level that is most
                     significant for determining PE behavior. Higher affinity
                     levels are increasingly less significant in determining PE
                     behavior. The assigned value of the MPIDR.{Aff2, Aff1,
                     Aff0} or MPIDR_EL1.{Aff3, Aff2, Aff1, Aff0} set of fields
                     of each PE must be unique within the system as a whole.

MVFR0_EL1.long_name: AArch32 Media and VFP Feature Register 0
MVFR0_EL1.purpose:
Describes the features provided by the AArch32 Advanced SIMD and Floating-point
implementation.

Must be interpreted with MVFR1_EL1 and MVFR2_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

FPRound, bits [28:31]  - Floating-Point Rounding modes.
FPShVec, bits [24:27]  - Short Vectors.
FPSqrt, bits [20:23]   - Square Root.
FPDivide, bits [16:19] - Indicates whether the floating-point implementation
                         provides support for VFP divide operations.
FPTrap, bits [12:15]   - Floating Point Exception Trapping.
FPDP, bits [8:11]      - Double Precision.
FPSP, bits [4:7]       - Single Precision.
SIMDReg, bits [0:3]    - Advanced SIMD registers.

MVFR1_EL1.long_name: AArch32 Media and VFP Feature Register 1
MVFR1_EL1.purpose:
Describes the features provided by the AArch32 Advanced SIMD and Floating-point
implementation.

Must be interpreted with MVFR0_EL1 and MVFR2_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D10.4.1.

SIMDFMAC, bits [28:31] - Advanced SIMD Fused Multiply-Accumulate.
FPHP, bits [24:27]     - Floating Point Half Precision.
SIMDHP, bits [20:23]   - Advanced SIMD Half Precision.
SIMDSP, bits [16:19]   - Advanced SIMD Single Precision.
SIMDInt, bits [12:15]  - Advanced SIMD Integer.
SIMDLS, bits [8:11]    - Advanced SIMD Load/Store.
FPDNaN, bits [4:7]     - Default NaN mode.
FPFtZ, bits [0:3]      - Flush to Zero mode.

MVFR2_EL1.long_name: AArch32 Media and VFP Feature Register 2
MVFR2_EL1.purpose:
Describes the features provided by the AArch32 Advanced SIMD and Floating-point
implementation.

Must be interpreted with MVFR0_EL1 and MVFR1_EL1.

For general information about the interpretation of the ID registers, see
'Principles of the ID scheme for fields in ID registers' in the Arm®
Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
D7.1.3.

FPMisc, bits [4:7]   - Indicates whether the floating-point implementation
                       provides support for miscellaneous VFP features.
SIMDMisc, bits [0:3] - Indicates whether the Advanced SIMD implementation
                       provides support for miscellaneous Advanced SIMD
                       features.

NZCV.purpose:
Allows access to the condition flags.

N, bit [31] - Negative condition flag. Set to 1 if the result of the last flag-
              setting instruction was negative.
Z, bit [30] - Zero condition flag. Set to 1 if the result of the last flag-
              setting instruction was zero, and to 0 otherwise. A result of zero
              often indicates an equal result from a comparison.
C, bit [29] - Carry condition flag. Set to 1 if the last flag-setting
              instruction resulted in a carry condition, for example an unsigned
              overflow on an addition.
V, bit [28] - Overflow condition flag. Set to 1 if the last flag-setting
              instruction resulted in an overflow condition, for example a
              signed overflow on an addition.

OSDLR_EL1.purpose:
Used to control the OS Double Lock.

DLK, bit [0] - OS Double Lock control bit.
                   0b0 OS Double Lock unlocked.
                   0b1 OS Double Lock locked, if DBGPRCR_EL1.CORENPDRQ (Core no
               powerdown request) bit is set to 0 and the PE is in Non-debug
               state.

OSDTRRX_EL1.long_name: OS Lock Data Transfer Register, Receive
OSDTRRX_EL1.purpose:
Used for save/restore of DBGDTRRX_EL0. It is a component of the Debug
Communications Channel.

bits [0:31] - Update DTRRX without side-effect. Writes to this register update
              the value in DTRRX and do not change RXfull. Reads of this
              register return the last value written to DTRRX and do not change
              RXfull. For the full behavior of the Debug Communications Channel,
              see 'The Debug Communication Channel and Instruction Transfer
              Register' in the Arm® Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for
              Armv8-A architecture profile, chapter H4.

OSDTRTX_EL1.long_name: OS Lock Data Transfer Register, Transmit
OSDTRTX_EL1.purpose:
Used for save/restore of DBGDTRTX_EL0. It is a component of the Debug
Communications Channel.

bits [0:31] - Return DTRTX without side-effect. Reads of this register return
              the value in DTRTX and do not change TXfull. Writes of this
              register update the value in DTRTX and do not change TXfull. For
              the full behavior of the Debug Communications Channel, see 'The
              Debug Communication Channel and Instruction Transfer Register' in
              the Arm® Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A
              architecture profile, chapter H4.

OSECCR_EL1.long_name: OS Lock Exception Catch Control Register
OSECCR_EL1.purpose:
Provides a mechanism for an operating system to access the contents of EDECCR
that are otherwise invisible to software, so it can save/restore the contents of
EDECCR over powerdown on behalf of the external debugger.

EDECCR, bits [0:31] - Used for save/restore to EDECCR over powerdown. Reads or
                      writes to this field are indirect accesses to EDECCR.

OSLAR_EL1.purpose:
Used to lock or unlock the OS Lock.

OSLK, bit [0] - On writes to OSLAR_EL1, bit[0] is copied to the OS Lock. Use
                OSLSR_EL1.OSLK to check the current status of the lock.

OSLSR_EL1.purpose:
Provides the status of the OS Lock.

OSLM[1], bit [3] - This field is bit[1] of OSLM[1:0]. OS lock model implemented.
                   Identifies the form of OS save and restore mechanism
                   implemented.
                       0b00 OS Lock not implemented.
                       0b10 OS Lock implemented.
                   All other values are reserved. In an Armv8 implementation the
                   value 0b00 is not permitted. The OSLM field is split as
                   follows:
                     - OSLM[1] is OSLSR_EL1[3].
                     - OSLM[0] is OSLSR_EL1[0].
nTT, bit [2]     - Not 32-bit access. This bit is always RAZ. It indicates that
                   a 32-bit access is needed to write the key to the OS Lock
                   Access Register.
OSLK, bit [1]    - OS Lock Status.
                       0b0 OS Lock unlocked.
                       0b1 OS Lock locked.
                   The OS Lock is locked and unlocked by writing to the OS Lock
                   Access Register.
OSLM[0], bit [0] - This field is bit[0] of OSLM[1:0]. See OSLM[1] for the field
                   description.

PAN.purpose:
Allows access to the Privileged Access Never bit.

PAN, bit [22] - Privileged Access Never.
                    0b0 Privileged reads and write are not disabled by this
                mechanism.
                    0b1 Disables privileged read and write accesses to addresses
                accessible at EL0 for an enabled stage 1 translation regime that
                defines the EL0 permissions.
                The value of this bit is usually preserved on taking an
                exception, except in the following situations:
                  - When the target of the exception is EL1, and the value of
                the SCTLR_EL1.SPAN bit is 0, this bit is set to 1.
                  - When the target of the exception is EL2, HCR_EL2.{E2H, TGE}
                is {1, 1}, and the value of the SCTLR_EL2.SPAN bit is 0, this
                bit is set to 1.

PAR_EL1.purpose:
Returns the output address (OA) from an Address translation instruction that
executed successfully, or fault information if the instruction did not execute
successfully.

ATTR, bits [56:63]      - Memory attributes for the returned output address.
PA[51:48], bits [48:51] - Extension to PA[47:12].
PA[47:12], bits [12:47] - Output address.
NS, bit [9]             - Non-secure.
SH, bits [7:8]          - Shareability attribute, for the returned output
                          address.
F, bit [0]              - Indicates whether the instruction performed a
                          successful address translation.

PMBIDR_EL1.purpose:
Provides information to software as to whether the buffer can be programmed at
the current Exception level.

F, bit [5]        - Flag updates. Defines whether the address translation
                    performed by the Profiling Buffer manages the Access Flag
                    and dirty state.
P, bit [4]        - Programming not allowed. The Profiling Buffer is owned by a
                    higher Exception level or the other Security state.
Align, bits [0:3] - Defines the minimum alignment constraint for PMBPTR_EL1. If
                    this field is non-zero, then the PE must pad every record up
                    to a multiple of this size.

PMBLIMITR_EL1.purpose:
Defines the upper limit for the profiling buffer, and enables the profiling
buffer

LIMIT, bits [12:63] - Limit address. PMBLIMITR_EL1.LIMIT:Zeros(12) is the
                      address of the first byte in memory after the last byte in
                      the profiling buffer. If the smallest implemented
                      translation granule is not 4KB, then bits[N-1:12] are
                      res0, where N is the implementation defined value,
                      Log_2(smallest implemented translation granule).
FM, bits [1:2]      - Fill mode
                          0b00 Stop collection and raise maintenance interrupt
                      on buffer fill.
                      All other values are reserved. If this field is programmed
                      with a reserved value, the PE behaves as if this field has
                      a defined value, other than for a direct read of the
                      register. Software must not rely on the behavior of
                      reserved values, as they might change in a future version
                      of the architecture.
E, bit [0]          - Profiling Buffer enable
                          0b0 All output is discarded.
                          0b1 Profiling buffer enabled.

PMBPTR_EL1.purpose:
Defines the current write pointer for the profiling buffer.

PTR, bits [0:63] - Current write address. Defines the virtual address of the
                   next entry to be written to the buffer. The architecture
                   places restrictions on the values software can write to the
                   pointer. For more information see 'Restrictions on the
                   current write pointer' in the Arm® Architecture Reference
                   Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section
                   D6.3.5. As a result, an implementation might treat some of
                   bits[M:0], where M is defined by PMBIDR_EL1.Align, as res0.
                   On a management interrupt, PMBPTR_EL1 is frozen.

PMBSR_EL1.purpose:
Provides syndrome information to software when the buffer is disabled because
the management interrupt has been raised.

EC, bits [26:31] - Exception class Top-level description of the cause of the
                   buffer management event
DL, bit [19]     - Partial record lost. Following a buffer management event
                   other than an asynchronous External abort, indicates whether
                   the last record written to the Profiling Buffer is complete.
EA, bit [18]     - External abort.
S, bit [17]      - Service
COLL, bit [16]   - Collision detected.
MSS, bits [0:15] - Management Event Specific Syndrome. Contains syndrome
                   specific to the management event.

PMCCFILTR_EL0.long_name: Performance Monitors Cycle Count Filter Register
PMCCFILTR_EL0.purpose:
Determines the modes in which the Cycle Counter, PMCCNTR_EL0, increments.

P, bit [31]   - Privileged filtering bit. Controls counting in EL1. If EL3 is
                implemented, then counting in Non-secure EL1 is further
                controlled by the PMCCFILTR_EL0.NSK bit.
U, bit [30]   - User filtering bit. Controls counting in EL0. If EL3 is
                implemented, then counting in Non-secure EL0 is further
                controlled by the PMCCFILTR_EL0.NSU bit.
NSK, bit [29] - Non-secure EL1 (kernel) modes filtering bit. Controls counting
                in Non-secure EL1. If the value of this bit is equal to the
                value of the PMCCFILTR_EL0.P bit, cycles in Non-secure EL1 are
                counted. Otherwise, cycles in Non-secure EL1 are not counted.
NSU, bit [28] - Non-secure EL0 (Unprivileged) filtering bit. Controls counting
                in Non-secure EL0. If the value of this bit is equal to the
                value of the PMCCFILTR_EL0.U bit, cycles in Non-secure EL0 are
                counted. Otherwise, cycles in Non-secure EL0 are not counted.
NSH, bit [27] - EL2 (Hypervisor) filtering bit. Controls counting in EL2. If
                Secure EL2 is implemented, counting in Secure EL2 is further
                controlled by the PMCCFILTR_EL0.SH bit.
M, bit [26]   - Secure EL3 filtering bit. If the value of this bit is equal to
                the value of the PMCCFILTR_EL0.P bit, cycles in Secure EL3 are
                counted. Otherwise, cycles in Secure EL3 are not counted. Most
                applications can ignore this field and set its value to 0. This
                field is not visible in the AArch32 PMCCFILTR System register.
SH, bit [24]  - Secure EL2 filtering. If the value of this bit is not equal to
                the value of the PMCCFILTR_EL0.NSH bit, cycles in Secure EL2 are
                counted. Otherwise, cycles in Secure EL2 are not counted. If
                Secure EL2 is not implemented or is disabled, this field is
                res0. This field is not visible in the AArch32 PMCCFILTR System
                register.

PMCCNTR_EL0.purpose:
Holds the value of the processor Cycle Counter, CCNT, that counts processor
clock cycles. See 'Time as measured by the Performance Monitors cycle counter'
in the Arm® Architecture Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture
profile for more information.

PMCCFILTR_EL0 determines the modes and states in which the PMCCNTR_EL0 can
increment.

CCNT, bits [0:63] - Cycle count. Depending on the values of PMCR_EL0.{LC,D},
                    this field increments in one of the following ways:
                      - Every processor clock cycle.
                      - Every 64th processor clock cycle. Writing 1 to
                    PMCR_EL0.C sets this field to 0.

PMCEID0_EL0.long_name: Performance Monitors Common Event Identification register 0
PMCEID0_EL0.purpose:
Defines which common architectural events and common microarchitectural  events
are implemented, or counted, using PMU events in the ranges 0x0000 to 0x001F and
0x4000 to 0x401F.

When the value of a bit in the register is 1 the corresponding common event is
implemented and counted.

Arm recommends that, if a common event is never counted, the value of the
corresponding register bit is 0.

For more information about the common events and the use of the PMCEID<n>_EL0
registers see The section describing 'Event numbers and common events' in
chapter D5 'The Performance Monitors Extension' of the Arm Architecture
Reference Manual, for Armv8-A architecture profile.

IDhi<n>, bits [32:63] - IDhi[n] corresponds to common event (0x4000 + n). For
                        each bit:
                            0b0 The common event is not implemented, or not
                        counted.
                            0b1 The common event is implemented.
ID<n>, bits [0:31]    - ID[n] corresponds to common event n. For each bit:
                            0b0 The common event is not implemented, or not
                        counted.
                            0b1 The common event is implemented.

PMCEID1_EL0.long_name: Performance Monitors Common Event Identification register 1
PMCEID1_EL0.purpose:
Defines which common architectural events and common microarchitectural  events
are implemented, or counted, using PMU events in the ranges 0x0020 to 0x003F and
0x4020 to 0x403F.

When the value of a bit in the register is 1 the corresponding common event is
implemented and counted.

Arm recommends that, if a common event is never counted, the value of the
corresponding register bit is 0.

For more information about the common events and the use of the PMCEID<n>_EL0
registers see The section describing 'Event numbers and common events' in
chapter D5 'The Performance Monitors Extension' of the Arm Architecture
Reference Manual, for Armv8-A architecture profile.

IDhi<n>, bits [32:63] - IDhi[n] corresponds to common event (0x4020 + n). For
                        each bit:
                            0b0 The common event is not implemented, or not
                        counted.
                            0b1 The common event is implemented.
ID<n>, bits [0:31]    - ID[n] corresponds to common event (0x0020 + n). For each
                        bit:
                            0b0 The common event is not implemented, or not
                        counted.
                            0b1 The common event is implemented.

PMCNTENCLR_EL0.long_name: Performance Monitors Count Enable Clear register
PMCNTENCLR_EL0.purpose:
Disables the Cycle Count Register, PMCCNTR_EL0, and any implemented event
counters PMEVCNTR<n>. Reading this register shows which counters are enabled.

C, bit [31]       - PMCCNTR_EL0 disable bit. Disables the cycle counter
                    register. Possible values are:
                        0b0 When read, means the cycle counter is disabled. When
                    written, has no effect.
                        0b1 When read, means the cycle counter is enabled. When
                    written, disables the cycle counter.
P<n>, bits [0:30] - Event counter disable bit for PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0. If N is less
                    than 31, then bits [30:N] are RAZ/WI. When EL2 is
                    implemented and enabled in the current Security state, in
                    EL1 and EL0, N is the value in MDCR_EL2.HPMN. Otherwise, N
                    is the value in PMCR_EL0.N.
                        0b0 When read, means that PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 is disabled.
                    When written, has no effect.
                        0b1 When read, means that PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 is enabled.
                    When written, disables PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0.

PMCNTENSET_EL0.long_name: Performance Monitors Count Enable Set register
PMCNTENSET_EL0.purpose:
Enables the Cycle Count Register, PMCCNTR_EL0, and any implemented event
counters PMEVCNTR<n>. Reading this register shows which counters are enabled.

C, bit [31]       - PMCCNTR_EL0 enable bit. Enables the cycle counter register.
                    Possible values are:
                        0b0 When read, means the cycle counter is disabled. When
                    written, has no effect.
                        0b1 When read, means the cycle counter is enabled. When
                    written, enables the cycle counter.
P<n>, bits [0:30] - Event counter enable bit for PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0. If N is less
                    than 31, then bits [30:N] are RAZ/WI. When EL2 is
                    implemented and enabled in the current Security state, in
                    EL1 and EL0, N is the value in MDCR_EL2.HPMN. Otherwise, N
                    is the value in PMCR_EL0.N.
                        0b0 When read, means that PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 is disabled.
                    When written, has no effect.
                        0b1 When read, means that PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 event counter
                    is enabled. When written, enables PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0.

PMCR_EL0.purpose:
Provides details of the Performance Monitors implementation, including the
number of counters implemented, and configures and controls the counters.

IMP, bits [24:31]    - Implementer code.
IDCODE, bits [16:23] - Identification code.
N, bits [11:15]      - Indicates the number of event counters implemented.
LP, bit [7]          - Long event counter enable.
LC, bit [6]          - Long cycle counter enable.
DP, bit [5]          - Disable cycle counter when event counting is prohibited.
X, bit [4]           - Enable export of events in an implementation defined PMU
                       event export bus.
D, bit [3]           - Clock divider.
C, bit [2]           - Cycle counter reset.
P, bit [1]           - Event counter reset.
E, bit [0]           - Enable.

PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0.purpose:
Holds event counter n, which counts events, where n is 0 to 30.

bits [0:63] - Event counter n. Value of event counter n, where n is the number
              of this register and is a number from 0 to 30.

PMEVTYPER<n>_EL0.purpose:
Configures event counter n, where n is 0 to 30.

P, bit [31]                   - Privileged filtering bit.
U, bit [30]                   - User filtering bit.
NSK, bit [29]                 - Non-secure EL1 (kernel) modes filtering bit.
NSU, bit [28]                 - Non-secure EL0 (Unprivileged) filtering bit.
NSH, bit [27]                 - EL2 (Hypervisor) filtering bit.
M, bit [26]                   - Secure EL3 filtering bit.
MT, bit [25]                  - Multithreading.
SH, bit [24]                  - Secure EL2 filtering.
evtCount[15:10], bits [10:15] - Extension to evtCount[9:0].
evtCount[9:0], bits [0:9]     - Event to count.

PMINTENCLR_EL1.long_name: Performance Monitors Interrupt Enable Clear register
PMINTENCLR_EL1.purpose:
Disables the generation of interrupt requests on overflows from the Cycle Count
Register, PMCCNTR_EL0, and the event counters PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0. Reading the
register shows which overflow interrupt requests are enabled.

C, bit [31]       - PMCCNTR_EL0 overflow interrupt request disable bit. Possible
                    values are:
                        0b0 When read, means the cycle counter overflow
                    interrupt request is disabled. When written, has no effect.
                        0b1 When read, means the cycle counter overflow
                    interrupt request is enabled. When written, disables the
                    cycle count overflow interrupt request.
P<n>, bits [0:30] - Event counter overflow interrupt request disable bit for
                    PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0. If N is less than 31, then bits [30:N] are
                    RAZ/WI. When EL2 is implemented and enabled in the current
                    Security state, in EL1, N is the value in MDCR_EL2.HPMN.
                    Otherwise, N is the value in PMCR_EL0.N.
                        0b0 When read, means that the PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 event
                    counter interrupt request is disabled. When written, has no
                    effect.
                        0b1 When read, means that the PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 event
                    counter interrupt request is enabled. When written, disables
                    the PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 interrupt request.

PMINTENSET_EL1.long_name: Performance Monitors Interrupt Enable Set register
PMINTENSET_EL1.purpose:
Enables the generation of interrupt requests on overflows from the Cycle Count
Register, PMCCNTR_EL0, and the event counters PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0. Reading the
register shows which overflow interrupt requests are enabled.

C, bit [31]       - PMCCNTR_EL0 overflow interrupt request enable bit. Possible
                    values are:
                        0b0 When read, means the cycle counter overflow
                    interrupt request is disabled. When written, has no effect.
                        0b1 When read, means the cycle counter overflow
                    interrupt request is enabled. When written, enables the
                    cycle count overflow interrupt request.
P<n>, bits [0:30] - Event counter overflow interrupt request enable bit for
                    PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0. If N is less than 31, then bits [30:N] are
                    RAZ/WI. When EL2 is implemented and enabled in the current
                    Security state, in EL1, N is the value in MDCR_EL2.HPMN.
                    Otherwise, N is the value in PMCR_EL0.N.
                        0b0 When read, means that the PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 event
                    counter interrupt request is disabled. When written, has no
                    effect.
                        0b1 When read, means that the PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 event
                    counter interrupt request is enabled. When written, enables
                    the PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 interrupt request.

PMMIR_EL1.purpose:
Describes Performance Monitors parameters specific to the implementation to
software.

SLOTS, bits [0:7] - Operation width. The largest value by which the STALL_SLOT
                    event might increment by in a single cycle. If the
                    STALL_SLOT event is not implemented, this field might read
                    as zero.

PMOVSCLR_EL0.long_name: Performance Monitors Overflow Flag Status Clear Register
PMOVSCLR_EL0.purpose:
Contains the state of the overflow bit for the Cycle Count Register,
PMCCNTR_EL0, and each of the implemented event counters PMEVCNTR<n>. Writing to
this register clears these bits.

C, bit [31]       - Cycle counter overflow clear bit.
                        0b0 When read, means the cycle counter has not
                    overflowed since this bit was last cleared. When written,
                    has no effect.
                        0b1 When read, means the cycle counter has overflowed
                    since this bit was last cleared. When written, clears the
                    cycle counter overflow bit to 0.
                    PMCR_EL0.LC controls whether an overflow is detected from
                    unsigned overflow of PMCCNTR_EL0[31:0] or unsigned overflow
                    of PMCCNTR_EL0[63:0].
P<n>, bits [0:30] - Event counter overflow clear bit for PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0. If N
                    is less than 31, then bits [30:N] are RAZ/WI. When EL2 is
                    implemented and enabled in the current Security state, in
                    EL1 and EL0, N is the value in MDCR_EL2.HPMN. Otherwise, N
                    is the value in PMCR_EL0.N.
                        0b0 When read, means that PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 has not
                    overflowed since this bit was last cleared. When written,
                    has no effect.
                        0b1 When read, means that PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 has overflowed
                    since this bit was last cleared. When written, clears the
                    PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 overflow bit to 0.
                    If ARMv8.5-PMU is implemented, MDCR_EL2.HLP and PMCR_EL0.LP
                    control whether an overflow is detected from unsigned
                    overflow of PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0[31:0] or unsigned overflow of
                    PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0[63:0].

PMOVSSET_EL0.long_name: Performance Monitors Overflow Flag Status Set register
PMOVSSET_EL0.purpose:
Sets the state of the overflow bit for the Cycle Count Register, PMCCNTR_EL0,
and each of the implemented event counters PMEVCNTR<n>.

C, bit [31]       - Cycle counter overflow set bit.
                        0b0 When read, means the cycle counter has not
                    overflowed since this bit was last cleared. When written,
                    has no effect.
                        0b1 When read, means the cycle counter has overflowed
                    since this bit was last cleared. When written, sets the
                    cycle counter overflow bit to 1.
                    PMCR_EL0.LC controls whether an overflow is detected from
                    unsigned overflow of PMCCNTR_EL0[31:0] or unsigned overflow
                    of PMCCNTR_EL0[63:0].
P<n>, bits [0:30] - Event counter overflow set bit for PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0. If N is
                    less than 31, then bits [30:N] are RAZ/WI. When EL2 is
                    implemented and enabled in the current Security state, in
                    EL1 and EL0, N is the value in MDCR_EL2.HPMN. Otherwise, N
                    is the value in PMCR_EL0.N.
                        0b0 When read, means that PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 has not
                    overflowed since this bit was last cleared. When written,
                    has no effect.
                        0b1 When read, means that PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 has overflowed
                    since this bit was last cleared. When written, sets the
                    PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 overflow bit to 1.
                    If ARMv8.5-PMU is implemented, MDCR_EL2.HLP and PMCR_EL0.LP
                    control whether an overflow is detected from unsigned
                    overflow of PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0[31:0] or unsigned overflow of
                    PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0[63:0].

PMSCR_EL1.purpose:
Provides EL1 controls for Statistical Profiling

PCT, bits [6:7] - Physical Timestamp. If timestamp sampling is enabled and the
                  Profiling Buffer is owned by EL1, requests which timestamp
                  counter value is collected. If ARMv8.6-ECV is implemented,
                  this is a two bit field as shown. Otherwise, bit[7] is res0.
                      0b00 Virtual counter, CNTVCT_EL0, is collected.
                      0b01 Physical counter, CNTPCT_EL0, is collected.
                      0b11 Physical counter, CNTPCT_EL0, minus CNTPOFF_EL2 is
                  collected.
PCT, bits [6:7] - Physical Timestamp. Reserved. This field reads as 0b01 and
                  ignores writes. Software should treat this field as UNK/SBZP.
TS, bit [5]     - Timestamp enable.
                      0b0 Timestamp sampling disabled.
                      0b1 Timestamp sampling enabled.
PA, bit [4]     - Physical Address sample enable.
                      0b0 Physical addresses are not collected.
                      0b1 Physical addresses are collected.
CX, bit [3]     - CONTEXTIDR_EL1 sample enable.
                      0b0 CONTEXTIDR_EL1 is not collected.
                      0b1 CONTEXTIDR_EL1 is collected.
E1SPE, bit [1]  - EL1 Statistical Profiling Enable.
                      0b0 Sampling disabled at EL1.
                      0b1 Sampling enabled at EL1.
E0SPE, bit [0]  - EL0 Statistical Profiling Enable. Controls sampling at EL0
                  when HCR_EL2.TGE == 0 or if EL2 is disabled or not
                  implemented.
                      0b0 Sampling disabled at EL0.
                      0b1 Sampling enabled at EL0.

PMSCR_EL2.purpose:
Provides EL2 controls for Statistical Profiling

PCT, bits [6:7] - Physical Timestamp. If timestamp sampling is enabled,
                  determines which counter is collected. The behavior depends on
                  the Profiling Buffer owning Exception level. If ARMv8.6-ECV is
                  implemented, this is a two bit field as shown. Otherwise,
                  bit[7] is res0.
TS, bit [5]     - Timestamp Enable.
PA, bit [4]     - Physical Address Sample Enable.
CX, bit [3]     - CONTEXTIDR_EL2 Sample Enable.
E2SPE, bit [1]  - EL2 Statistical Profiling Enable.
E0HSPE, bit [0] - EL0 Statistical Profiling Enable.

PMSELR_EL0.long_name: Performance Monitors Event Counter Selection Register
PMSELR_EL0.purpose:
Selects the current event counter PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 or the cycle counter, CCNT.

PMSELR_EL0 is used in conjunction with PMXEVTYPER_EL0 to determine the event
that increments a selected event counter, and the modes and states in which the
selected counter increments.

It is also used in conjunction with PMXEVCNTR_EL0, to determine the value of a
selected event counter.

SEL, bits [0:4] - Selects event counter, PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0, where n is the value
                  held in this field. This value identifies which event counter
                  is accessed when a subsequent access to PMXEVTYPER_EL0 or
                  PMXEVCNTR_EL0 occurs. This field can take any value from 0
                  (0b00000) to (PMCR.N)-1, or 31 (0b11111). When PMSELR_EL0.SEL
                  is 0b11111, it selects the cycle counter and:
                    - A read of the PMXEVTYPER_EL0 returns the value of
                  PMCCFILTR_EL0.
                    - A write of the PMXEVTYPER_EL0 writes to PMCCFILTR_EL0.
                    - A read or write of PMXEVCNTR_EL0 has constrained
                  unpredictable effects. See PMXEVCNTR_EL0 for more details. For
                  details of the results of accesses to the event counters, see
                  PMXEVTYPER_EL0 and PMXEVCNTR_EL0. For information about the
                  number of counters accessible at each Exception level, see
                  MDCR_EL2.HPMN.

PMSEVFR_EL1.purpose:
Controls sample filtering by events. The overall filter is the logical AND of
these filters. For example, if E[3] and E[5] are both set to 1, only samples
that have both event 3 (Level 1 unified or data cache refill) and event 5 set
(TLB walk) are recorded

E[<z>], bits [48:63] - E[<z>] is the event filter for event <z>. If event <z> is
                       not implemented, or filtering on event <z> is not
                       supported, the corresponding bit is RAZ/WI.
E[<y>], bits [24:31] - E[<y>] is the event filter for event <y>. If event <y> is
                       not implemented, or filtering on event <y> is not
                       supported, the corresponding bit is RAZ/WI.
E[18], bit [18]      - Empty predicate.
E[17], bit [17]      - Partial predicate.
E[<x>], bits [12:15] - E[<x>] is the event filter for event <x>. If event <x> is
                       not implemented, or filtering on event <x> is not
                       supported, the corresponding bit is RAZ/WI.
E[11], bit [11]      - Alignment.
E[7], bit [7]        - Mispredicted.
E[5], bit [5]        - TLB walk.
E[3], bit [3]        - Level 1 data or unified cache refill.
E[1], bit [1]        - Architecturally retired.

PMSFCR_EL1.purpose:
Controls sample filtering. The filter is the logical AND of the FL, FT and FE
bits. For example, if FE == 1 and FT == 1 only samples including the selected
operation types and the selected events will be recorded

ST, bit [18] - Store filter enable
                   0b0 Do not record store operations
                   0b1 Record all store operations, including vector stores and
               all atomic operations
LD, bit [17] - Load filter enable
                   0b0 Do not record load operations
                   0b1 Record all load operations, including vector loads and
               atomic operations that return data
B, bit [16]  - Branch filter enable
                   0b0 Do not record branch and exception return operations
                   0b1 Record all branch and exception return operations
FL, bit [2]  - Filter by latency
                   0b0 Latency filtering disabled
                   0b1 Latency filtering enabled. Samples with a total latency
               less than PMSLATFR_EL1.MINLAT will not be recorded
FT, bit [1]  - Filter by operation type. The filter is the logical OR of the ST,
               LD and B bits. For example, if LD and ST are both set, both load
               and store operations are recorded
                   0b0 Type filtering disabled
                   0b1 Type filtering enabled. Samples not one of the selected
               operation types will not be recorded
FE, bit [0]  - Filter by event
                   0b0 Event filtering disabled
                   0b1 Event filtering enabled. Samples not including the events
               selected by PMSEVFR_EL1 will not be recorded

PMSICR_EL1.purpose:
Software must write zero to PMSICR_EL1 before enabling sample profiling for a
sampling session. Software must then treat PMSICR_EL1 as an opaque, 64-bit,
read/write register used for context switches only.

ECOUNT, bits [56:63] - Secondary sample interval counter.
COUNT, bits [0:31]   - Primary sample interval counter Provides the primary
                       counter used for sampling.

PMSIDR_EL1.purpose:
Describes the Statistical Profiling implementation to software

CountSize, bits [16:19] - Defines the size of the counters
MaxSize, bits [12:15]   - Defines the largest size for a single record, rounded
                          up to a power-of-two. If this is the same as the
                          minimum alignment (PMBIDR_EL1.Align), then each record
                          is exactly this size
Interval, bits [8:11]   - Recommended minimum sampling interval. This provides
                          guidance from the implementer to the smallest minimum
                          sampling interval, N.
ERnd, bit [5]           - Defines how the random number generator is used in
                          determining the interval between samples, when enabled
                          by PMSIRR_EL1.RND.
LDS, bit [4]            - Data source indicator for sampled load instructions
ArchInst, bit [3]       - Architectural instruction profiling
FL, bit [2]             - Filtering by latency. This bit is RAO.
FT, bit [1]             - Filtering by operation type. This bit is RAO.
FE, bit [0]             - Filtering by events. This bit is RAO.

PMSIRR_EL1.purpose:
Defines the interval between samples

INTERVAL, bits [8:31] - Bits [31:8] of the PMSICR_EL1 interval counter reload
                        value. Software must set this to a non-zero value. If
                        software sets this to zero, an unknown sampling interval
                        is used. Software should set this to a value greater
                        than the minimum indicated by PMSIDR_EL1.Interval
RND, bit [0]          - Controls randomization of the sampling interval
                            0b0 Disable randomization of sampling interval
                            0b1 Add (pseudo-)random jitter to sampling interval
                        The random number generator is not architected.

PMSLATFR_EL1.purpose:
Controls sample filtering by latency

MINLAT, bits [0:11] - Minimum latency. When PMSFCR_EL1.FL == 1, defines the
                      minimum total latency for filtered operations. Samples
                      with a total latency less than MINLAT will not be recorded
                      This field is ignored by the PE when PMSFCR_EL1.FL == 0.

PMSWINC_EL0.purpose:
Increments a counter that is configured to count the Software increment event,
event 0x00. For more information, see  'SW_INCR' in the Arm® Architecture
Reference Manual, Armv8, for Armv8-A architecture profile, section D5.

P<n>, bits [0:30] - Event counter software increment bit for PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0. If
                    N is less than 31, then bits [30:N] are WI. When EL2 is
                    implemented and enabled in the current Security state, in
                    EL1 and EL0, N is the value in MDCR_EL2.HPMN. Otherwise, N
                    is the value in PMCR_EL0.N.
                        0b0 No action. The write to this bit is ignored.
                        0b1 If PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 is enabled and configured to
                    count the software increment event, increments
                    PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 by 1. If PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0 is disabled, or not
                    configured to count the software increment event, the write
                    to this bit is ignored.

PMUSERENR_EL0.purpose:
Enables or disables EL0 access to the Performance Monitors.

ER, bit [3] - Event counter Read.
CR, bit [2] - Cycle counter Read.
SW, bit [1] - Traps Software Increment writes to EL1, or to EL2 when it is
              implemented and enabled for the current Security state and
              HCR_EL2.TGE is 1.
EN, bit [0] - Traps EL0 accesses to the Performance Monitor registers to EL1, or
              to EL2 when it is implemented and enabled for the current Security
              state and HCR_EL2.TGE is 1, from both Execution states as follows.

PMXEVCNTR_EL0.long_name: Performance Monitors Selected Event Count Register
PMXEVCNTR_EL0.purpose:
Reads or writes the value of the selected event counter, PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0.
PMSELR_EL0.SEL determines which event counter is selected.

PMEVCNTR<n>, bits [0:63] - Value of the selected event counter, PMEVCNTR<n>_EL0,
                           where n is the value stored in PMSELR_EL0.SEL.

PMXEVTYPER_EL0.long_name: Performance Monitors Selected Event Type Register
PMXEVTYPER_EL0.purpose:
When PMSELR_EL0.SEL selects an event counter, this accesses a PMEVTYPER<n>_EL0
register. When PMSELR_EL0.SEL selects the cycle counter, this accesses
PMCCFILTR_EL0.

Event type register or PMCCFILTR_EL0, bits [0:31] - When PMSELR_EL0.SEL == 31,
                                                    this register accesses
                                                    PMCCFILTR_EL0. Otherwise,
                                                    this register accesses
                                                    PMEVTYPER<n>_EL0 where n is
                                                    the value in PMSELR_EL0.SEL.

RGSR_EL1.purpose:
Random Allocation Tag Seed Register.

SEED, bits [8:23] - Seed register used for generating values returned by
                    RandomAllocationTag().
TAG, bits [0:3]   - Tag generated by the most recent IRG instruction.

RMR_EL1.purpose:
If EL1 is the highest implemented Exception level and this register is
implemented:

  - A write to the register at EL1 can request a Warm reset.
  - If EL1 can use AArch32 and AArch64, this register specifies the Execution
state that the PE boots into on a Warm reset.

RR, bit [1]   - Reset Request. Setting this bit to 1 requests a Warm reset.
AA64, bit [0] - When EL1 can use AArch32, determines which Execution state the
                PE boots into after a Warm reset:
                    0b0 AArch32.
                    0b1 AArch64.
                On coming out of the Warm reset, execution starts at the
                implementation defined reset vector address of the specified
                Execution state. If EL1 cannot use AArch32 this bit is RAO/WI.

RMR_EL2.purpose:
If EL2 is the highest implemented Exception level and this register is
implemented:

  - A write to the register at EL2 can request a Warm reset.
  - If EL2 can use AArch32 and AArch64, this register specifies the Execution
state that the PE boots into on a Warm reset.

RR, bit [1]   - Reset Request. Setting this bit to 1 requests a Warm reset.
AA64, bit [0] - When EL2 can use AArch32, determines which Execution state the
                PE boots into after a Warm reset:
                    0b0 AArch32.
                    0b1 AArch64.
                On coming out of the Warm reset, execution starts at the
                implementation defined reset vector address of the specified
                Execution state. If EL2 cannot use AArch32 this bit is RAO/WI.

RMR_EL3.purpose:
If EL3 is the implemented and this register is implemented:

  - A write to the register at EL3 can request a Warm reset.
  - If EL3 can use AArch32 and AArch64, this register specifies the Execution
state that the PE boots into on a Warm reset.

RR, bit [1]   - Reset Request. Setting this bit to 1 requests a Warm reset.
AA64, bit [0] - When EL3 can use AArch32, determines which Execution state the
                PE boots into after a Warm reset:
                    0b0 AArch32.
                    0b1 AArch64.
                On coming out of the Warm reset, execution starts at the
                implementation defined reset vector address of the specified
                Execution state. If EL3 cannot use AArch32 this bit is RAO/WI.

RNDR.purpose:
Random Number. Returns a 64-bit random number which is reseeded from the True
Random Number source at an implementation defined rate.

If the hardware returns a genuine random number, PSTATE.NZCV is set to 0b0000.

If the instruction cannot return a genuine random number in a reasonable period
of time, PSTATE.NZCV is set to 0b0100 and the data value returned in unknown.

RNDR is a read-only register.

RNDR, bits [0:63] - Random Number. Returns a 64-bit Random Number which is
                    reseeded from the True Random Number source at an
                    implementation defined rate.

RNDRRS.purpose:
Reseeded Random Number. Returns a 64-bit random number which is reseeded from
the True Random Number source at an implementation defined rate.

If the hardware returns a genuine random number, PSTATE.NZCV is set to 0b0000.

If the instruction cannot return a genuine random number in a reasonable period
of time, PSTATE.NZCV is set to 0b0100 and the data value returned in unknown.

RNDRRS is a read-only register.

RNDRRS, bits [0:63] - Reseeded Random Number. Returns a 64-bit Random Number
                      which is reseeded from the True Random Number source
                      immediately before this read.

RVBAR_EL1.long_name: Reset Vector Base Address Register (if EL2 and EL3 not implemented)
RVBAR_EL1.purpose:
If EL1 is the highest Exception level implemented, contains the implementation
defined address that execution starts from after reset when executing in AArch64
state.

bits [0:63] - Reset Address. The implementation defined address that execution
              starts from after reset when executing in 64-bit state. Bits[1:0]
              of this register are 00, as this address must be aligned, and the
              address must be within the physical address size supported by the
              PE.

RVBAR_EL2.long_name: Reset Vector Base Address Register (if EL3 not implemented)
RVBAR_EL2.purpose:
If EL2 is the highest Exception level implemented, contains the implementation
defined address that execution starts from after reset when executing in AArch64
state.

bits [0:63] - Reset Address. The implementation defined address that execution
              starts from after reset when executing in 64-bit state. Bits[1:0]
              of this register are 00, as this address must be aligned, and the
              address must be within the physical address size supported by the
              PE.

RVBAR_EL3.long_name: Reset Vector Base Address Register (if EL3 implemented)
RVBAR_EL3.purpose:
If EL3 is the highest Exception level implemented, contains the implementation
defined address that execution starts from after reset when executing in AArch64
state.

bits [0:63] - Reset Address. The implementation defined address that execution
              starts from after reset when executing in 64-bit state. Bits[1:0]
              of this register are 00, as this address must be aligned, and the
              address must be within the physical address size supported by the
              PE.

S3_<op1>_<Cn>_<Cm>_<op2>.purpose:
This area of the instruction set space is reserved for implementation defined
registers.

SCR_EL3.purpose:
Defines the configuration of the current Security state. It specifies:

  - The Security state of EL0, EL1, and EL2. The Security state is either Secure
or Non-secure.
  - The Execution state at lower Exception levels.
  - Whether IRQ, FIQ, SError interrupts, and External abort exceptions are taken
to EL3.
  - Whether various operations are trapped to EL3.

AMVOFFEN, bit [35]   - Activity Monitors Virtual Offsets Enable.
TWEDEL, bits [30:33] - TWE Delay.
TWEDEn, bit [29]     - TWE Delay Enable.
ECVEn, bit [28]      - ECV Enable.
FGTEn, bit [27]      - Enables access to the Fine-Grained Traps registers:
                       HAFGRTR_EL2, HDFGRTR_EL2, HDFGWTR_EL2, HFGRTR_EL2,
                       HFGITR_EL2 and HFGWTR_EL2.
ATA, bit [26]        - Allocation Tag Access.
EnSCXT, bit [25]     - Enable access to the SCXTNUM_EL2, SCXTNUM_EL1, and
                       SCXTNUM_EL0 registers.
FIEN, bit [21]       - Fault Injection enable.
NMEA, bit [20]       - Non-maskable External Aborts.
EASE, bit [19]       - External aborts to SError interrupt vector.
EEL2, bit [18]       - Secure EL2 Enable.
API, bit [17]        - Controls the use of the following instructions related to
                       Pointer Authentication.
API, bit [17]        - Controls the use of instructions related to Pointer
                       Authentication.
APK, bit [16]        - Trap registers holding "key" values for Pointer
                       Authentication.
TERR, bit [15]       - Trap Error record accesses.
TLOR, bit [14]       - Trap LOR registers.
TWE, bit [13]        - Traps EL2, EL1, and EL0 execution of WFE instructions to
                       EL3, from both Security states and both Execution states,
                       reported using EC syndrome value 0x01.
TWI, bit [12]        - Traps EL2, EL1, and EL0 execution of WFI instructions to
                       EL3, from both Security states and both Execution states,
                       reported using EC syndrome value 0x01.
ST, bit [11]         - Traps Secure EL1 accesses to the Counter-timer Physical
                       Secure timer registers to EL3, from AArch64 state only,
                       reported using EC syndrome value 0x18.
RW, bit [10]         - Execution state control for lower Exception levels.
SIF, bit [9]         - Secure instruction fetch.
SIF, bit [9]         - Secure instruction fetch.
HCE, bit [8]         - Hypervisor Call instruction enable.
SMD, bit [7]         - Secure Monitor Call disable.
EA, bit [3]          - External Abort and SError interrupt routing.
FIQ, bit [2]         - Physical FIQ Routing.
IRQ, bit [1]         - Physical IRQ Routing.
NS, bit [0]          - Non-secure bit.

SCTLR_EL1.purpose:
Provides top level control of the system, including its memory system, at EL1
and EL0.

TWEDEL, bits [46:49] - TWE Delay.
TWEDEn, bit [45]     - TWE Delay Enable.
DSSBS, bit [44]      - Default PSTATE.SSBS value on Exception Entry.
ATA, bit [43]        - Allocation Tag Access in EL1.
ATA0, bit [42]       - Allocation Tag Access in EL0.
TCF, bits [40:41]    - Tag Check Fail in EL1.
TCF0, bits [38:39]   - Tag Check Fail in EL0.
ITFSB, bit [37]      - When synchronous exceptions are not being generated by
                       Tag Check fails which are generated for Loads and Stores
                       in EL0 or EL1, controls the auto-synchronization of Tag
                       Check fails into TFSRE0_EL1 and TFSR_EL1.
BT1, bit [36]        - PAC Branch Type compatibility at EL1.
BT0, bit [35]        - PAC Branch Type compatibility at EL0.
EnIA, bit [31]       - Controls enabling of pointer authentication (using the
                       APIAKey_EL1 key) of instruction addresses in the EL1&0
                       translation regime.
EnIB, bit [30]       - Controls enabling of pointer authentication (using the
                       APIBKey_EL1 key) of instruction addresses in the EL1&0
                       translation regime.
LSMAOE, bit [29]     - Load Multiple and Store Multiple Atomicity and Ordering
                       Enable.
nTLSMD, bit [28]     - No Trap Load Multiple and Store Multiple to Device-nGRE
                       /Device-nGnRE/Device-nGnRnE memory.
EnDA, bit [27]       - Controls enabling of pointer authentication (using the
                       APDAKey_EL1 key) of instruction addresses in the EL1&0
                       translation regime.
UCI, bit [26]        - Traps EL0 execution of cache maintenance instructions, to
                       EL1, or to EL2 when it is implemented and enabled for the
                       current Security state and HCR_EL2.TGE is 1, from AArch64
                       state only, reported using EC syndrome value 0x18.
EE, bit [25]         - Endianness of data accesses at EL1, and stage 1
                       translation table walks in the EL1&0 translation regime.
E0E, bit [24]        - Endianness of data accesses at EL0.
SPAN, bit [23]       - Set Privileged Access Never, on taking an exception to
                       EL1.
EIS, bit [22]        - Exception Entry is Context Synchronizing.
IESB, bit [21]       - Implicit Error Synchronization event enable.
TSCXT, bit [20]      - Trap EL0 Access to the SCXTNUM_EL0 register, when EL0 is
                       using AArch64.
WXN, bit [19]        - Write permission implies XN (Execute-never).
nTWE, bit [18]       - Traps EL0 execution of WFE instructions to EL1, or to EL2
                       when it is implemented and enabled for the current
                       Security state and HCR_EL2.TGE is 1, from both Execution
                       states, reported using EC syndrome value 0x01.
nTWI, bit [16]       - Traps EL0 execution of WFI instructions to EL1, or to EL2
                       when it is implemented and enabled for the current
                       Security state and HCR_EL2.TGE is 1, from both Execution
                       states, reported using EC syndrome value 0x01.
UCT, bit [15]        - Traps EL0 accesses to the CTR_EL0 to EL1, or to EL2 when
                       it is implemented and enabled for the current Security
                       state and HCR_EL2.TGE is 1, from AArch64 state only,
                       reported using EC value 0x18.
DZE, bit [14]        - Traps EL0 execution of DC ZVA instructions to EL1, or to
                       EL2 when it is implemented and enabled for the current
                       Security state and HCR_EL2.TGE is 1, from AArch64 state
                       only, reported using EC syndrome value 0x18.
EnDB, bit [13]       - Controls enabling of pointer authentication (using the
                       APDBKey_EL1 key) of instruction addresses in the EL1&0
                       translation regime.
I, bit [12]          - Instruction access Cacheability control, for accesses at
                       EL0 and EL1:
EOS, bit [11]        - Exception Exit is Context Synchronizing.
EnRCTX, bit [10]     - Enable EL0 Access to the AArch32 CFPRCTX, DVPRCTX and
                       CPPRCTX instructions, and the AArch64 CFP RCTX, DVP RCT
                       and CPP RCTX instructions.
UMA, bit [9]         - User Mask Access.
SED, bit [8]         - SETEND instruction disable.
ITD, bit [7]         - IT Disable.
nAA, bit [6]         - Non-aligned access.
CP15BEN, bit [5]     - System instruction memory barrier enable.
SA0, bit [4]         - SP Alignment check enable for EL0.
SA, bit [3]          - SP Alignment check enable.
C, bit [2]           - Cacheability control, for data accesses.
A, bit [1]           - Alignment check enable.
M, bit [0]           - MMU enable for EL1 and EL0 stage 1 address translation.

SCTLR_EL2.purpose:
Provides top level control of the system, including its memory system, at EL2.

When ARMv8.1-VHE is implemented, and the value of HCR_EL2.{E2H, TGE} is {1, 1},
these controls apply also to execution at EL0.

DSSBS, bit [44]   - Default PSTATE.SSBS value on Exception Entry.
ATA, bit [43]     - Allocation Tag Access.
TCF, bits [40:41] - Tack Check Fail in EL2.
ITFSB, bit [37]   - When synchronous exceptions are not being generated by Tag
                    Check fails which are generated for Loads and Stores in EL0,
                    EL1 or EL2, controls the auto-synchronisaton of Tag Check
                    fails into TFSRE0_EL1, TFSR_EL1 and TFSR_EL2.
BT, bit [36]      - PAC Branch Type compatibility at EL2.
EnIA, bit [31]    - Controls enabling of pointer authentication (using the
                    APIAKey_EL1 key) of instruction addresses in the EL2&0
                    translation regime.
EnIB, bit [30]    - Controls enabling of pointer authentication (using the
                    APIBKey_EL1 key) of instruction addresses in the EL2&0
                    translation regime.
EnDA, bit [27]    - Controls enabling of pointer authentication (using the
                    APDAKey_EL1 key) of instruction addresses in the EL2&0
                    translation regime.
EE, bit [25]      - Endianness of data accesses at EL2, stage 1 translation
                    table walks in the EL2 or EL2&0 translation regime, and
                    stage 2 translation table walks in the EL1&0 translation
                    regime.
EIS, bit [22]     - Exception entry is a context synchronization event.
IESB, bit [21]    - Implicit Error Synchronization event enable.
WXN, bit [19]     - Write permission implies XN (Execute-never).
EnDB, bit [13]    - Controls enabling of pointer authentication (using the
                    APDBKey_EL1 key) of instruction addresses in the EL2&0
                    translation regime.
I, bit [12]       - Instruction access Cacheability control, for accesses at
                    EL2:
EOS, bit [11]     - Exception exit is a context synchronization Event.
nAA, bit [6]      - Non-aligned access.
SA, bit [3]       - SP Alignment check enable.
C, bit [2]        - Cacheability control, for data accesses.
A, bit [1]        - Alignment check enable.
M, bit [0]        - MMU enable for EL2 stage 1 address translation.

SCTLR_EL3.purpose:
Provides top level control of the system, including its memory system, at EL3.

DSSBS, bit [44]   - Default PSTATE.SSBS value on Exception Entry.
ATA, bit [43]     - Allocation Tag Access in EL3.
TCF, bits [40:41] - Tag Check Fail in EL3.
ITFSB, bit [37]   - When asynchronous exceptions are being generated by Tag
                    Check fails which are generated for Loads and Stores at any
                    exception level, controls the auto-synchronisaton of Tag
                    Check fails into TFSRE0_EL1 and TFSR_ELx.
BT, bit [36]      - PAC Branch Type compatibility at EL3.
EnIA, bit [31]    - Controls enabling of pointer authentication (using the
                    APIAKey_EL1 key) of instruction addresses in the EL3
                    translation regime.
EnIB, bit [30]    - Controls enabling of pointer authentication (using the
                    APIBKey_EL1 key) of instruction addresses in the EL3
                    translation regime.
EnDA, bit [27]    - Controls enabling of pointer authentication (using the
                    APDAKey_EL1 key) of instruction addresses in the EL3
                    translation regime.
EE, bit [25]      - Endianness of data accesses at EL3, and stage 1 translation
                    table walks in the EL3 translation regime.
EIS, bit [22]     - Exception Entry is Context Synchronizing.
IESB, bit [21]    - Implicit Error Synchronization event enable.
WXN, bit [19]     - Write permission implies XN (Execute-never).
EnDB, bit [13]    - Controls enabling of pointer authentication (using the
                    APDBKey_EL1 key) of instruction addresses in the EL3
                    translation regime.
I, bit [12]       - Instruction access Cacheability control, for accesses at
                    EL3:
EOS, bit [11]     - Exception Exit is Context Synchronizing.
nAA, bit [6]      - Non-aligned access.
SA, bit [3]       - SP Alignment check enable.
C, bit [2]        - Cacheability control, for data accesses.
A, bit [1]        - Alignment check enable.
M, bit [0]        - MMU enable for EL3 stage 1 address translation.

SCXTNUM_EL0.purpose:
Provides a number that can be used to separate out different context numbers
with the EL0 exception level, for the purpose of protecting against side-
channels using branch prediction and similar resources.

bits [0:63] - Software Context Number. A number to identify the context within
              the EL0 exception level.

SCXTNUM_EL1.purpose:
Provides a number that can be used to separate out different context numbers
with the EL1 exception level, for the purpose of protecting against side-
channels using branch prediction and similar resources.

bits [0:63] - Software Context Number. A number to identify the context within
              the EL1 exception level.

SCXTNUM_EL2.purpose:
Provides a number that can be used to separate out different context numbers
with the EL2 exception level, for the purpose of protecting against side-
channels using branch prediction and similar resources.

bits [0:63] - Software Context Number. A number to identify the context within
              the EL2 exception level.

SCXTNUM_EL3.purpose:
Provides a number that can be used to separate out different context numbers
with the EL3 exception level, for the purpose of protecting against side-
channels using branch prediction and similar resources.

bits [0:63] - Software Context Number. A number to identify the context within
              the EL3 exception level.

SDER32_EL2.purpose:
Allows access to the AArch32 register SDER from Secure EL2 and EL3 only.

SUNIDEN, bit [1] - Secure User Non-Invasive Debug Enable.
                       0b0 This bit does not affect Performance Monitors event
                   counting at Secure EL0.
                       0b1 If EL1 is using AArch32, Performance Monitors event
                   counting is allowed in Secure EL0.
SUIDEN, bit [0]  - Secure User Invasive Debug Enable.
                       0b0 This bit does not affect the generation of debug
                   exceptions at Secure EL0.
                       0b1 If EL1 is using AArch32, debug exceptions from Secure
                   EL0 are enabled.

SDER32_EL3.purpose:
Allows access to the AArch32 register SDER from AArch64 state only. Its value
has no effect on execution in AArch64 state.

SUNIDEN, bit [1] - Secure User Non-Invasive Debug Enable.
                       0b0 This bit does not affect Performance Monitors event
                   counting at Secure EL0.
                       0b1 If EL1 is using AArch32, Performance Monitors event
                   counting is allowed in Secure EL0.
SUIDEN, bit [0]  - Secure User Invasive Debug Enable.
                       0b0 This bit does not affect the generation of debug
                   exceptions at Secure EL0.
                       0b1 If EL1 is using AArch32, debug exceptions from Secure
                   EL0 are enabled.

SPSR_EL1.purpose:
Holds the saved process state when an exception is taken to EL1.

N, bit [31]           - Negative Condition flag.
Z, bit [30]           - Zero Condition flag.
C, bit [29]           - Carry Condition flag.
V, bit [28]           - Overflow Condition flag.
Q, bit [27]           - Overflow or saturation flag.
IT[1:0], bits [25:26] - If-Then.
DIT, bit [24]         - Data Independent Timing.
SSBS, bit [23]        - Speculative Store Bypass.
PAN, bit [22]         - Privileged Access Never.
SS, bit [21]          - Software Step.
IL, bit [20]          - Illegal Execution state.
GE, bits [16:19]      - Greater than or Equal flags.
IT[7:2], bits [10:15] - If-Then.
E, bit [9]            - Endianness.
A, bit [8]            - SError interrupt mask.
I, bit [7]            - IRQ interrupt mask.
F, bit [6]            - FIQ interrupt mask.
T, bit [5]            - T32 Instruction set state.
M[4], bit [4]         - Execution state.
M[3:0], bits [0:3]    - AArch32 Mode.

Holds the saved process state when an exception is taken to EL2.

Z, bit [30]           - Zero Condition flag.
C, bit [29]           - Carry Condition flag.
V, bit [28]           - Overflow Condition flag.
Q, bit [27]           - Overflow or saturation flag.
IT[1:0], bits [25:26] - If-Then.
DIT, bit [24]         - Data Independent Timing.
SSBS, bit [23]        - Speculative Store Bypass.
PAN, bit [22]         - Privileged Access Never.
SS, bit [21]          - Software Step.
IL, bit [20]          - Illegal Execution state.

IT[7:2], bits [10:15] - If-Then.
E, bit [9]            - Endianness.
A, bit [8]            - SError interrupt mask.
I, bit [7]            - IRQ interrupt mask.
F, bit [6]            - FIQ interrupt mask.
T, bit [5]            - T32 Instruction set state.
M[4], bit [4]         - Execution state.
M[3:0], bits [0:3]    - AArch32 Mode.

PAN, bit [22]         - Privileged Access Never.

IT[1:0], bits [25:26] - If-Then.

N, bit [31]           - Negative Condition flag.
Z, bit [30]           - Zero Condition flag.
C, bit [29]           - Carry Condition flag.
V, bit [28]           - Overflow Condition flag.
Q, bit [27]           - Overflow or saturation flag.
IT[1:0], bits [25:26] - If-Then.
J, bit [24]           - res0.
SSBS, bit [23]        - Speculative Store Bypass.
PAN, bit [22]         - Privileged Access Never.
DIT, bit [21]         - Data Independent Timing.
IL, bit [20]          - Illegal Execution state.

C, bit [29]           - Carry Condition flag.

Q, bit [27]           - Overflow or saturation flag.
