SPSel.purpose:
Allows the Stack Pointer to be selected between SP_EL0 and SP_ELx.

SP, bit [0] - Stack pointer to use. Possible values of this bit are:
                  0b0 Use SP_EL0 at all Exception levels.
                  0b1 Use SP_ELx for Exception level ELx.

SP_EL0.purpose:
Holds the stack pointer associated with EL0. At higher Exception levels, this is
used as the current stack pointer when the value of SPSel.SP is 0.

bits [0:63] - Stack pointer.

SP_EL1.purpose:
Holds the stack pointer associated with EL1. When executing at EL1, the value of
SPSel.SP determines the current stack pointer:

 SPSel.SP | Current stack pointer
 ---------+----------------------
 0b0      | SP_EL0               
 0b1      | SP_EL1               

bits [0:63] - Stack pointer.

SP_EL2.purpose:
Holds the stack pointer associated with EL2. When executing at EL2, the value of
SPSel. SP determines the current stack pointer:

 SPSel.SP | Current stack pointer
 ---------+----------------------
 0b0      | SP_EL0               
 0b1      | SP_EL2               

bits [0:63] - Stack pointer.

SP_EL3.purpose:
Holds the stack pointer associated with EL3. When executing at EL3, the value of
SPSel.SP determines the current stack pointer:

 SPSel.SP | Current stack pointer
 ---------+----------------------
 0b0      | SP_EL0               
 0b1      | SP_EL3               

bits [0:63] - Stack pointer.

SSBS.purpose:
Allows access to the Speculative Store Bypass Safe bit.

SSBS, bit [12] - Speculative Store Bypass Safe. Prohibits speculative loads or
                 stores which might practically allow a cache timing side
                 channel. A cache timing side channel might be exploited where a
                 load or store uses an address that is derived from a register
                 that is being loaded from memory using a load instruction
                 speculatively read from a memory location. If PSTATE.SSBS is
                 enabled, the address derived from the load instruction might be
                 from earlier in the coherence order than the latest store to
                 that memory location with the same virtual address.
                     0b0 Hardware is not permitted to load or store
                 speculatively, in a manner that could practically give rise to
                 a cache timing side channel, using an address derived from a
                 register value that has been loaded from memory using a load
                 instruction (L) that speculatively reads an entry from earlier
                 in the coherence order from that location being loaded from
                 than the entry generated by the latest store (S) to that
                 location using the same virtual address as L.
                     0b1 Hardware is permitted to load or store speculatively,
                 in a manner that could practically give rise to a cache timing
                 side channel, using an address derived from a register value
                 that has been loaded from memory using a load instruction (L)
                 that speculatively reads an entry from earlier in the coherence
                 order fro that location being loaded from than the entry
                 generated by the latest store (S) to that location using the
                 same virtual address as L.
                 The value of this bit is set to the value in the
                 SCTLR_ELx.DSSBS field on taking an exception to ELx.

TCO.purpose:
When ARMv8.5-MemTag is implemented, this register allows tag checks to be
disabled globally.

TCO, bit [25] - Allows memory tag checks to be globally disabled.
                    0b0 Loads and Stores are not affected by this control.
                    0b1 Loads and Stores are unchecked.

TCR_EL1.purpose:
The control register for stage 1 of the EL1&0 translation regime.

TCMA1, bit [58]     - Controls the generation of Unchecked accesses at EL1, and
                      at EL0 if HCR_EL2.{E2H,TGE}!={1,1}, when address[59:55] =
                      0b11111.
TCMA0, bit [57]     - Controls the generation of Unchecked accesses at EL1, and
                      at EL0 if HCR_EL2.{E2H,TGE}!={1,1}, when address[59:55] =
                      0b00000.
E0PD1, bit [56]     - Faulting control for EL0 access to any address translated
                      by TTBR1_EL1.
E0PD0, bit [55]     - Faulting control for EL0 access to any address translated
                      by TTBR0_EL1.
NFD1, bit [54]      - Non-fault translation table walk disable for stage 1
                      translations using TTBR1_EL1.
NFD0, bit [53]      - Non-fault translation table walk disable for stage 1
                      translations using TTBR0_EL1.
TBID1, bit [52]     - Controls the use of the top byte of instruction addresses
                      for address matching.
TBID0, bit [51]     - Controls the use of the top byte of instruction addresses
                      for address matching.
HWU162, bit [50]    - Hardware Use.
HWU161, bit [49]    - Hardware Use.
HWU160, bit [48]    - Hardware Use.
HWU159, bit [47]    - Hardware Use.
HWU062, bit [46]    - Hardware Use.
HWU061, bit [45]    - Hardware Use.
HWU060, bit [44]    - Hardware Use.
HWU059, bit [43]    - Hardware Use.
HPD1, bit [42]      - Hierarchical Permission Disables.
HPD0, bit [41]      - Hierarchical Permission Disables.
HD, bit [40]        - Hardware management of dirty state in stage 1 translations
                      from EL0 and EL1.
HA, bit [39]        - Hardware Access flag update in stage 1 translations from
                      EL0 and EL1.
TBI1, bit [38]      - Top Byte ignored - indicates whether the top byte of an
                      address is used for address match for the TTBR1_EL1
                      region, or ignored and used for tagged addresses.
TBI0, bit [37]      - Top Byte ignored - indicates whether the top byte of an
                      address is used for address match for the TTBR0_EL1
                      region, or ignored and used for tagged addresses.
AS, bit [36]        - ASID Size.
IPS, bits [32:34]   - Intermediate Physical Address Size.
TG1, bits [30:31]   - Granule size for the TTBR1_EL1.
SH1, bits [28:29]   - Shareability attribute for memory associated with
                      translation table walks using TTBR1_EL1.
ORGN1, bits [26:27] - Outer cacheability attribute for memory associated with
                      translation table walks using TTBR1_EL1.
IRGN1, bits [24:25] - Inner cacheability attribute for memory associated with
                      translation table walks using TTBR1_EL1.
EPD1, bit [23]      - Translation table walk disable for translations using
                      TTBR1_EL1.
A1, bit [22]        - Selects whether TTBR0_EL1 or TTBR1_EL1 defines the ASID.
T1SZ, bits [16:21]  - The size offset of the memory region addressed by
                      TTBR1_EL1.
TG0, bits [14:15]   - Granule size for the TTBR0_EL1.
SH0, bits [12:13]   - Shareability attribute for memory associated with
                      translation table walks using TTBR0_EL1.
ORGN0, bits [10:11] - Outer cacheability attribute for memory associated with
                      translation table walks using TTBR0_EL1.
IRGN0, bits [8:9]   - Inner cacheability attribute for memory associated with
                      translation table walks using TTBR0_EL1.
EPD0, bit [7]       - Translation table walk disable for translations using
                      TTBR0_EL1.
T0SZ, bits [0:5]    - The size offset of the memory region addressed by
                      TTBR0_EL1.

TCR_EL2.purpose:
The control register for stage 1 of the EL2, or EL2&0, translation regime:

  - When the Effective value of HCR_EL2.E2H is 0, this register controls stage 1
of the EL2 translation regime, that supports a single VA range, translated using
TTBR0_EL2.
  - When the value of HCR_EL2.E2H is 1, this register controls stage 1 of the
EL2&0 translation regime, that supports both:
    - A lower VA range, translated using TTBR0_EL2.
    - A higher VA range, translated using TTBR1_EL2.

TCMA, bit [30]      - Controls the generation of Unchecked accesses at EL2 when
                      address [59:56] = 0b0000.
TBID, bit [29]      - Controls the use of the top byte of instruction addresses
                      for address matching.
HWU62, bit [28]     - Hardware Use.
HWU61, bit [27]     - Hardware Use.
HWU60, bit [26]     - Hardware Use.
HWU59, bit [25]     - Hardware Use.
HPD, bit [24]       - Hierarchical Permission Disables.
HD, bit [22]        - Hardware management of dirty state in stage 1 translations
                      from EL2.
HA, bit [21]        - Hardware Access flag update in stage 1 translations from
                      EL2.
TBI, bit [20]       - Top Byte Ignored.
PS, bits [16:18]    - Physical Address Size.
TG0, bits [14:15]   - Granule size for the TTBR0_EL2.
SH0, bits [12:13]   - Shareability attribute for memory associated with
                      translation table walks using TTBR0_EL2.
ORGN0, bits [10:11] - Outer cacheability attribute for memory associated with
                      translation table walks using TTBR0_EL2.
IRGN0, bits [8:9]   - Inner cacheability attribute for memory associated with
                      translation table walks using TTBR0_EL2.
T0SZ, bits [0:5]    - The size offset of the memory region addressed by
                      TTBR0_EL2.

TCR_EL3.purpose:
The control register for stage 1 of the EL3 translation regime.

TCMA, bit [30]      - Controls the generation of Unchecked accesses at EL3 when
                      address [59:56] = 0b0000.
TBID, bit [29]      - Controls the use of the top byte of instruction addresses
                      for address matching.
HWU62, bit [28]     - Hardware Use.
HWU61, bit [27]     - Hardware Use.
HWU60, bit [26]     - Hardware Use.
HWU59, bit [25]     - Hardware Use.
HPD, bit [24]       - Hierarchical Permission Disables.
HD, bit [22]        - Hardware management of dirty state in stage 1 translations
                      from EL3.
HA, bit [21]        - Hardware Access flag update in stage 1 translations from
                      EL3.
TBI, bit [20]       - Top Byte Ignored.
PS, bits [16:18]    - Physical Address Size.
TG0, bits [14:15]   - Granule size for the TTBR0_EL3.
SH0, bits [12:13]   - Shareability attribute for memory associated with
                      translation table walks using TTBR0_EL3.
ORGN0, bits [10:11] - Outer cacheability attribute for memory associated with
                      translation table walks using TTBR0_EL3.
IRGN0, bits [8:9]   - Inner cacheability attribute for memory associated with
                      translation table walks using TTBR0_EL3.
T0SZ, bits [0:5]    - The size offset of the memory region addressed by
                      TTBR0_EL3.

TFSRE0_EL1.purpose:
Holds accumulated Tag Check Fails occurring in EL0 which are not taken
precisely.

TF1, bit [1] - Tag Check Fail. Asynchronously set to 1 when a Tag Check fail
               using a virtual address with bit<55>==0b1 occurs.
TF0, bit [0] - Tag Check Fail. Asynchronously set to 1 when a Tag Check fail
               using a virtual address with bit<55>==0b0 occurs.

TFSR_EL1.purpose:
Holds accumulated Tag Check Fails occurring in EL1 which are not taken
precisely.

TF1, bit [1] - Tag Check Fail. Asynchronously set to 1 when a Tag Check fail
               using a virtual address with bit<55>==0b1 occurs.
TF0, bit [0] - Tag Check Fail. Asynchronously set to 1 when a Tag Check fail
               using a virtual address with bit<55>==0b0 occurs.

TFSR_EL2.purpose:
Holds accumulated Tag Check Fails occurring in EL2 which are not taken
precisely.

TF1, bit [1] - Tag Check Fail. Asynchronously set to 1 when a Tag Check fail
               using a virtual address with bit<55>==0b1 occurs.
               When HCR_EL2.E2H==0b0, this field is res0.
TF0, bit [0] - Tag Check Fail. Asynchronously set to 1 when a Tag Check fail
               using a virtual address with bit<55>==0b0 occurs.

TFSR_EL3.purpose:
Holds accumulated Tag Check Fails occurring in EL3 which are not taken
precisely.

TF0, bit [0] - Tag Check Fail. Asynchronously set to 1 when a Tag Check fail
               using a virtual address with bit<55>==0b0 occurs.

TPIDRRO_EL0.long_name: EL0 Read-Only Software Thread ID Register
TPIDRRO_EL0.purpose:
Provides a location where software executing at EL1 or higher can store thread
identifying information that is visible to software executing at EL0, for OS
management purposes.

The PE makes no use of this register.

bits [0:63] - Thread ID. Thread identifying information stored by software
              running at this Exception level.

TPIDR_EL0.long_name: EL0 Read/Write Software Thread ID Register
TPIDR_EL0.purpose:
Provides a location where software executing at EL0 can store thread identifying
information, for OS management purposes.

The PE makes no use of this register.

bits [0:63] - Thread ID. Thread identifying information stored by software
              running at this Exception level.

TPIDR_EL1.purpose:
Provides a location where software executing at EL1 can store thread identifying
information, for OS management purposes.

The PE makes no use of this register.

bits [0:63] - Thread ID. Thread identifying information stored by software
              running at this Exception level.

TPIDR_EL2.purpose:
Provides a location where software executing at EL2 can store thread identifying
information, for OS management purposes.

The PE makes no use of this register.

bits [0:63] - Thread ID. Thread identifying information stored by software
              running at this Exception level.

TPIDR_EL3.purpose:
Provides a location where software executing at EL3 can store thread identifying
information, for OS management purposes.

The PE makes no use of this register.

bits [0:63] - Thread ID. Thread identifying information stored by software
              running at this Exception level.

TRFCR_EL1.purpose:
Provides EL1 controls for Trace.

TS, bits [5:6] - Timestamp Control
                     0b01 Virtual timestamp. The traced timestamp is the
                 physical counter value, minus the value of CNTVOFF_EL2.
                     0b10 Guest Physical timestamp. The traced timestamp is the
                 physical counter value, minus the value of CNTPOFF_EL2.
                     0b11 Physical timestamp. The traced timestamp is the
                 physical counter value.
                 All other values are reserved This field is ignored if any of
                 the following are true:
                   - SelfHostedTraceEnabled() == FALSE.
                   - EL2 is implemented and TRFCR_EL2.TS != 0b00. When EL2 is
                 implemented and enabled in the current Security state, the
                 physical counter uses a fixed physical offset of zero if either
                 of the following are true:
                   - CNTHCTL_EL2.ECV is 0.
                   - SCR_EL3.ECVEn is 0.
                   - HCR_EL2.{E2H, TGE} is {1, 1}.
E1TRE, bit [1] - EL1 Trace Enable.
                     0b0 Trace is prohibited at EL1.
                     0b1 Trace is allowed at EL1.
                 This field is ignored if SelfHostedTraceEnabled() == FALSE.
E0TRE, bit [0] - EL0 Trace Enable.
                     0b0 Trace is prohibited at EL0.
                     0b1 Trace is allowed at EL0.
                 This field is ignored if any of the following are true:
                   - SelfHostedTraceEnabled() == FALSE.
                   - EL2 is implemented and enabled in the current Security
                 state and HCR_EL2.TGE == 1.

TRFCR_EL2.purpose:
Provides EL2 controls for Trace.

TS, bits [5:6]  - Timestamp Control. Controls which timebase is used for trace
                  timestamps.
                      0b00 Timestamp controlled by TRFCR_EL1.TS or TRFCR.TS.
                      0b01 Virtual timestamp. The traced timestamp is the
                  physical counter value, minus the value of CNTVOFF_EL2.
                      0b10 Guest Physical timestamp. The traced timestamp is the
                  physical counter value, minus the value of CNTPOFF_EL2.
                      0b11 Physical timestamp. The traced timestamp is the
                  physical counter value.
CX, bit [3]     - CONTEXTIDR_EL2 and VMID trace enable.
                      0b0 CONTEXTIDR_EL2 and VMID trace prohibited.
                      0b1 CONTEXTIDR_EL2 and VMID trace allowed.
E2TRE, bit [1]  - EL2 Trace Enable.
                      0b0 Trace is prohibited at EL2.
                      0b1 Trace is allowed at EL2.
E0HTRE, bit [0] - EL0 Trace Enable.
                      0b0 Trace is prohibited at EL0 when HCR_EL2.TGE == 1.
                      0b1 Trace is allowed at EL0 when HCR_EL2.TGE == 1.

TTBR0_EL1.purpose:
Holds the base address of the translation table for the initial lookup for stage
1 of the translation of an address from the lower VA range in the EL1&0
translation regime, and other information for this translation regime.

ASID, bits [48:63] - An ASID for the translation table base address.
BADDR, bits [1:47] - Translation table base address, A[47:x] or A[51:x],
                     bits[47:1].
CnP, bit [0]       - Common not Private.

TTBR0_EL2.purpose:
When HCR_EL2.E2H is 0, holds the base address of the translation table for the
initial lookup for stage 1 of an address translation in the EL2 translation
regime, and other information for this translation regime.

When HCR_EL2.E2H is 1, holds the base address of the translation table for the
initial lookup for stage 1 of the translation of an address from the lower VA
range in the EL2&0 translation regime, and other information for this
translation regime.

ASID, bits [48:63] - When HCR_EL2.E2H is 0, this field is res0.
BADDR, bits [1:47] - Translation table base address, A[47:x] or A[51:x],
                     bits[47:1].
CnP, bit [0]       - Common not Private.

TTBR0_EL3.purpose:
Holds the base address of the translation table for the initial lookup for stage
1 of an address translation in the EL3 translation regime, and other information
for this translation regime.

BADDR, bits [1:47] - Translation table base address, A[47:x] or A[51:x].
CnP, bit [0]       - Common not Private.

TTBR1_EL1.purpose:
Holds the base address of the translation table for the initial lookup for stage
1 of the translation of an address from the higher VA range in the EL1&0 stage 1
translation regime, and other information for this translation regime.

ASID, bits [48:63] - An ASID for the translation table base address.
BADDR, bits [1:47] - Translation table base address, A[47:x] or A[51:x],
                     bits[47:1].
CnP, bit [0]       - Common not Private.

TTBR1_EL2.purpose:
When HCR_EL2.E2H is 1, holds the base address of the translation table for the
initial lookup for stage 1 of the translation of an address from the higher VA
range in the EL2&0 translation regime, and other information for this
translation regime.

When HCR_EL2.E2H is 0, the contents of this register are ignored by the PE,
except for a direct read or write of the register.

ASID, bits [48:63] - An ASID for the translation table base address.
BADDR, bits [1:47] - Translation table base address, A[47:x] or A[51:x],
                     bits[47:1].
CnP, bit [0]       - Common not Private.

UAO.purpose:
Allows access to the User Access Override bit.

UAO, bit [23] - User Access Override.
                    0b0 The behavior of LDTR* and STTR* instructions is as
                defined in the base Armv8 architecture.
                    0b1 When executed at EL1, or at EL2 with HCR_EL2.{E2H, TGE}
                == {1, 1}, LDTR* and STTR* instructions behave as the equivalent
                LDR* and STR* instructions.
                When executed at EL3, or at EL2 with HCR_EL2.E2H == 0 or
                HCR_EL2.TGE == 0, the LDTR* and STTR* instructions behave as the
                equivalent LDR* and STR* instructions, regardless of the setting
                of the PSTATE.UAO bit.

VBAR_EL1.purpose:
Holds the vector base address for any exception that is taken to EL1.

bits [11:63] - Vector Base Address. Base address of the exception vectors for
               exceptions taken to EL1. If the implementation does not support
               ARMv8.2-LVA, then:
                 - If tagged addresses are being used, bits [55:48] of VBAR_EL1
               must be the same or else the use of the vector address will
               result in a recursive exception.
                 - If tagged addresses are not being used, bits [63:48] of
               VBAR_EL1 must be the same or else the use of the vector address
               will result in a recursive exception. If the implementation
               supports ARMv8.2-LVA, then:
                 - If tagged addresses are being used, bits [55:52] of VBAR_EL1
               must be the same or else the use of the vector address will
               result in a recursive exception.
                 - If tagged addresses are not being used, bits [63:52] of
               VBAR_EL1 must be the same or else the use of the vector address
               will result in a recursive exception.

VBAR_EL2.purpose:
Holds the vector base address for any exception that is taken to EL2.

bits [11:63] - Vector Base Address. Base address of the exception vectors for
               exceptions taken to EL2. If the implementation does not support
               ARMv8.2-LVA, then:
                 - If tagged addresses are being used, bits [55:48] of VBAR_EL2
               must be 0 or else the use of the vector address will result in a
               recursive exception.
                 - If tagged addresses are not being used, bits [63:48] of
               VBAR_EL2 must be 0 or else the use of the vector address will
               result in a recursive exception. If the implementation supports
               ARMv8.2-LVA, then:
                 - If tagged addresses are being used, bits [55:52] of VBAR_EL2
               must be the same or else the use of the vector address will
               result in a recursive exception.
                 - If tagged addresses are not being used, bits [63:52] of
               VBAR_EL2 must be the same or else the use of the vector address
               will result in a recursive exception.

VBAR_EL3.purpose:
Holds the vector base address for any exception that is taken to EL3.

bits [11:63] - Vector Base Address. Base address of the exception vectors for
               exceptions taken to EL3. If the implementation does not support
               ARMv8.2-LVA, then:
                 - If tagged addresses are being used, bits [55:48] of VBAR_EL3
               must be 0 or else the use of the vector address will result in a
               recursive exception.
                 - If tagged addresses are not being used, bits [63:48] of
               VBAR_EL3 must be 0 or else the use of the vector address will
               result in a recursive exception. If the implementation supports
               ARMv8.2-LVA, then:
                 - If tagged addresses are being used, bits [55:52] of VBAR_EL3
               must be the same or else the use of the vector address will
               result in a recursive exception.
                 - If tagged addresses are not being used, bits [63:52] of
               VBAR_EL3 must be the same or else the use of the vector address
               will result in a recursive exception.

VDISR_EL2.purpose:
Records that a virtual SError interrupt has been consumed by an ESB instruction
executed at EL1.

An indirect write to VDISR_EL2 made by an ESB instruction does not require an
explicit synchronization operation for the value written to be observed by a
direct read of DISR_EL1 or DISR occurring in program order after the ESB
instruction.

A, bit [31]      - Set to 1 when an ESB instruction defers a virtual SError
                   interrupt.
IDS, bit [24]    - The value copied from VSESR_EL2.IDS.
ISS, bits [0:23] - The value copied from VSESR_EL2.ISS.

VMPIDR_EL2.purpose:
Holds the value of the Virtualization Multiprocessor ID. This is the value
returned by EL1 reads of MPIDR_EL1.

Aff3, bits [32:39] - Affinity level 3. See the description of Aff0 for more
                     information. Aff3 is not supported in AArch32 state.
U, bit [30]        - Indicates a Uniprocessor system, as distinct from PE 0 in a
                     multiprocessor system. The possible values of this bit are:
                         0b0 Processor is part of a multiprocessor system.
                         0b1 Processor is part of a uniprocessor system.
MT, bit [24]       - Indicates whether the lowest level of affinity consists of
                     logical PEs that are implemented using a multithreading
                     type approach. See the description of Aff0 for more
                     information about affinity levels. The possible values of
                     this bit are:
                         0b0 Performance of PEs at the lowest affinity level is
                     largely independent.
                         0b1 Performance of PEs at the lowest affinity level is
                     very interdependent.
Aff2, bits [16:23] - Affinity level 2. See the description of Aff0 for more
                     information.
Aff1, bits [8:15]  - Affinity level 1. See the description of Aff0 for more
                     information.
Aff0, bits [0:7]   - Affinity level 0. This is the affinity level that is most
                     significant for determining PE behavior. Higher affinity
                     levels are increasingly less significant in determining PE
                     behavior. The assigned value of the MPIDR.{Aff2, Aff1,
                     Aff0} or MPIDR_EL1.{Aff3, Aff2, Aff1, Aff0} set of fields
                     of each PE must be unique within the system as a whole.

VNCR_EL2.purpose:
When ARMv8.4-NV is implemented, holds the base address that is used to define
the memory location that is accessed by transformed reads and writes of System
registers.

BADDR, bits [12:52] - Base Address. If the virtual address space for EL2 does
                      not support more than 48 bits, then bits [52:49] are RESS.
                      When a register read/write is transformed to be a Load or
                      Store, the address of the load/store is to
                      SignOffset(VNCR.BADDR:Offset<11:0>, 64).

VPIDR_EL2.purpose:
Holds the value of the Virtualization Processor ID. This is the value returned
by EL1 reads of MIDR_EL1.

Implementer, bits [24:31]  - The Implementer code. This field must hold an
                             implementer code that has been assigned by Arm.
                             Assigned codes include the following: Arm can
                             assign codes that are not published in this manual.
                             All values not assigned by Arm are reserved and
                             must not be used.
Variant, bits [20:23]      - An implementation defined variant number.
                             Typically, this field is used to distinguish
                             between different product variants, or major
                             revisions of a product.
Architecture, bits [16:19] - The permitted values of this field are:
PartNum, bits [4:15]       - An implementation defined primary part number for
                             the device. On processors implemented by Arm, if
                             the top four bits of the primary part number are
                             0x0 or 0x7, the variant and architecture are
                             encoded differently.
Revision, bits [0:3]       - An implementation defined revision number for the
                             device.

VSESR_EL2.purpose:
Provides the syndrome value reported to software on taking a virtual SError
interrupt exception to EL1, or on executing an ESB instruction at EL1.

When the virtual SError interrupt is taken to EL1 using AArch64, then the
syndrome value is reported in ESR_EL1.

When the virtual SError interrupt is taken to EL1 using AArch32, then the
syndrome value is reported in DFSR.{AET, ExT} and the remainder of DFSR is set
as defined by VMSAv8-32. For more information, see The AArch32 Virtual Memory
System Architecture.

When the virtual SError interrupt is deferred by an ESB instruction, then the
syndrome value is written to VDISR_EL2.

AET, bits [14:15] - When a virtual SError interrupt is taken to EL1 using
                    AArch32, DFSR[15:4] is set to VSESR_EL2.AET. When a virtual
                    SError interrupt is deferred by an ESB instruction,
                    VDISR_EL2[15:4] is set to VSESR_EL2.AET.
ExT, bit [12]     - When a virtual SError interrupt is taken to EL1 using
                    AArch32, DFSR[12] is set to VSESR_EL2.ExT. When a virtual
                    SError interrupt is deferred by an ESB instruction,
                    VDISR_EL2[12] is set to VSESR_EL2.ExT.

VSTCR_EL2.purpose:
The control register for stage 2 of the Secure EL1&0 translation regime.

SA, bit [30]      - Secure stage 2 translation output address space.
SW, bit [29]      - Secure stage 2 translation address space.
TG0, bits [14:15] - Secure stage 2 granule size for VSTTBR_EL2.
SL0, bits [6:7]   - Starting level of the Secure stage 2 translation lookup,
                    controlled by VSTCR_EL2. The meaning of this field depends
                    on the value of VSTCR_EL2.TG0.
SL0, bits [6:7]   - Starting level of the Secure stage 2 translation lookup,
                    controlled by VSTCR_EL2. The meaning of this field depends
                    on the value of VSTCR_EL2.TG0.
T0SZ, bits [0:5]  - The size offset of the memory region addressed by
                    VSTTBR_EL2. The region size is 2^(64-VSTCR_EL2.T0SZ) bytes.
                    The maximum and minimum possible values for this field
                    depend on the level of translation table and the memory
                    translation granule size, as described in the AArch64
                    Virtual Memory System Architecture chapter. If this field is
                    programmed to a value that is not consistent with the
                    programming of SL0, then a stage 2 level 0 Translation fault
                    is generated.

VSTTBR_EL2.long_name: Virtualization Secure Translation Table Base Register
VSTTBR_EL2.purpose:
The base register for stage 2 of the Secure EL1&0 translation regime. Holds the
base address of the translation table for the initial lookup for stage 2 of an
address translation in the Secure EL1&0 translation regime, and other
information for this translation stage.

BADDR, bits [1:47] - Translation table base address, A[47:x] or A[51:x].
CnP, bit [0]       - Common not Private, for stage 2 of the Secure EL1&0
                     translation regime.

VTCR_EL2.purpose:
The control register for stage 2 of the EL1&0 translation regime.

NSA, bit [30]       - Non-secure stage 2 translation output address space.
NSW, bit [29]       - Non-secure stage 2 translation table address space.
HWU62, bit [28]     - Hardware Use.
HWU61, bit [27]     - Hardware Use.
HWU60, bit [26]     - Hardware Use.
HWU59, bit [25]     - Hardware Use.
HD, bit [22]        - Hardware management of dirty state in stage 2 translations
                      when EL2 is enabled in the current Security state.
HA, bit [21]        - Hardware Access flag update in Non-secure and Secure stage
                      2 translations when EL2 is enabled in the current Security
                      state.
VS, bit [19]        - VMID Size.
PS, bits [16:18]    - Physical address Size for the Second Stage of translation.
TG0, bits [14:15]   - Granule size for the VTTBR_EL2.
SH0, bits [12:13]   - Shareability attribute for memory associated with
                      translation table walks using VTTBR_EL2 or VSTTBR_EL2.
ORGN0, bits [10:11] - Outer cacheability attribute for memory associated with
                      translation table walks using VTTBR_EL2 or VSTTBR_EL2.
IRGN0, bits [8:9]   - Inner cacheability attribute for memory associated with
                      translation table walks using VTTBR_EL2 or VSTTBR_EL2.
SL0, bits [6:7]     - Starting level of the Secure stage 2 translation lookup,
                      controlled by VTCR_EL2.
SL0, bits [6:7]     - Starting level of the Secure stage 2 translation lookup,
                      controlled by VTCR_EL2.
T0SZ, bits [0:5]    - The size offset of the memory region addressed by
                      VTTBR_EL2.

VTTBR_EL2.purpose:
Holds the base address of the translation table for the initial lookup for stage
2 of an address translation in the EL1&0 translation regime, and other
information for this translation regime.

VMID[15:8], bits [56:63] - Extension to VMID[7:0].
VMID[7:0], bits [48:55]  - The VMID for the translation table.
BADDR, bits [1:47]       - Translation table base address, A[47:x] or A[51:x],
                           bits[47:1].
CnP, bit [0]             - Common not Private.

ZCR_EL1.purpose:
The SVE Control Register for EL1 is used to control aspects of SVE visible at
Exception levels EL1 and EL0.

LEN, bits [0:3] - Constrains the scalable vector register length for EL1 and EL0
                  to (LEN+1)x128 bits. For all purposes other than returning the
                  result of a direct read of ZCR_EL1 then this field behaves as
                  if it is set to the minimum of the stored value and the
                  constrained length inherited from more privileged Exception
                  levels in the current Security state, rounded down to the
                  nearest implemented vector length. An indirect read of
                  ZCR_EL1.LEN appears to occur in program order relative to a
                  direct write of the same register, without the need for
                  explicit synchronization.

ZCR_EL2.purpose:
The SVE Control Register for EL2 is used to control aspects of SVE visible at
Exception levels EL2, EL1, and EL0, when EL2 is enabled in the current Security
state.

LEN, bits [0:3] - Constrains the scalable vector register length for EL2, EL1,
                  and EL0 to (LEN+1)x128 bits, when EL2 is enabled in the
                  current Security state. For all purposes other than returning
                  the result of a direct read of ZCR_EL2 then this field behaves
                  as if it is set to the minimum of the stored value and the
                  constrained length inherited from more privileged Exception
                  levels in the current Security state, rounded down to the
                  nearest implemented vector length. An indirect read of
                  ZCR_EL2.LEN appears to occur in program order relative to a
                  direct write of the same register, without the need for
                  explicit synchronization.

ZCR_EL3.purpose:
The SVE Control Register for EL3 is used to control aspects of SVE visible at
all Exception levels.

LEN, bits [0:3] - Constrains the scalable vector register length for all
                  Exception levels to (LEN+1)x128 bits. For all purposes other
                  than returning the result of a direct read of ZCR_EL3 then
                  this field behaves as if rounded down to the nearest
                  implemented vector length. An indirect read of ZCR_EL3.LEN
                  appears to occur in program order relative to a direct write
                  of the same register, without the need for explicit
                  synchronization.

APGAKeyLo_EL12.long_name: Pointer Authentication Key A for Code Low (EL12)

APGAKeyHi_EL12.long_name: Pointer Authentication Key A for Code High (EL12)

APIAKeyLo_EL12.long_name: Pointer Authentication Key A for Instruction Low (EL12)

APIAKeyHi_EL12.long_name: Pointer Authentication Key A for Instruction High (EL12)

APIBKeyLo_EL12.long_name: Pointer Authentication Key A for Instruction Low (EL12)

APIBKeyHi_EL12.long_name: Pointer Authentication Key A for Instruction High (EL12)

APDAKeyLo_EL12.long_name: Pointer Authentication Key A for Data Low (EL12)

APDAKeyHi_EL12.long_name: Pointer Authentication Key A for Data High (EL12)

APDBKeyLo_EL12.long_name: Pointer Authentication Key A for Data Low (EL12)

APDBKeyHi_EL12.long_name: Pointer Authentication Key A for Data High (EL12)

APVMKEYLO_EL2.long_name: Pointer Authentication VM Machine Key Low

APVMKEYHI_EL2.long_name: Pointer Authentication VM Machine Key High

UPMESR0_EL1.long_name: Uncore Performance Monitor Event Selection Register 0

UPMECM0_EL1.long_name: Uncore Performance Monitor Event Core Mask 0

UPMECM1_EL1.long_name: Uncore Performance Monitor Event Core Mask 1

UPMPCM_EL1.long_name: Uncore Performance Monitor PMI Core Mask

UPMECM2_EL1.long_name: Uncore Performance Monitor Event Core Mask 2

UPMECM3_EL1.long_name: Uncore Performance Monitor Event Core Mask 3

UPMESR1_EL1.long_name: Uncore Performance Monitor Event Selection Register 1
